title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: The original 1970 US tinda muta release of The Man Who Sold the World employed a cartoon-like cover drawing by Bowie's friend Michael J. Weller, featuring a cowboy in front of the Cane Hill mental asylum.[16] Weller, whose friend was a patient there, suggested the idea after Bowie had asked him to create a design that would capture the music's foreboding tone. Drawing on pop art styles, he depicted a dreary main entrance block to the hospital with a damaged clock tower. For the design's foreground, he used a photograph of John Wayne to draw a cowboy figure wearing a ten-gallon hat and a rifle, which was meant as an allusion to the song "Running Gun Blues". Bowie suggested Weller incorporate the "exploding head" signature on the cowboy's hat, a feature he had previously used on his posters while a part of the Arts Lab. He also added an empty speech balloon for the cowboy figure, which was intended to have the line "roll up your sleeves and show us your arms"—a pun on record players, guns, and drug use—but Mercury found the idea too risqué and the balloon was left blank. According to Bowie biographer Nicholas Pegg, "at this point, David's intention was to call the album Metrobolist, a play on Fritz Lang's Metropolis: the title would remain on the tape boxes even after Mercury had released the LP in America as The Man Who Sold the World."[4] Bowie was enthusiastic about the finished design, but soon reconsidered the idea and had the art department at Philips Records, a subsidiary of Mercury, enlist photographer Keith MacMillan to shoot an alternate cover. The shoot took place in a "domestic environment" of the Haddon Hall living room, where Bowie reclined on a chaise longue in a cream and blue satin "man's dress", an early indication of his interest in exploiting his androgynous appearance.[4] The dress was designed by British fashion designer Michael Fish.[17] It has been said that his "bleached blond locks, falling below shoulder level" in the photo, were inspired by

author: System
content: 09 January 2019 Nelson Maligro, ON6 Philippine Navy Via email: nelsonmaligro@gmail.com Dear Sir: Thank you for meeting with us last November 2018 to discuss your document management requirements. May we take this opportunity to summarize the Globodox DMS objectives discussed during the meeting: 1. To respond quickly to the search/retrieval of records. Globodox DMS provides several search methods including the retrieval of records by indices or by a document's content, very similar to how a search and retrieve is made in Yahoo or Google. 2. To demonstrate office efficiency. Retrieval of records can be by school name, by teacher's name such as last name, first name, middle name, locality, and other fields. FMWC would like to define. Globodox DMS provides simple and advance search functions. 3. To have a backup of records electronically. Electronic records (scanned civil registry images, Microsoft Office files, email, and other forms of electronic files) placed into Globodox DMS can be copied into external medias to serve as a backup of original paper and office records. 4. To maintain disaster recovery measures in times of fire, rain, and earthquakes. In case of disaster, Globodox DMS can utilize these external disks/CDs and recreate the server database for business continuity. Floro International Corporation Unit 717B, ACG Buding Shaw Boulevard, Wack Wack, Mandaluyong Phone 533-2584 Fax: 654-7215 email: floro@floro-intl.com www.floro-intl.com, www.digitizingdocuments.com 2000-001 5. To relieve employees from clerical activities such as searching, retrieving and printing. 6. To provide security of original documents. Paper documents do not need to be accessed, thereby minimizing loss or misfiled documents though the use of Globodox DMS. Moreover, minimizing the handling of paper documents minimizes the wear and tear caused by handling. 7. To provide transfer of technology to the employees of FMWC through training and implementation of the Globodox DMS system. We have

title: Update.pptx
filename: D:/drive/N6B/SOP/2020/APR/Brief Description of the General Function of.docx
author: System
content: Brief Description of the General Function of Information Technology Officer (ITO) II: Formulate plans, policies, and manage IT infrastructure and cyber security controls; supervise the activities of subordinate analyst, researcher, programmer, and technologist in the conduct of systems development and maintenance of computers and IT networks. Specific Duties and Responsibilities: Develop, review, and update the PN cyber security and information system policies and procedures. Develop, review, and update the PN Information Systems Strategic Plan (ISSP). Oversees the activities of subordinate analyst, and programmers in the development of information systems. Oversees the activities of subordinate technologist in the conduct of preventive and corrective maintenance of computers and networks. Evaluate and facilitate the fund request of PN units pertaining to Information and Communication Technology hardware and software. Oversees the implementation of all funded ICT projects of the PN including cyber security controls, network infrastructure, and information systems. Provides technical advice to superior officers on matters pertaining to information technology and cyber security.

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: Chapter 1 `INTRODUCTION Background of the Study Data exchange or data communication is a key process of providing accurate and timely information to senior leaders, top management, and decision makers. It involves the use of email, instant messaging, video conference, chat, online forums, and other applications that transmit data from sender to receiver. Many organizations and modern companies prefer to use instant messaging rather than email for simpler and more user-friendly collaboration among staff and management. It also exchanges data almost at an instant, allowing two-way communication in near real-time. Instant messaging applications like Facebook messenger, SKYPE, and Yahoo Messenger provide easy, fast, and cost-effective means of text, voice, and video communication. It has become the most preferred application to communicate with peers, families, and among professionals from various industries and sectors. Businesses are now beginning to embrace IM for their office communication. Although it is less formal than a face to face meeting, it can bridge the gap of needing to collaborate and communicate with each other. Private companies, schools, organizations, and government agencies use IM to support or provide redundancy with their other existing mode of communication. The military recognizes the necessity to develop or acquire a secure, reliable, and near real-time data communication tool for effective exchange of information and to provide the high-command a means to collate information needed for decision-making. In today's network-centric operation, Instant Messaging (IM) is an essential information communication tool for rapid delivery of messages and reports, and for situational awareness. The US military has long been using IM for its military operations. In fact, Cummings (2004, p. 654) stated that "it was the primary means of communication between navy ships during Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2003". The Philippine Navy (PN), a branch of service in t

title: Update.pptx
filename: D:/drive/N6B/SOP/2020/MAY/CEIS Dir on PN Standard LAN and Network Security .docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS DIRECTIVE ) NUMBER… ) SUBJECT: Supplemental Guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities TO: See Distribution REFERENCES: SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities CEIS LD Nr. 2012-001 dtd 19 Dec 2012, Subj: PN Standard LAN and Network Security Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. PURPOSE: This CEIS Directive prescribes the supplemental guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities particularly on the conformity to the SANS twenty (20) Critical Security Controls. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cybersecurity -deliberate synergy of technologies, processes, and practices to protect information and the networks, computer systems and appliances, and programs used to collect, process, store, and transport that information from attack, damage and unauthorized access. Cybersecurity Posture – refers to the overall cybersecurity strength of an PN. It expresses the relative security of the IT estate and its vulnerability to outside threats. Risk Assessment – is a process of identifying, estimating, and prioritizing risks of PNal assets and operations. It involves evaluating hazards, and developing plans to remove or minimize the level of risk. Security Controls - refers to technical, physical, and administrative safeguards to detect cyber threats, minimize risks, and protect from cyber attacks. POLICIES Malware Protection Utilize centr

General:  ROOTCON is an annual cyber security conference and the largest hacking conference in the Philippines. The event aims to foster camaraderie and sharing of expertise among cybersecurity professionals, security researchers, and ethical hackers. A two-day activity showcasing lectures on the latest techniques and tactics of hacking, a hands-on experience on ways of cracking devices; and competing in the Capture the Flag (CTF) contest - a special kind of cybersecurity competition designed to challenge its participants to solve computer security problems. This activity was held on 26-27 September 2019 at Taal Vista Hotel, Tagaytay and was attended by LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, CPT JEAN PAUL T SAN GABRIEL PN(M), LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN, LTJG JOMAR M WELBA PN, SN2 Rhea T Espinosa PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. II. content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada  2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila Secretary EDUARDO M. AÑO Department of Interior and Local Government DILG NAPOLCOM Center EDSA corner Quezon Avenue Quezon City, Metro Manila Dear Secretary Año: The Philippine Navy (PN) will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019 (CyDex 2019) from 15 to 26 July 2019 at Philippine Navy Officers Club, Marine Barracks Rudiardo Brown (MBRB), Fort Bonifacio, Taguig City. The objective of this exercise is to evaluate the responsiveness and effectiveness of the existing PN doctrines, procedures, and protocols in cyber warfare. In this regard, the PN respectfully requests for a courtesy call on the Secretary or any of his concerned staff most convenient schedule to further discuss and articulate the intent of the command on this upcoming event, and the needed participation of your department. Likely   Occurs several times, a common occurrence.  Occasional  Occurs sporadically, but is not uncommon.  Seldom   Remotely possible, could occur at some time. Usually several things must go wrong for it to happen.  Unlikely   Can assume will not occur, but not impossible.  SEVERITY  Catastrophic  Complete mission failure or the loss of ability to accomplish a mission. Death or permanent total disability. Loss of major or mission-critical systems or equipment. Major property or facility damage. Severe environmental damage. Mission-critical security failure. Unacceptable collateral damage  Critical  Severely degraded mission capability or unit readiness. Permanent partial disability or temporary total disability exceeding three months time. Extensive major damage to equipment or systems. Significant damage to property or the environment. Security failure. Significant collateral damage. Marginal  Degraded mission capability or unit readiness. Minor damage to equipment or systems, property, or the environment. Lost days due to injury or illness not exceeding three months. Minor damage to property or the environment. Negligible  Little or no adverse impact on mission capability. First aid or minor medical treatment. Slight equipment or system damage, but fully functional or serviceable. Little or no property or environmental damage. title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_MS.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: 51 Chapter 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION This chapter presents the final output of the system and the result of the evaluation. Project description, project structure, and the capabilities and limitations are briefly discussed to elucidate the finished project. The result of the evaluation and its interpretation was also presented in this chapter. Project Description The Cryptographic IM (CIM) system is an instant messaging application that allows data communication among peers. It provides essential features for office collaboration such as one-to-one chat, group chat, file transfer, and others. Multi-layered encryption is integrated into the CIM to provide greater security. Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) and the Hidden in Plain Sight (HIPS) algorithm encrypts the data as it traverses across the network. The system was developed in modules or components making it agile in any type of deployment. Meaning, the CIM can be deployed even without the other modules if it is not required for a particular deployment. There are three (3) modules developed, the base, file transfer, and the encryption module. The base component provides the platform for the two (2) components and other future components to be integrated into. These future components can also be a third-party DLL, API, or SDK. Project Structure The CIM was developed using the Microsoft Visual C# 2017. It runs on both MS Windows 7 and Windows 10 platform and requires dot.Net 4.6 framework. Microsoft Access database engine was included during the installation to allow local storage of user lists and other settings. The figure below shows the final structure of the system. content: Explore the English language on a new scale using AI-powered English language navigator. Setting up Eclipse: Java's popular IDE Summary This tutorial will help you to install JDK (Java Development Kit), setup Eclipse IDE (Integrated development environment) and get started with Java. Keywords: IDE, Eclipse, JDK Downloads First of all you have to download some stuff from the Internet: 1. Download the latest JDK from: http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp 2. Download Eclipse IDE for Java Developers from: http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ Installation Run JDK installer and follow instructions. After you installed the JDK, unpack eclipse archive somewhere on a disk and run eclipse.exe. Get started with Eclipse Select a workspace If you did previous steps right, you should see the following: You are asked to select a workspace directory, where all of your further projects would be stored. You may leave the default folder or choose another one. It's important to remember this path for future. After you choose the workspace location, press ok and wait a little, while Eclipse is loading. Creating a project Choose File New Java Project from menu. In the "New Java Project" window type "HelloWorld" in the project name edit box. Then press Finish button. Click with the right button on the HelloWorld project in package explorer. Choose New Class: Name it "HelloWorld" and set checker box to create main method stub. Then press Finish button. Type: System.out.println("Hello World! I am new to Java."); in the main method's body and run HelloWorld with run button: You will see the result in a console window: Your first Java application is ready! We will discuss it in detail in the next article. title: 1515574050-FINAL_PN Staff Writing Hand Guide.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/1515574050-FINAL_PN Staff Writing Hand Guide.pdf
author: System
content: Staff Writing Hand Guide PHILIPPINE NAVY PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 2 Philippine Navy Staff Writing Hand Guide Copyright 2017 Office of the Chief of Naval Staff PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 3 Message The crafting of the PN Staff Writing Hand Guide supports the aim of the Philippine Navy to be a world-class navy that our maritime nation can be proud of. More than our thrusts for operational and strategic excellence, we also endeavor for a holistic advancement, which includes the quality of our naval documents. Through this hand guide, we take another step forward in terms of professionalizing our navy and its systems. We cultivate and further improve our written documents as a reflection of our excellence and professionalism. Just like our processes and strategies, our written documents must also be improved in a way that will make our jobs easier and our service better. With the few but important points presented in this hand guide, we must aim to take the standards of the navy writing to a higher level. Therefore, everyone is encouraged to follow the writing guidelines contained in this hand guide. FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila RONALD JOSEPH S MERCADO Vice Admiral, AFP PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 4 Message The Philippine Navy (PN) uses written communication in its official and daily correspondence, both within and outside our institution. We put everything in writing to have permanency of records and effective communication that leads to efficient operations. To achieve clear and concise naval documents, this PN Staff Writing Hand Guide prescribes the use of plain writing that will allow readers to easily comprehend what is written. It does not only supplement the PN Staff Writing Manual, but it also introduces resolutions to the common issues observed in the different written communication. With this hand guide, all officers, enlisted personnel and civilian emp

title: Comparison of Mobile Phones with regards to Privacy and Security.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Comparison of Mobile Phones with regards to Privacy and Security.docx
author: System
content: Comparison of Mobile Phones with regards to Privacy and Security Parameters Huawei Oppo Samsung Iphone Encryption File-based (AES 256 bit) File-based (AES 256 bit) File-based (AES 256 bit) Authentication Pin, Password, Pattern Pin, Password, Pattern Pin, Password, Pattern, Fingerprint and Iris Scanner Pin, Password, Pattern, Facial Recognition Privacy Protection (e.g. disable location) Yes Yes Yes Yes Security Patch Time-frame Monthly Scheduled Monthly, Quarterly, and Only when necessary Scheduled Password Protected Files SecureFolder Reputable Apps Store Less stringent review in Playstore More stringent review Operating System Open Source (Can be freely modified) Proprietary Hardware Advance RISC Machine Main Office Location China South Korea USA Embedded Spying Chips no substantial proof of espionage has ever been established Assessment: All mobile phones provide the necessary security features for data protection. However, Iphone is more advantage in having less reported malware due to its proprietary OS and a more stringent review of all applications in the App Store.

title: Brief Description of the General Function of.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Brief Description of the General Function of.docx
author: System
content: Brief Description of the General Function of Information Technology Officer (ITO) II: Formulate plans, policies, and manage IT infrastructure and cyber security controls; supervise the activities of subordinate analyst, researcher, programmer, and technologist in the conduct of systems development and maintenance of computers and IT networks. Specific Duties and Responsibilities: Develop, review, and update the PN cyber security and information system policies and procedures. Develop, review, and update the PN Information Systems Strategic Plan (ISSP). Oversees the activities of subordinate analyst, and programmers in the development of information systems. Oversees the activities of subordinate technologist in the conduct of preventive and corrective maintenance of computers and networks. Evaluate and facilitate the fund request of PN units pertaining to Information and Communication Technology hardware and software. Oversees the implementation of all funded ICT projects of the PN including cyber security controls, network infrastructure, and information systems. Provides technical advice to superior officers on matters pertaining to information technology and cyber security.

title: Conference-01Oct2019.docx
author: System
content: ICT Project Updates – 01 October 2019 Minutes of Conference Procurement Monitoring System CNICTC intends to launch the system prior the 2nd semester command conference. DN6 suggested: Include target date on every sub-phases. Re-audit (VAPT) on every modification of the system. Separate systems admin: System admin as owner and system admin as technical. Monitoring will be feed to the SOC. Audit log includes event about unauthorized access. Foresight the archiving of logs and database. Remove the project trail in the public viewing. Admin can only view all entries but does not have privilege to edit any entry. Simulation training of the system on 03 Oct 2019 DN6: Initial test with the end users prior command conference Issues on encoding previous and ongoing projects into the system will be resolved by N4 Red and Gray Network Current Setup CSG: Direct NICT stations to submit network diagram in Visio format to consolidated in order to come up a holistic network architecture of the PN NICTC to come up an enterprise AD architecture. Next week follow up. CONOPS for the Cyber Lab LCDR SORIANO seeks guidance from N2 regarding this matter. N6 and NICTC to craft the CONOPS DN6: in Coordination with N2 on the concept of the Cyber Lab. PKI No designated officer to implement the PKI. Communicate with the NICTC on the implementation of PKI ISSP CSG: Start planning cloud computing. Include in the planning the replete of all obsolete computers in the PN. Include Data Science and AI in the crafting of ISSP Other Matters: CSG: Filter all ICT related projects for tier2 The need to convene the C4ISR Board Look into the scheduling of C4ISR Family conference

author: System
content: Staff Writing Hand Guide PHILIPPINE NAVY PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 2 Philippine Navy Staff Writing Hand Guide Copyright 2017 Office of the Chief of Naval Staff PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 3 Message The crafting of the PN Staff Writing Hand Guide supports the aim of the Philippine Navy to be a world-class navy that our maritime nation can be proud of. More than our thrusts for operational and strategic excellence, we also endeavor for a holistic advancement, which includes the quality of our naval documents. Through this hand guide, we take another step forward in terms of professionalizing our navy and its systems. We cultivate and further improve our written documents as a reflection of our excellence and professionalism. Just like our processes and strategies, our written documents must also be improved in a way that will make our jobs easier and our service better. With the few but important points presented in this hand guide, we must aim to take the standards of the navy writing to a higher level. Therefore, everyone is encouraged to follow the writing guidelines contained in this hand guide. FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila RONALD JOSEPH S MERCADO Vice Admiral, AFP PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 4 Message The Philippine Navy (PN) uses written communication in its official and daily correspondence, both within and outside our institution. We put everything in writing to have permanency of records and effective communication that leads to efficient operations. To achieve clear and concise naval documents, this PN Staff Writing Hand Guide prescribes the use of plain writing that will allow readers to easily comprehend what is written. It does not only supplement the PN Staff Writing Manual, but it also introduces resolutions to the common issues observed in the different written communication. With this hand guide, all officers, enlisted personnel and civilian emp

title: Standard Data Center Construction.pdf
author: System
content: WHITE PAPER The Three Principles of Data Center Infrastructure Design The Three Principles of Data Center Infrastructure Design Understand These Three Principles and You'll: Lower your total cost of ownership Support your future growth plans Reduce your risk of downtime Maximize performance Improve your ability to reconfigure Your data center is the most critical resource within your organization. As you know, it provides the means for all storage, management and dissemination of data, applications and communications for your business. When employees and customers are unable to access the servers, storage systems and networking devices that reside in the data center, your entire organization can shut down. Millions of dollars can be lost in a matter of minutes for businesses like banks, airlines, shipping facilities and online brokerages. Faced with these consequences, IT executives today must optimize their data centers, particularly the network infrastructure. When you consider that 70 percent of network downtime can be attributed to physical layer problems, specifically cabling faults, it's paramount that more consideration be given to infrastructure design. Within this white paper we introduce three principles, that when executed properly, will help you gain significant benefits and savings throughout the life of your data center. Page The Three Principles of Data Center Design When you understand the three principles of data center design, you are able to: Lower your total cost of ownership Support your future growth plans Reduce your risk of downtime Maximize performance Improve your ability to reconfigure Principle 1: Space Savings Environmentally controlled real estate is expensive. The cost of building a data center is more than $1,000 per square foot in some cases (see Table 1). Data center racks and equipment can take up an enormous amount of real estate, and the future demand for more network connections, bandwidth and storage may require even more space

title: NRAN-8FL6LW_R0_EN.pdf
author: System
content: Calculating Space and Power Density Requirements for Data Centers Revision 0 by Neil Rasmussen White Paper 155 The historic method of specifying data center power density using a single number of watts per square foot (or watts per square meter) is an unfortunate practice that has caused needless confusion as well as waste of energy and money. This paper demonstrates how the typical methods used to select and specify power density are flawed, and provides an improved approach for establishing space requirements, including recom- mended density specifications for typical situations. Executive summary by Schneider Electric White Papers are now part of the Schneider Electric white paper library produced by Schneider Electric's Data Center Science Center DCSC@Schneider-Electric.com Calculating Space and Power Density Requirements for Data Centers Schneider Electric – Data Center Science Center Rev 0 2 Two key design parameters for a data center are the IT load rating in kW and the physical size of the IT and equipment rooms. In principle, these are related by the concept of power density, which vaguely relates the building size to the IT load. Historically, it has been common to describe and specify data centers with phrases like "2,000 square meters at 1,000 watts per square meter". Terminology like this results in needless confusion and ambiguity in the data center specification. Furthermore, this historic approach often results in underutilized power and cooling equipment, which leads to reduced electrical efficiency and excessive first-time costs. This paper describes an improved method for specifying power density. Furthermore, this paper makes specific recommendations for power density for new data centers, based on a few simple data center characteristics. There are four major problems with the historic practice of describing power density in terms of watts per square foot or watts per square meter. 1. What is included in the area calculation, or how it relates t

title: 0217 - AAR on OPLAW Cyberwarfare Seminar.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/AAR/0217 - AAR on OPLAW Cyberwarfare Seminar.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR WCEIS, N6 Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Branch Chief, Research and Doctrine To: AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Subj: Operational Law Alumni Forum (Cyberwarfare Seminar) Ref: NDCP Invitation Encl: 1) Programme of Activities 2) Certificate of Appearance 3) Pictures 4) Presentations on Hybrid Threats and its Implications 5) Cyberwarfare and International Law 6) Operational Law and the Threats of Cyberwarfare and Terrorism in the Philippines I. General: The National Defense College of the Philippines (NDCP), in cooperation with the Friedrich Ebert Stiftung (FES), conducted the Operational Law Alumni Forum featuring a seminar on "Cyberwarfare, the Law of Armed Conflict and Challenges of Future Warfare". The two-day activity was held from 17 to 18 February 2017 at Club Balai Isabel, Talisay, Batangas and was attended by OPLAW alumni from the defense department, AFP, government agencies and non-government agencies. The activity aimed to achieve the following: Collaborate with all the OPLAW alumni from the five classes Discuss cyberwarfare Discuss the operational law in cyberwarfare The alumni were transported from Discovery Hotel, Ortigas, Pasig City to the venue in Talisay, Batangas on 171330H February 2017. The alumni joined the graduation ceremony of Operational Law Course Class 5 on 171600H February 2017 followed by a dinner fellowship. The main activity started thru a formal opening ceremony on 180900H February 2017. BGEN ROLAND G JUNGCO AFP (Ret), the Executive Vice President of NDCP rendered a welcome remarks. The foreign counterpart, Dr. Johannes Kadura, resident representative of FES, also gave his welcome remarks. The highlight of the seminar are the topics delivered by prolific speakers namely CDR THOMAS BOEHLKE (Ret), a faculty from the German Armed Forces Command and Staff College who discussed Hybrid

General: The Microsoft Philippines, in cooperation with NTT Data (formerly Wizards Group), conducted Microsoft Official Course 20410D: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012. The course is a five (5) days activity whichwas held from 27February to 03March 2017 at NTT Data Phils. Training Center, Unit 2801, 88 Corporate Center, Sedeño corner Valero St, Salcedo VillageMakati City. The course was participated by the undersigned together with LT BERT Z. DOLOT PN and S2DP Rhea Mae E. Espinosa PN from Naval Information, Communications and Technology Center (NICTC). The course is composed of a classroom lectures and laboratory exercises from 9am to 5pm everyday led by a Microsoft Certified Trainer (MCT). Exercise guide materials and desktop computers with internet access were provided and configuredfor every students to access the Digital Microsoft Official Courseware.During the duration of the course, breakfast, light snacks and lunch were also provided. The Microsoft Official Course 20410D: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 is outlined to 13 modules as follows: Module 1: Deploying and Mapping Windows Server 2012 Module 2: Introduction to Active Directory Domain Services Module 3: Managing Active Directory Domain Services Objects Module 4: Automating Active Directory Domain Services Administration Module 5: Implementing IPv4 Module 6: Implementing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Module 7:

title: AAR on CyberCon.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR WCEIS, N6 Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Branch Chief, Cyber Warfare Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR, N6 Subj: AAR on Cyber Security Conference and Exhibition (Cybercon Asia 2017) Ref: Invitation from WorldTech Philippines Inc. Encl: 1) Agenda Details 2) Certificate of Attendance 3) Pictures I. General: CyberCon Asia is an annual cyber security conference and exhibitions that brings together asia's leading cyber experts to discuss various issues, trends, and threat landscape of the cyberspace. The PN was invited by Worldtech Philippines in this two (2) day seminar held at Grand Convention Center, Cebu City, Philippines; attended by LT RODEL G BARRACA PN and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. The event, aims to produce a consortium of cyber security professionals, IT practitioners, ethical hackers and IT product specialists from various industries, academe, corporate sectors, government, and non-government organizations to raise awareness about the state of cyber security in both domestic and international level. Specifically, the conference aims to achieve the following: Develop solidarity in protecting nations privacy; Raise awareness in cyber related threats. Discuss best practices and frameworks for cyber security. Share new techniques in exploiting software vulnerabilities in order to counter possible attack against our own information systems. The activity started with a speech from the PNP Chief of Public Information Office, PCSupt. Dionardo Bernardo Carlos followed by lecture on Data Privacy Act by the Deputy Privacy Commissioner of NPC, Mr. Damian O. Mapa; and the presentation of National Cybersecurity Plan 2022 by the DICT Region 7 Director, Mr. Antonio E. Padre. While some subsequent speakers grab the opportunity to discuss their product portfolio, others provide lectures on cyber security framework a

title: AAR Publication of Research .docx
author: System
content: HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: International Publication of Mr. Maligro's Research Paper Entitled Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging Ref: Letter invitation from the organizer of IRCCEEE Encl: Volume 9, No.1.2, 2020 of International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering I. General: The International Research Conference in Computing, Engineering, Education and Education Technology (IRCCEEE) is an International forum of academicians, professionals, researchers, and scientists with research involving engineering, education, and computing technology. This year the event was held at Legazpi City, Philippines. Mr. Maligro's research is fortunate to be chosen as one of the three (3) thesis and dissertations of Technological University of the Philippines (TUP) to be presented and showcased during this event. Due to conflict schedule, Mr Maligro was represented by his adviser Dr. Gemma Belga during this conference and successfully defended the research before the panel of experts and professors. The research entitled "Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging" is actually the enhancement of PNC2 Messenger - the messaging application widely used by the Philippine Navy - integrating AES 256 bit and Hidden in Plain Sight (HIPS) Encryption Algorithm (see enclosure). The research paper is initially accessible at http://www.warse.org/IJATCSE/static/pdf/file/ijatcse35912sl2020.pdf pending the indexing of Scopus Journal - the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature. . II. Timeline of Activities Leading to the Publication of Research: Date Activities November 2018 Final Oral Defense of Thesis at TUP with CPT JOHANNA V PORTILLO PN(M) as member of the Panel

title: Welcome Remarks.docx
author: System
content: Welcome Remarks It is my honour and my pleasure to welcome you to________________. Back sometime in May of 2013, the government websites of the Philippines are being taken down by "Taiwanese" keyboard warriors following the taiwanese fishermen incident, serving as payback. The Philippines is now taking a step towards safeguarding its digital network or the cyberspace. The digital world is becoming more and more vulnerable. As much as great inventions and technologies empower us, these pose real threats and can lead to unprecedented damage. Inadequate response to these incidents may result to national crisis. Statistics are truly alarming. Each minute somewhere around the world a cyberattack is being performed. Literally this very second, someone's computer is being hacked, someone's personal records, financial information, or intellectual property is being stolen and sold on the black market. The Philippine Military is no exception to this. Everyday your Philippine Navy experiences numerous cyber-attacks in an attempt to penetrate our network and some get through by means of inadvertent downloads and USB insertion. Criminals are stepping up their game and data breaches are increasingly common and devastating. That is why we need to act together – Government agencies, Private Sectors, NGO, Academe, and even households with internet connections. With that, Thank You at Mabuhay po tayong lahat!

title: ISSP Caption.docx
author: System
content: Information Systems Strategic Plan This ISSP is the PN's ICT implementing strategy to address the capability requirements for information assurance across all levels of command with particular focus on the following mission critical information system services: Naval Operation Reporting System (NORS) - A system that integrates and automates the reporting of individual status and operating condition of all deployed naval ships, aircraft and marine units to provide commanders with timely situational awareness and common operating picture for decision making. Maritime Situational Awareness IS (MSAIS) - A system that will collect information from airborne, ship-borne and land-based monitoring systems that will generate maritime picture and enable a nationwide maritime situational awareness. Voice Data and Video Communication System - A collection and integration of satellite, IP-VPN, telephone, and radio communication systems utilized in both Red and Gray networks. Integrated Personnel Management System (IPMS) - The system that establishes PN-wide integrated personnel records management in order to effect near real-time update on personnel status. It automates and improves human resource processes such as recruitment, maintenance of 201 files, attendance and leave monitoring and employee compensation and benefits. Property Accounting and Logistics Mgmt. System (PALMS) - A system consisting of several modular applications encompassing development of mainstream supply inventory, logistics, firearms records, and ships repair. PN Budget, Audit and Resources System (BARS) - A system that provides financial resource management and strategic budgetary planning. It will collect and analyze financial data, tracks resource utilization, and provides visualized management report.

Philippine Army Inclusion in the budget the PA WAN enhancement and HPA Wifi connectivity; The HPA Wifi Project will separate the internet from the PANET; and Establish closed PANET; . content: Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System(EPMIS) Armed Forces of the Philippines Procurement Service (AFFPS) Scope of Presentation Reference Background Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) System Features & Benefits Automated Processes Sample Prototype and generated report' Issues and Concerns Recommendations Reference FOIC, PN Command Guidance CY 2019 Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) of AFPPS Background In line with FOIC, PN Command Guidance CY 2019 to ensure check and balance as well as transparency in procurement processes of all projects is the adoption of a Procurement Monitoring System. Last 28 March 2019, Mr Bong Sapasap of Business Solutions and IT Services presented Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) that was previously used by AFP Procurement Service (AFPPS). Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) a web-based application developed to serve as the focal point for AFPPS, its Procurement Centers and Contracting Offices to process, manage, and monitor procurement services Features User Friendly Process Oriented/Driven Transaction transparency/traceability Compliant to standards/statutory and regulatory requirements Real time availability of data/reports to Catered Units, Suppliers and stakeholders Secured SECURED has the highest 'class' of available SSL, Extended Validation (EV) SSL, that secures websites SECURED Has a high-level 2048-bit encryption provided by COMODO SSL Certificate SECURED Has a grade of A and above in compliance with SSL/TLS Security Test BENEFITS Improved Quality, Governance and Reliability Barcodes in every forms. Security codes are imbedded in each form to ensure printed forms came out of the system. Ensuring authenticity of the documents. All forms are precise. title: Cyber IPB.docx
author: System
content: Scenario: The AFP opens a bid for its Internet and IP VPN connectivity as required by higher authorities; subsequently, MISIS-TEL Telephone Company, being the lowest bidder, won and was awarded the contract to provide the internet and IP VPN services for all AFP units including the PN. Some secured networks of the AFP, especially the VPN, are now passing through the MISIS-TEL routing nodes. Because of these, threat on cyber security is perceived to be eminent. Operational security is compromised and personal/ family safeties of AFP members are put to risk. Condition: The AFP secured network or the VPN is running through MISIS-TEL Telco. National ID System is contracted to a Chinese Firm Metro Manila CCTV project is contracted to a Chinese Firm Requirement (Action of the Attacker): Recon and scan the AFP network through the MISIS-TEL VPN control terminal. Chong Go is a penetration agent of CH government disguising an employee of MISIS-Tel Company. Chong is in charge of maintaining routers and network switches of IP VPN including the subnet of the AFP. He reckoned and gathered information about the AFP; and later learned the allocated IP address or network address of the AFP. Chong, being inside the IP VPN of all MISIS-TEL subscribers, scanned the network or subnet owned by the AFP using the NMAP. The NMAP is an effective tool for scanning and identifying all devices connected in the network. It generates a graphical layout of the entire network including basic information of the devices (e.g. OS version, ports opened) upon completion of the scan. The attacker now is able to map out the entire network of the AFP including all connected computers and servers. Intrude into J3 and N3 domains and terminals. Chong narrows down to J3 and N3 computer terminals using various info gathering tools such as nslookup, traceroute, and Sparta (banner grabber). The attacker selects a specific computer terminal from the shortlisted targets and conducts a Man-in the Middle (MITM) attac

title: scenario for cyber ipb.docx
author: System
content: SCENARIO 1: MISLATEL AS 3rd TELCO PLAYER RP has approved the MISLATEL as the provisional 3rd Telco to provide internet and IP VPN services in order to break the duopoly of PLDT and GLOBE Telecoms. Part of MISLATEL is China Telecoms, a state-sponsored corporation. MISLATEL offers the lowest bid in providing internet and IP VPN services to some government agencies, to include the Philippine Navy. At present, the current internet and IP VPN services provided by PLDT is less viable in terms of technological and financial concerns that led to the termination of contract of PLDT. title: LOI - CEBIS1-Edited 3.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T ED 6 of 6 PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 Subject: PN Letter of Instruction Nr _____ (Implementation of Civilian Employee Biometric Information System) To: (See Distribution) References: FOIC, PN approved DF, Subj: Repair and Enhancement of PN IPMS Database System TNIG DF to FOIC, Subj: Civilian Employee Biometric Information System SITUATION: The FOIC, PN has approved the adoption of the PN Civilian Employee Biometric System (CEBIS). This project is in accordance with the requirements of higher headquarters for the inclusion of a module in Integrated Personnel Management System (IPMS) that can provide a database of PN civilian employees for the purpose of personnel management. This is in line with the initiative of the Civil Service Commision (CSC) in development of Human Resource Information System (HRIS). The CEBIS module will generally automate and manage information on human resources, payroll, management, and accounting activities pertaining to the civilian personnel of the PN. Furthermore, this system will bring together sub-systems such as Personnel Information System (PIS), Biometrics Information System (BIS), and Payroll Information System (Payroll IS) for an easy and cost effective storage, integration, and retrieval of HR data of the PN civilian personnel. MISSION: To undertake necessary planning, preparation, and coordination, in order to ensure the successful implementation of PN Civilian Employee Biometric Information System (CEBIS). EXECUTION: Concept of Operation: The implementation will compose of the following activities broken down into phases: Phase 1 – Database Build-up of CEBIS Personnel Information System This phase covers the integration of the CEBIS database in the IPMS server. The following activities shall be conducted. Preparation of the CEBIS and IPMS for integration; Determination and creation of accounts for designate

author: System
content: General Function AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 The AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6, assists and advices the Flag Officer In Command, PN on matters pertaining to C4ISR Systems support for PN Command and Control (C2), maritime situational awareness, information assurance, cyberspace operations, and electronic warfare. Proposed Modifications and Justification for N6 Civilian Plantilla Staffing Proposed Staffing Modification Action Scrap and Build – creation of new units and/or positions corresponding to the equivalent cost of structures or staffing reduced or abolished (DBM National Budget Circular no. 485 dated March 13 2003) Reclassification of positions – may be applied only when there has ben a substantial change in the regular duties and responsibilities of the incumbent of the position and which may result in a change in any or all of the following: position title, level, and salary grade. (DBM National Circular no. 2005-5 stated August 16 2005) Retitling Proposed Positions for Scrap and Build ACTUAL PLANTILLA POSITIONS (TO SCRAP) PROPOSED NEW POSITIONS (TO BUILD) Job Title SG Annual Salary Job Title SG Annual Salary Computer Maintenance Technologist II (1) SG – 11 242,148.00 Information technology Officer II (1) SG-20 564,444.00 Administrative Officer IV (1) SG 15 348,120.00 Computer Programmer I SG-15 348,120.00 TOTAL 3 590,268.00 TOTAL 2 912,564.00 JUSTIFICATION: The proposed positions recommended to be scrapped are vacant. The re-organization of ON6 which created new branches entailed the need to create additional civilian positions that are needed to perform tasks in lieu of the functions of the respective branch which these positions will be assigned. Further, the scrap and build proposal will incur an excess variance of 322, 296 on personnel services cost. title: CYBER IPB rev 2.pptx
author: System
content: Cyber IPB – Possible Scenario Scenario CONDITION REQUIREMENT (Possible Action of the Attacker) SCOPE Scenario The AFP opens a bid for its Internet and IP VPN connectivity as required by higher authorities; Subsequently, MISLATEL Telephone Company, being the lowest bidder, won and was awarded the contract to provide Internet and IP VPN services for all AFP units including the PN. Operational security is compromised and personal/ family safeties of AFP members are put to risk with the AFP VPN services being provided by MISLATEL. Condition The AFP secured network or the VPN is running through MISLATEL Telco. National ID System is contracted to a Chinese Firm Metro Manila CCTV project is contracted to a Chinese Firm Requirement (Actions of the Hacker) 1. Recon and scan the AFP network through the MISLATEL VPN terminal. Xi Maa is a hacker and an agent of CH government disguising an employee of MISLATEL Company. Xi is in charge of maintaining routers and network switches of IP VPN including the subnet of the AFP. He reckoned and gathered information about the AFP; and later learned the allocated IP address or network address of the AFP. Requirement (Actions of the Hacker) 1. Recon and scan the AFP network through the MISLATEL VPN terminal. Xi, being inside the IP VPN of all MISLATEL subscribers, scanned the network or subnet owned by the AFP using the NMAP. The NMAP is an effective tool for scanning and identifying all devices connected in the network. It generates a graphical layout of the entire network including basic information of the devices (e.g. OS version, ports opened) upon completion of the scan. The attacker now is able to map out the entire network of the AFP including all connected computers and servers. Requirement (Actions of the Hacker) Intrude into J3 and N3 domains and terminals. Xi narrows down to J3 and N3 computer terminals using various info gathering tools such as nslookup, traceroute, and Sparta (banner grabber). The attacker selects a specific co

Part of MISLATEL is China Telecoms, a state-sponsored corporation. By 2020, the PN open the bidding to the 3 Telco and subsequently, MISLATEL was awarded the contract to provide the internet and IP VPN services. Some secured networks of the PN, especially the VPN, are passing through the MISLATEL routing nodes that uses China software. Because of these, threat on cyber security is perceived to be eminent. POSSIBLE SCENARIO SCENARIO2: AFP CYBER SECURITY BREACH USING THE HUAWEI TECH Currently, the PN IP VPN and internet services is using the PLDT infrastructure. However, it is using the Huawei Technology for its core infrastructure. It is a fact that Huawei Technology possibly transmits data to China because of their state policy (national intelligence law), thus, exposing any confidential information that passes thru the said infrastructure. With this contentions, the PN is facing the challenges on information security breach. title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0b.xlsx
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_JOEY_v2.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_DALIOAN.xlsx
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_MS.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: NICTC Ltr- Acter Activity REport on Implementation of PN CEBIS.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CEBIS/NICTC Ltr- Acter Activity REport on Implementation of PN CEBIS.pdf
author: System
content: PHILIPPINE NAVY  NAVAL INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGY CENTER  A Naval Base Heracleo Alano Sangley Point, Cavite City 28 NOV 2Ul8 From: Commander, Naval Information and Communication Technology Center To: Flag Officer In Command, Philippine Navy (Attn: AC of NS for C4ISR System, N6) Subj: After Activity Report on Implementation of PN CEBIS (Phase 1) Ref: HPN LOI Nr 042-18 re same subject Encl: Same as Subject 1. Above reference pertains to the project of Higher Headquarters for the inclusion of a module in Integrated Personnel Management System (IPMS) that can provide a database of PN civilian employees for the purpose of personnel management. 2. In relation, this Center designated a Project Management Team (PMT) headed by CDR SALVADOR M SAMBALILO PN (GSC) and Technical Working Group (TWG) headed by ENS ALHISHAM D JULWADI PN as Project Officer for the said project per SO NR 89 HNICTC dated 07 November 2018. 3. In this regard, fonivarded is the After-activity Report of this Center regarding the implementation of PN Civilian Employee Biometric Information System (CEBIS) phase 1. Wherein in this phase, the Center already conducted information and dissemination to PN civilian personnel to all PN units through Video Teleconferencing System last 06 November 2018. 4. The phase 2 and 3 will be funded under 2019 SPA through bidding that is expected to execute on the 3'“ Quarter of same year. 5. For information and reference. _ ﬁ__ _ __ I IMPERIO CAPT PN(GSC)

title: CRA Checklist.docx
author: System
content: CRA Checklist (for PN Only) Critical Security Controls Policies Tools Reports CSC 4 – Vulnerability Mgmt Utilize VA tools Policy on regular conduct of VA VA VA reports Compare VA results and prioritize remediation Software Update and Patch Mgmt System Policy on Patch Management WSUS or Patch Mgmt System Reports on Software security updates CSC 8 – Data Recovery Ensure all system data are automatically and regularly backup Policy on Data Backup and Recovery Backup and Recovery Software Reports on conducted backup Backup as complete system (imaging) Cloning or imaging software CSC 14 – Monitoring and Audit of Logs Enable Logging and NTP Policy on Logs and Network Monitoring NTP server and check logs Reports on Network Monitoring as generated by the SIEM or IDS Review of Logs to identify anomalies IDS or any Network Monitoring Log collection and Deployment of SIEM SIEM CSC 18 – Incident Response and Mgmt Ensure incident response plan CERT Policy AAR on cyber incidents Devise a mechanism for the reporting of any anomalies Policy pertaining to reporting of anomalies Trouble Ticketing System or Hotline Nr Reports from the end users Plan and conduct routine incident response exercises Documents on CSIRT exercises AAR on CSIRT exercises CSC 20 – Penetration Testing Conduct regular penetration tests on information systems Documents showing conduct of Penetration Testing AAR on the conduct of Pen Test Perform periodic Red Team exercises to test organizational readiness. Documents showing plans and programs for the conduct of Cyber Defense Exercise AAR on the conduct of Red Team Exercise

title: Annex B CRA Parameters.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/AFP CRA/Annex B CRA Parameters.docx
author: System
content: ANNEX "B" to SOP Nr ____AFP Dated__________ Cybersecurity Risk Assessment (CRA) Template CRA Parameters Description Available Capability Gap Recommendation Inventory of Authorized and Unauthorized Devices Reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems: Use active monitoring and configuration management to maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. No inventory of authorized and unauthorized devices Program for Asset Management System such as MS Active Directory Inventory of Authorized and Unauthorized Software Identify vulnerable or malicious software to mitigate or root out attacks: Devise a list of authorized software for each type of system, and deploy tools to track software installed (including type, version, and patches) and monitor for unauthorized or unnecessary software. Secure Configurations for Hardware and Software on Mobile Devices, Laptop, Workstations, and Servers Prevent attackers from exploiting services and settings that allow easy access through networks and browsers: Build a secure image that is used for all new systems deployed to the enterprises, host these standard images on secure storage servers, regularly validate and update these configurations, and track system images in a configuration management system. Continuous Vulnerability Assessment and Remediation Proactively identify and repair software vulnerabilities reported by security researchers or vendors: Regularly run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems and quickly remediate any vulnerabilities, which critical problems fixed within 48 hours. Malware Defenses Block malicious code from tampering with system settings or contents, capturing sensitive data, or spreading: Use automated anti-virus and anti-spyware to continuously monitor and protect workstations, servers, and mobile devices. Automatically update such anti-malware

title: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/CRA_OJ6/CRA-PRESENTATION CONSOLIDATION/ISG-CEIS/AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
author: System
content: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) 04 – 08 March 2019 CRA Parameters Capability Gap Recommendation Continuous Vulnerability Management Utilize an up-to-date SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool to automatically scan all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis to identify all potential vulnerabilities on the organization's systems. Lack of SCAP-compliant vulnerability assessment or scanning tool to scan all systems and network. Run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis; inform system administrators of most critical vulnerabilities Implement and enforce SCAP Based Vulnerability Management System Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning with agents running locally on each system or with remote scanners that are configured with elevated rights on the system being tested. No authenticated credential authentication for vulnerability assessment. Perform vulnerability scanning on each end system in authenticated mode with agents or remote scanners Tenable can provide authenticated vulnerability scanning on all networked end systems using software agents or remote scanners. Use a dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability scans, which should not be used for any other administrative activities and should be tied to specific machines at specific IP addresses. No dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability assessment. Monitor logs associated with any scanning activity and associated administrator accounts to ensure legitimate scans Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that the operating systems are running the most recent security updates provided by the software vendor. No centralized update deployment service and/or patch management system tools. Deploy automated patch management tools and software update tools for OS and software; apply patches to all systems Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that third-party software on al

title: N6B Comments.docx
author: System
content: N6B Comments Five years from now this SOP will still be in effect but the hardware and software requirements will already be obsolete. Consider a general but forward-looking statement – "DRMS specialists shall be provided with computers (hardware, software) with specifications that will enable them faster encoding and mobility for the performance of their job" All servers shall be housed and maintained in the NICTC Data Center In Security, consider - "Laptop computers dedicated for DRMS shall be installed with Virtual Private Network (VPN) and appropriate security features needed for mobility. This VPN shall be used prior transmission (e.g. email) of any documents. " In Conduct and Usage, consider – "Desktop and Laptop computers are provided solely for DRMS usage. Users shall not download or install any software without the approval of NICTC; likewise it should not be utilized for any purposes other than DRMS functions. title: Config Mgmt_ver 1.docx
author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER………………………………… PN INFOSTRUCTURE CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES 1. PURPOSE: The purpose of this SOP is to provide guidance to Philippine Navy units/offices to ensure compliances with minimally acceptable system configuration requirements as determined by the organization within the information security standards and best practices. Furthermore, this SOP shall provide guidance to PN units/offices to develop fixed reference in the development cycle or an agreed-upon specification of information systems. PN shall develop baseline configuration that shall serve as a documented basis for defining incremental change and encompasses many different aspects of the information systems. The baseline configuration shall be the center of the effective configuration management program whose purpose is to give definite basis for change control in a project by controlling various configuration items like work, features, system performance and other measurable configuration, which is basically defined specification that is considered the baseline for all changes that follow. In addition, this SOP is important process for establishing and maintaining secure information system configurations and provides important support for managing security risks in information systems. This SOP supports the policy and guidelines of the PN Cybersecurity Policy and adopted the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems–Requirements. 2. SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY: This SOP applies to all personnel and third party stakeholders, who provide, administer, maintain, and operate PN information system services

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_JOEY_v2.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: MFR-Conceptus.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPNAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 01 December 2017 MEMORANDUM for- AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: After conference report on the IELTA Conceptus System The Chief of Cyber Warfare Branch, ON6 together with CDR SALVADOR SAMBALILO PN, LCDR JAMES MINGUILLAN PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro attended the product presentation of IELTA on 211300H November 2017 at the Manila Peninsula Hotel, Makati City. The proponent presented the Conceptus System, a social media and web intelligence platform. The following are salient features of the system: Passive intelligence collection from social media and the web through creation of a seemingly legit social media personality (Avatar) that will blend in with the group or person of interest (POI); Crawls social media, deep web, darknet and bitcoin websites to collect valuable intelligence information about the POI; Generates actionable recommendation to grow and improve the avatar's reputation; and Correlates information from bitcoin transactions to provide further insights into the identity of the POI. While similar products, like the Knowlesys, have already been introduced to the PN, this branch is unable to determine the value and cost-benefit analysis of the system since this is a tool for Intelligence gathering. As such, we shall forward its brochure and other pertinent information to the TIG, NISF for their evaluation. For information of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems. RODEL G BARRACA LT PN Chief, Cyber Warfare Branch 3-Encls: Conference Notice Attendance Brochure

title: Eclipse IDE.pdf
author: System
content: Explore the English language on a new scale using AI-powered English language navigator. Setting up Eclipse: Java's popular IDE Summary This tutorial will help you to install JDK (Java Development Kit), setup Eclipse IDE (Integrated development environment) and get started with Java. Keywords: IDE, Eclipse, JDK Downloads First of all you have to download some stuff from the Internet: 1. Download the latest JDK from: http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp 2. Download Eclipse IDE for Java Developers from: http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ Installation Run JDK installer and follow instructions. After you installed the JDK, unpack eclipse archive somewhere on a disk and run eclipse.exe. Get started with Eclipse Select a workspace If you did previous steps right, you should see the following: You are asked to select a workspace directory, where all of your further projects would be stored. You may leave the default folder or choose another one. It's important to remember this path for future. After you choose the workspace location, press ok and wait a little, while Eclipse is loading. Creating a project Choose File New Java Project from menu. In the "New Java Project" window type "HelloWorld" in the project name edit box. Then press Finish button. Click with the right button on the HelloWorld project in package explorer. Choose New Class: Name it "HelloWorld" and set checker box to create main method stub. Then press Finish button. Type: System.out.println("Hello World! I am new to Java."); in the main method's body and run HelloWorld with run button: You will see the result in a console window: Your first Java application is ready! title: readme.txt
author: System
content: LastActivityView v1.32 Copyright (c) 2012 - 2018 Nir Sofer Web site: http://www.nirsoft.net Description =========== LastActivityView is a tool for Windows operating system that collects information from various sources on a running system, and displays a log of actions made by the user and events occurred on this computer. The activity displayed by LastActivityView includes: Running .exe file, Opening open/save dialog-box, Opening file/folder from Explorer or other software, software installation, system shutdown/start, application or system crash, network connection/disconnection and more... You can easily export this information into csv/tab-delimited/xml/html file or copy it to the clipboard and then paste into Excel or other software. System Requirements =================== This utility works on any version of Windows, starting from Windows 2000 and up to Windows 10. Both 32-bit and 64-bit systems are supported. Known Limitations ================= This tool gathers information from various sources, including the Registry, the events log of Windows, the Prefetch folder of Windows (C:\windows\Prefetch), the MiniDump folder of Windows (C:\Windows\Minidump), and more... The accuracy and the availability of the information displayed by LastActivityView might be different from one system to another. For example, if the user or a software makes changes in the Registry, the action time displayed by LastActivityView might be wrong, because it's based on the modified time of some Registry keys. Also, for every type of action/event, there is some limitation according to the way that the information is saved in the system. For example, the 'Select file in open/save dialog-box' action is limited for one action of every file extension, so if the user opened 2 .doc files with the open/save dialog-box, only the last one will be displayed.
