content: pfSense Tutorial BSDCan 2008 From zero to hero with pfSense May 13, 2008 Chris Buechler <cmb@bsdperimeter.com> Scott Ullrich <sullrich@bsdperimeter.com> History of pfSense Started as a work project 13 years ago when we needed a internal firewall Originally Linux, switched to FreeBSD 2.2 Evolution of this path shrunk the firewall down to a Soekris size Moatware was started Met Chris Buechler during this time Sell a number of products Sales guy moves to Florida Moatware fails Chris and myself debate starting over fresh pfSense is forked from m0n0wall roughly 4 years ago Still going strong today pfSense Overview Customized FreeBSD distribution tailored for use as a firewall and router. pfSense has many base features and can be extended with the package system including one touch installations of popular 3rd party packages such as SpamD (spam filter) and Squid (web caching). Includes many features found in commercial products such as Cisco PIX, Sonicwall, Watchguard, etc. Many support avenues available, mailing lists, forum and commercial support. Has the best price on the planet.... Free! pfSense Platforms Live CD Full Install Embedded Developers pfSense Stable Versions 1.0 - October 4, 2006 * 1.0.1 - October 20, 2006 * 1.2 - RELENG_1_2 - February 25, 2008 Downloaded more than 500,000 times to date * Not branched in CVS pfSense Development Versions Current Development Versions 1.3-ALPHA - RELENG_1 2.0-ALPHA-ALPHA-ALPHA - HEAD Snapshots are built every two hours available at http://snapshots.pfsense.org Bonus for attendees - 1.3 snapshots available Minimum Hardware Requirements CPU - 100 MHz (500+ MHz for best experience) RAM - 128 MB (256 MB or more is encouraged) Platform Specific Live CD CD-ROM drive (currently USB CD-ROM devices are not supported) USB flash drive or floppy drive to store configuration Full Installation CD-ROM for initial installation 1 GB hard drive Embedded 128 MB CF serial port for console null modem cable Popular hardware NICs - Intel Pro/100 and

title: AuditScripts.xlsx
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Config Mgmt/Config Management Policy/CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY.docx
author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER………………………………… PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION SYSTEMS CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES 1. PURPOSE: The purpose of this SOP is to provide guidance to Philippine Navy units/offices to ensure compliances with minimally acceptable system configuration requirements as determined by the organization within the information security standards and best practices. Furthermore, this SOP shall provide guidance to PN units/offices to develop fixed reference in the development cycle or an agreed-upon specification of information systems. PN shall develop baseline configuration that shall serve as a documented basis for defining incremental change and encompasses many different aspects of the information systems. The baseline configuration shall be the center of the effective configuration management program whose purpose is to give definite basis for change control in a project by controlling various configuration items like work, features, system performance and other measurable configuration, which is basically defined specification that is considered the baseline for all changes that follow. In addition, this SOP is important process for establishing and maintaining secure information system configurations and provides important support for managing security risks in information systems. This SOP supports the policy and guidelines of the PN Cybersecurity Policy and adopted the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems–Requirements. 2. SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY: This SOP applies to: All personnel who administer, maintain, and operate PN information system services and components. A

title: LCDR JONATAS PN Assignment for Forensics.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/LCDR JONATAS PN Assignment for Forensics.pdf
author: System
content: CASE STUDY IN FORENSIC INVESTIGATION SUBMITTED BY: LCDR JOSEPH L JONATAS PN BCWOC 02-2018 Executive Summary CE Jack Daniels, who works in National Research and Technology Development Center is suspected of accessing and possessing digital content pertaining to frogs. Accessing, possessing, and distribution of digital content pertaining to frogs breaches both civil and criminal laws. Jack has also been accused by NRTDC of obtaining two highly confidential documents. One document encompasses the names, position, usernames and password of notable personnel within the company. The second company is a top secret technology invention report wherein Jack should not have had access to either of these documents. As a consultant who specialized in Digital Forensics investigation, I am tasked to examine an image of Jack's laptop which was seized with the appropriate warrants. An image of the hard disk was created using forensically sound practices. Only a logical acquisition was undertaken by the individual responsible for creating the forensic copy. The logical acquisition was undertaken in a forensically sound manner and the md5 value at the same time of acquisition was "a72a04e309dc8aa20345db1e2ba4cd61". To start the investigation, the examiner Samsung Ativ 7 Core i5 laptop to investigate the downloaded image of Jack Daniels hard disk through the use of the following applications; OSMount, OSForensics, Autopsy, Passware Password Recovery Kit Forensic and Truecrypt. With the use of OSForensics and Autopsy Tools, the examiner investigate, exploit and explore the recent activity made by Jack Daniel to the computer. Manually browsing and/or auto search was also conducted using both software to search any suspicious file specifically frogs that has been accessed by Jack Daniel to his laptop. After thorough search and analyzation, fifteen (15) frogs were located to different folder locations. Said files extensions were change intentionally by Jack Daniel to avoid easy detection a

title: v2_CEIS Directive-AFP CRA_v3.docx
author: System
content: AFP Vision 2028: A World-class Armed Forces, Source of National Pride GENERAL HEADQUARTERS ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff for Communications, Electronics and Information Systems, J6 Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City OTAG/OJ6 STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER ________ AFP CYBER RISK ASSESSMENT REFERENCES: AFP Cyber Strategy; 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Secuirty (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the AFP cyber defense capability, there is a need to determine first the current AFP cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among AFP units. However, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should, therefore, be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats.The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to ensure cybersecurity AFP-wide. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all AFP Staff Officer for CEIS and AFP CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: a. Cyber – is a prefix for a term or the modifier of a compound word, rather than a stand-alone word which usually relates to electronic data processing, information technology, electronic communications or information and computer sys

title: Annex A CRA Process.doc
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/AFP CRA/Annex A CRA Process.doc
author: System
content: ANNEX A to SOP Nr. _______ AFP dated ________ CRA PROCESS PHASES/STEPS Ucs/AFPWSSUs/JPS CEISSAFP MAJOR SERVICES AFPCyG I. Iinitial Assessment         A. Planning         Determine and define the system and procedures for evaluation. Identify and classify critical cyber assets. Determine Teams to conduct the Evaluation      B. Conduct         Perform cyber risk assessment. Assess risks to system information and assets. Select evident security controls. Monitor and assess the effectiveness of controls.     C. Report Generation         Generate comprehensive report on risk assessment and recommendation       D. Submission         Submit report for consolidation       II. Consolidation         Consolidate the submitted report from CEISSAFP and Major Services respective Cyber 6s      III. Overall Assessment         Define the Major Services, Program IV and entire AFP cybersecurity posture respectively      Provide support for active executive sponsorship and adequate resources / funding for the cyber security program.  IV. Programming         Define the program/procurement priorities in cyber related projects        V. Implementation         Realization of cyber related programs and projects to improved the cybersecurity posture of the AFP     

GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the PN cyber defense capability, there is a need to first determine the current PN cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among PN units. Thus, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats. The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to provide adequate cybersecurity controls for the PN. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. title: Configuraton Mgmt 09Oct2018.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D R E S T R I C T E D (Page 6 of 19) PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION SYSTEM CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN information systems (IS) and its components. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure IS for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN information systems and its components. PN IS includes but not limited to application software, operating system, and software-enabled C2 systems and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. Configuration Change Control - The systematic proposal, justificatio

title: Annexes-16 Aug 2019.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Config Mgmt/Config Management Policy/Annexes-16 Aug 2019.docx
author: System
content: Annex A of Circ Nr ______ HPN dtd _____________ cont''n: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES The PN shall develop, document, and implement the baseline configuration of PN C4ISR Systems in order to maintain security and resiliency of PN Infostructure. Baseline Configuration The NICTC shall review and recommend the baseline configuration and major configuration changes to the C4ISR Board; All baseline configurations shall be issued in the form of CEIS directive approved by FOIC, PN; The NICTC shall be the overall administrator of PN C4ISR Systems and shall implement the following to ensure baseline configurations and standards; Develop, document, and maintain under configuration control, a baseline configuration of the C4ISR systems; Regularly review and update the baseline configuration according to the following frequency and circumstances: Every six (6) months; When required due to implementation of system updates, new standards, change/update in topology/architecture, or as directed by Higher Headquarters; and, When C4ISR systems are installed or upgraded; Employ automated mechanisms to maintain an up-to-date, complete, accurate, and readily available baseline configuration of the systems; Retain previous versions of baseline configurations of the C4ISR system to support rollback; Maintain a baseline configuration for systems development and test environments that is managed separately from the operational baseline configuration; Provide C4ISR systems with secured configurations to individuals traveling to locations that the organization deems to be of significant risk; and Configuration Change Control The Configuration Change Controls (CCC) for PN C4ISR systems involve the systematic proposal, justification, implementation, testing, review, and disposition of changes to the systems, including system upgrades and modifications. title: 05-2011.pdf
author: System
content: RESOLUTION NO. 05-2011 _______________________________________________________________________________________________________ APPROVING THE PRE-SELECTION PROCEDURE IN THE CONDUCT OF LIMITED SOURCE BIDDING UNDER SECTION 49 OF REPUBLIC ACT 9184 AND ITS REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS Section 48 of Republic Act 9184 (RA 9184) provides that Limited Source Bidding, otherwise known as Selective Source Bidding, is a method of procurement that involves direct invitation to bid by the procuring entity from a set of pre-selected suppliers or consultants with known experience and proven capability relative to the requirements of a particular contract. Under Section 49 of RA 9184 and its revised Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR), it may be employed under any of the following conditions: (1) procurement of highly specialized types of goods (e.g., sophisticated defense equipment, complex air navigation systems, coal) and consulting services where only a few suppliers or consultants are known to be available, such that resorting to the public bidding method will not likely result in any additional suppliers or consultants participating in the bidding; or (2) procurement of major plant components where it is deemed advantageous to limit the bidding to known qualified bidders in order to maintain uniform quality and performance of the plant as a whole. Section 49.2 of the IRR of RA 9184 provides that the pre-selected suppliers or consultants shall be those appearing in a list maintained by the relevant government authority that has expertise in the type of procurement concerned. The list of pre-selected suppliers or consultants shall be updated periodically. A copy of the list shall be submitted to, and maintained updated with, the Government Procurement Policy Board (GPPB). In addition, the IRR under Section 49.3 thereof, prescribes that pre-selection shall be based upon the capability and resources of the bidders to perform the contract taking into account their

title: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY-Circular V 14-05-18.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Config Mgmt/CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY-Circular V 14-05-18.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D R E S T R I C T E D (Page 6 of 19) PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION SYSTEM CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN information systems (IS) and its components. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure IS for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN information systems and its components. PN IS includes but not limited to application software, operating system, and software-enabled C2 systems and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. Maintaining baseline configurations requires creating new baselines

title: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY-Circular.docx

author: System
content: RESTRICTED PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION SYSTEMS CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide guidance to Philippine Navy units, offices and personnel to ensure compliance with the Circular Nr 29 dated 27 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy, and as determined by the organization within the information security standards and best practices. Furthermore, this policy shall provide guidance to PN units/offices to develop fixed reference in the development cycle or an agreed-upon specification of information systems. PN shall develop baseline configuration that shall serve as a documented basis for defining incremental change and encompasses many different aspects of the information systems. The baseline configuration shall be the center of the effective configuration management program whose purpose is to give definite basis for change control in a project by controlling various configuration items like work, features, system performance and other measurable configuration, which is basically defined specification that is considered the baseline for all changes that follow. In addition, this policy is important process for establishing and maintaining secure information system configurations and provides important support for managing security risks in information systems. This policy supports the PN Cybersecurity Policy and adopted the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems–Requirements. title: CYBER WARFARE COURSE - Seatworks.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/CYBER WARFARE COURSE - Seatworks.docx
author: System
content: CYBER WARFARE COURSE – FIREWALL/IDS/SIEM Those who are absent for more than 6 meetings are required to submit all seat works from day 1 to day 12 Non-submission of seat works will mean INCOMPLETE for the course. Email your completed seat works to : csg.nictc@navy.mil.ph Cc: maligro.nelson7129ce@navy.mil.ph SEAT WORKS: Design a network diagram that exhibits preventative and detective security controls (use Microsoft Visio). Explain the following excerpt from best cybersecurity practices: "You cannot protect what you cannot see" Setup an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) – Security Onion Deliverables: Screenshot of Security Onion with your full name on it. Simulate the IDS ability to detect network probes or attacks using the NMAP/Zenmap. Deliverables: Screenshot of SGUIL that displays continues alerts triggered from the NMAP/Zenmap scan. Setup a firewall – PFSense Deliverables: Screenshot of PFSense FW with your name on it. Configure your FW to adopt the best FW practice - Block All and Permit Only Needed Services/protocols. Deliverables: Screenshot of PFSense showing the following egress filtering rules: Block all services/protocols. Allow only HTTP, HTTPS, DNS, and ICMP protocol.

title: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/CRA_OJ6/P3BD_10.1.6.153/CRA-PRESENTATION CONSOLIDATION/ISG-CEIS/AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
author: System
content: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) 04 – 08 March 2019 CRA Parameters Capability Gap Recommendation Continuous Vulnerability Management Utilize an up-to-date SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool to automatically scan all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis to identify all potential vulnerabilities on the organization's systems. Lack of SCAP-compliant vulnerability assessment or scanning tool to scan all systems and network. Run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis; inform system administrators of most critical vulnerabilities Implement and enforce SCAP Based Vulnerability Management System Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning with agents running locally on each system or with remote scanners that are configured with elevated rights on the system being tested. No authenticated credential authentication for vulnerability assessment. Perform vulnerability scanning on each end system in authenticated mode with agents or remote scanners Tenable can provide authenticated vulnerability scanning on all networked end systems using software agents or remote scanners. Use a dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability scans, which should not be used for any other administrative activities and should be tied to specific machines at specific IP addresses. No dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability assessment. Monitor logs associated with any scanning activity and associated administrator accounts to ensure legitimate scans Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that the operating systems are running the most recent security updates provided by the software vendor. No centralized update deployment service and/or patch management system tools. Deploy automated patch management tools and software update tools for OS and software; apply patches to all systems Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that third-party software on al

content: "The NAVY: Protecting the Seas, Securing our Future" DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (If any) File Number: N6B-0219- Subject: Availability of Funds to Support the Maintenance of Software Licenses TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS Date: Comment No:___ VIA: VCOM, PN LCDR BARRACA PN-6390 _________ N6 _________ ________DONFM_______ SUMMARY: Reference: CNICTC Letter to FOIC, PN (Attn: N6), Subject: Availability of Funds for the Procurement of Hardware and Software Requirements of the PN Units, Request for Updates on the Implementation of Software Licenses Conference Notice dated 27 Feb 2018 , Agenda: Procurement of Hardware and Software Above reference 1a pertains to the request of CNICTC for the procurement of computer hardware and software licenses in order to address the issue of unlicensed software as a result and findings of the Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing (VAPT) of the twenty two (22) PN units conducted during the AGI. Based on the assessment of the actual inventory and specifications of these computers, several desktops and laptops are obsolete and can no longer support the installation of the latest software specifically the Microsoft Windows 10 Pro operating system. Hence, the NICTC recommends the procurement of software licenses only to computers that meets the minimum requirements for Windows 10 and further recommends the replacement of the obsolete computers with desktops and laptops bundled with Windows 10 pro. Relatedly, the NICTC facilitated the procurement and installation of software licenses for some PN units through the previous fund releases (ref 1b). After assessment on the actual inventory of the remaining unlicensed computers (windows 10 compatible), the NICTC identifies the total number of required software licenses for the twenty two (22) PN units. Moreover, It was discussed during the conference (ref 1b) that only the software requirements shall be requested from the 2018 residual fund while the hardware shall be programmed f

content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ INVENTORY AND CONTROL OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems, there is a need to use active monitoring, manage configuration and maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution. Maintaining inventories for hardware and software will identify vulnerable systems, detect malicious software, mitigate unpatched software, and root out attacks. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units for the inventory of Information Technology (IT) hardware and software SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cyber – is a prefix for a term or the modifier of a compound word, rather than a stand-alone word which usually relates to electronic data processing, information technology, electronic communications or information and compu

content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ ACCOUNTS AND PRIVILEGES MANAGEMENT REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to establish a standard for the administration of user accounts that facilitate access PN information systems. An account, at minimum, consists of a user ID and a password; supplying account information will usually grant access to some set of services and resources. This policy establishes standards for issuing accounts, creating password values, and managing accounts. SCOPE: This SOP is applicable to units 6's and CEIS units for the management of user accounts or access to shared information or network devices. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cybersecurity -deliberate synergy of technologies, processes, and practices to protect information and the networks, computer systems and appliances, and programs used to collect, process, store, and transport that information from attack, damage and unauthorized access. Cybersecurity Posture – refers to the overall cybersecurity strength of an PN. It expresses the relative security of the IT estate and its vulnerability to outside threats. Risk Assessment – is a process of identifying, estimating, and prioritizing risks of PNal assets and operations. It involves evaluating hazards, and developing plans to remove or minimize the level of ris

title: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY-Edited-16Jan2019.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R Philippine Navy Command and Control, Computers, Communication, and Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) Systems Configuration Management Policy PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN C4ISR Systems. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure C4ISR Systems for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN C4ISR Systems. C4ISR Systems include but not limited to software/applications, operating system, Cybersecurity systems, and software-enabled C3 system and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. C4ISR Systems – pertain

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 5 -Internet Safety.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 5 -Internet Safety.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 0 Six (6) Tips For a Safer Internet Experience Source: Google.com Google offered six (6) tips for the billions of people who use the Internet to make their online presence safe from hacking and fraud. By strengthening their online defenses, internet users can be sure that their online information is secured. In the Philippine Navy, we may consider these useful tips from the Google for us and our family to be secured in using the Internet. Following are six (6) ways to a safer online experience: 1. Keep software up to date across devices, including mobile and desktop; 2. Use a unique password for every account. Think of it as having a different key to your front door, office and car. Passwords should be at least 8 characters long with numbers and special characters. Consider using a password manager; 3. Take the Security Checkup on your email account to spot possible unauthorized log-ins and access to your data; 4. Add a recovery phone number or email address to help you regain access to your account in case you can't sign in and keep these details updated. Some services use the recovery email to alert users on suspicious activity such as unauthorized logins; 5. Use 2-Step Verification to add another layer of security before accessing your account. This could come in the form of a code that is sent to a trusted device or a physical security key; and 6. For parents, teach your children about Internet safety. Google's Family Link allows users to manage their children's account settings and block certain apps and websites. ERIC E NICANOR COL PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 -FormJacking.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 06 Ransomware Out, Formjacking In as Primary Attack Vectors Source: https://www.symantec.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/ Symantec has seen a major uptick in formjacking attacks recently, with publicly reported attacks on the websites of companies including Ticketmaster, British Airways, Feedify, and Newegg by a group called Magecart being the most notable examples. Formjacking is a term we use to describe the use of malicious JavaScript code to steal credit card details and other information from payment forms on the checkout web pages of e-commerce sites. Formjacking is not a new technique, but recent campaigns are interesting as they are large, sophisticated, and have increased dramatically since mid-August 2018. . How does formjacking work? When a customer of an e-commerce site clicks "submit" or its equivalent after entering their details into a website's payment form, malicious JavaScript code that has been injected there by the cyber criminals collects all entered information, such as payment card details and the user's name and address. This information is then sent to the attacker's servers. Attackers can then use this information to perform payment card fraud or sell these details to other criminals on the dark web. How big is this campaign? This is a significant and sustained campaign, with activity increasing substantially in the week of September 13 to 20. According to Symantec telemetry, since August 13 we have blocked 248,000 attempts at formjacking—almost a quarter of a million instances. However, more than one third of those blocks (36 percent) occurred from September 13 to 20, indicating that this activity is increasing. What types of businesses are these attacks targeting? As we can see from the publicly reported attacks, Mag

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 -MITM.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 0 Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attack and How to Prevent Them Source: https://www.csoonline.com/article/3340117/cyberwarfare A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack is when an attacker intercepts communications between two parties either to secretly eavesdrop or modify traffic traveling between the two. Attackers might use MitM attacks to steal login credentials or personal information, spy on the victim, or sabotage communications or corrupt data. "MITM attacks are a tactical means to an end," says Zeki Turedi, technology strategist, EMEA at CrowdStrike. "The aim could be spying on individuals or groups to redirecting efforts, funds, resources, or attention." Though MitM can be protected against with encryption, successful attackers will either reroute traffic to phishing sites designed to look legitimate or simply pass on traffic to its intended destination once harvested or recorded, meaning detection of such attacks is incredibly difficult. How man-in-the-middle attacks work? MitM attacks consist of sitting between the connection of two parties and either observing or manipulating traffic. This could be through interfering with legitimate networks or creating fake networks that the attacker controls. Compromised traffic is then stripped of any encryption in order to steal, change or reroute that traffic to the attacker's destination of choice (such as a phishing log-in site). Because attackers may be silently observing or re-encrypting intercepted traffic to its intended source once recorded or edited, it can be a difficult attack to spot. "These types of attacks can be for espionage or financial gain, or to just be disruptive," says Turedi. "The damage caused can range from small to huge, depending on the attacker's goals and ability to cause misc

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 8 - Summer Cyber Safety Tips.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 8 - Summer Cyber Safety Tips.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) US Government Agencies Have Banned Tik Tok Application By: https://www.businessinsider.com/us-government-agencies-have-banned-tiktok-app-2020-2 The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) became the latest federal agency to ban short-form video app TikTok, which is owned by Chinese company ByteDance. The video platform has been criticized for censoring content that might offend governments in markets where it operates. In September 2019, The Guardian saw internal documents that instructed moderators to censor content that could anger the Chinese government, including mentions of Tiananmen Square or Tibetan Independence. In a statement, TikTok said that these policies were no longer in use as of May. In November, the US Senate held a hearing on technology and data security and invited representatives from major technology companies, including TikTok. TikTok declined to send a representative. Zhu said he planned to meet with lawmakers about their concerns over TikTok but then canceled the meetings. The lawmakers argued that because TikTok's parent company ByteDance is based in China, TikTok could be forced "to support and cooperate with intelligence work controlled by the Chinese Communist Party." The senators added in their October letter to the acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire that "there is no legal mechanism for Chinese companies to appeal if they disagree with a request." TikTok responded with a statement, saying that it stores all US user data in the United States and backs it up in Singapore. The TikTok refusal "only underscores Senator Cotton's concerns that the company is beholden to the Chinese Communist Party and will not secure the rights and privacy of its American users," the Arkansas Republican's office said in a state

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 3 - RANSOMWARE.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 3 - RANSOMWARE.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 02 GLOBE TELECOM CUSTOMER PERSONAL DATA BREACH Source: CNN Philippines BACKGROUND The Globe Telecom has experienced system error on its "On the List" program wherein 8,851 of its customers were affected. The said glitch happened on Tuesday, 29 January 2019 and it said to be the personal information were sent to the wrong people. As a matter of compliance with regulatory requirements in the Data Privacy Act, the Globe Telecom has rectified the issue with affected customers on sending wrong confirmation receipt to another individual and reported the incident to the National Privacy Commission. In addition, the error was just a case of sending the data registration confirmation receipt to the wrong individual and was not sent collectively or as a group of data. AFFECTED SUBSCRIBERS The said issue affected prepaid subscribers registered to its On the List program, which enables them to avail tickets to concerts and Globe events. The Globe has immediately took down the registration site and notified all affected customers and the rest of its 60 million prepaid customers were not inconvenienced by the glitch. RECOMMENDATION All PN personnel or dependents who have subscribed to the "On the List" online program of Globe Telecoms are reminded to take precautionary measures while the incident is under investigation. Furthermore, those who may have been affected are advised to monitor their online and offline accounts for any unusual activity, to change passwords, and other means of identity verification, and to be careful of phishing attempts and other online risks. ERIC E NICANOR COL PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- North Korea Malware.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- North Korea Malware.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) New North Korean Malware and Phishing Attacks Sourced from: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/us-govt-exposes-new-north-korean-malware-phishing-attacks/ The US government today released information on three new malware variants used in malicious cyber activity campaigns by a North Korean government-backed hacker group tracked as HIDDEN COBRA. The new malware is being used "for phishing and remote access by #DPRK cyber actors to conduct illegal activity, steal funds & evade sanctions" according to the information published by Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), and the Department of Defense (DoD). U.S. Cyber Command has also uploaded five samples of the newly discovered malware variants onto the VirusTotal malware aggregation repository. Besides the malware samples shared by the U.S. Cyber Command, CISA has also published detailed malware analysis reports (MARs) on its website containing indicators of compromise (IOCs) and YARA rules for each of the detected samples. The cybersecurity agency also provides mitigation measures in the form of Snort rules, as well as recommendations for system owners and administrators to strengthen the security posture of their organization's systems. The MARs are issued to help network defenders detect and reduce exposure to HIDDEN COBRA malicious cyber activity as the United States government cybersecurity agencies refer to North Korean government malicious activity. Three new North Korean malicious tools The first of the new malware variants, COPPERHEDGE, is described as a Remote Access Tool (RAT) "used by advanced persistent threat (APT) cyber actors in the targeting of cryptocurrency exchanges and related entities." This RAT is known for its capabil

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- SIM Jacking.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- SIM Jacking.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) Protect Yourself from SIM Take-over By: https://www.facebook.com/SmartCommunities/posts/2519963494998967 A SIM take-over is when somebody tries to transfer your SIM's mobile number to another SIM through social engineering techniques. It is like a virtual version of budol-budol and is also known as "SIM-jacking", or "SIM-hijacking". How is it done? Through voice calls or SMS, cyber criminals pretend to be a Telecom representative (i.e Smart Communication or Globe Telecom) and will ask you to send a text message and receive a code from the telecom provide. On a Smart SIM, you will be asked to send GET PIN to 7927; and for Globe SIM you will be asked to send UPGRADE to 8080. You will then receive an upgrade code or One Time Password (OTP) number. These codes are intended to transfer the phone number of your current SIM to the new SIM upon purchase of "Upgrade SIM". The Globe and Smart is providing this feature in order for subscribers to upgrade to LTE – a new wireless broadband standard for faster Internet connection - while retaining your current phone number. The cyber criminals will then ask for these codes or OTP numbers which they will use to activate a new SIM card in their possession. Once the key have activated the new SIM card, your current SIM will be deactivated. If you are compromised, all text messages (SMS) and calls that are supposed to be received by your number will be received by the cyber criminal. They can then use this data to hack your banking, email, and other online accounts. What to do? If you received similar messages report it by calling *888 to Smart subscribers or any Globe or Smart hotline numbers. Remember; never give any sensitive information to strangers. Smart and Globe representatives will never ask for your OTP number or upg

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- image malware MS Team .docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- image malware MS Team .docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) The Evil GIF Cyber Attack By: https://thehackernews.com/2020/04/microsoft-teams-vulnerability.html Video Tele-Conference System (VTS) is a communication and collaboration platform that includes chat, video conferencing, file storage, and application integration capabilities. The solution can be highly useful to organizations, particularly during this COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak, when many employees are forced to work from home. Researchers at CyberArk, a company that specializes in privileged access security solutions, discovered vulnerability related to how popular VTS passes authentication access tokens to an image file. An attacker can exploit this weakness to create a link or GIF image file that, when processed, it sends an authentication token to a server they control. In the case of links, the victim needs to click on the link, but in attacks involving GIF images, the victim simply needs to view the GIF image in the chat and their token is sent to the hacker. Once they have obtained the token, the attacker can use it to hijack the victim's account through the VTS Application Programming Interfaces (API). The attacker can use this method to read the user's messages, send messages on their behalf, create groups, add or remove users from a group, and change group permissions. However, there are certain prerequisites for the attack to work. First of all, when the victim sees the malicious GIF, their access token can only be sent to a subdomain (e.g. teams.microsoft.com), so the attacker somehow needs to hijack such a subdomain. Microsoft released a patch for this vulnerability earlier of April and ensured the public that the domains identified by CyberArk cannot be abused and says it has taken other measures to prevent exploitation. As of this writing, th

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- Eventbot .docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- Eventbot .docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) A New Android Malware That Steals Banking Passwords and Two-Factor Codes By: https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/29/eventbot-android-malware-banking/ Security researchers are sounding the alarm over a newly discovered Android malware that targets banking apps and cryptocurrency wallets. The malware, which researchers at security firm Cybereason recently discovered and called EventBot, masquerades as a legitimate Android app — like Adobe Flash or Microsoft Word for Android — which exploits Android's in-built accessibility features to obtain deep access to the device's operating system. Once installed — either by an unsuspecting user or by a malicious person with access to a victim's phone — the EventBot-infected fake app quietly siphons off passwords for more than 200 banking and cryptocurrency apps — including PayPal, Coinbase, CapitalOne and HSBC — and intercepts and two-factor authentication text message codes. With a victim's password and two-factor code, the hackers can break into bank accounts, apps and wallets, and steal a victim's funds. "The developer behind Eventbot has invested a lot of time and resources into creating the code, and the level of sophistication and capabilities is really high," Assaf Dahan, head of threat research at Cybereason, told TechCrunch. The malware quietly records every tap and key press, and can read notifications from other installed apps, giving the hackers a window into what's happening on a victim's device. At one point the malware's creators improved the encryption scheme it uses to communicate with the hackers' server, and included a new feature that can grab a user's device lock code, likely to allow the malware to grant itself higher privileges to the victim's device like payments and system settings. Best Security Pract

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 - Website Management.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 - Website Management.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 07 Best Security and Maintenance Practices for the Website The website is one of the important assets in an organization. As such, it is crucial that we manage and take proper security measures to protect it from various online threats. After all, a protected and well-maintained site will provide a secure environment for your visitors and increase the trust in your organization. In this bulletin, we will outline best practices for securing and maintaining the organization website. . Monitor and Update the Content of the Website A good reason to update your website with valuable content is to keep current audience updated. Your continually fresh content can provide visitors with valuable information about your organization. This will led visitors to your site through a search engine link. Regularly Scan the Website for Vulnerability Scan your web site for malware and vulnerability on a regular basis. Keeping it secure is the best way to prevent hackers from gaining access and ensuring your visitors has the best possible user experience. Patch or Update the Content Management System (CMS) A CMS is a digital system, and like all digital systems it can be hacked. As it gets older – a version of your CMS becomes more exposed to security risks. One of the biggest reasons that makers of a CMS release updates is to address these risks. Install a Web Application Firewall Install a Web Application Firewall to add another layer of protection to your site. You can use a plugin such as Sucuri to add their premium firewall functionality to your site. This will help instantly block hackers, add DDoS mitigation and prevention, and prevent Zero-Day exploits on your site. Backup the Website Having a backup of the website is crucial in case the worst happens. A

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 4 -GrandCrab Ransomware.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 4 -GrandCrab Ransomware.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 03 Beware of Spam Email with GandCrab Ransomware Security Source: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ A new malware spam (malspam) campaign pretending to be the current emergency exit map for the recipient's building is being used to install the GandCrab Ransomware. These spam emails contain malicious Word documents that download and install the infection from a remote computer. According to Myonlinesecurity.co.uk, who discovered this campaign, a server that was previously distributing the Ursnif banking Trojan has now started pushing GandCrab Ransomware v5.1. BleepingComputer decided to take a look at the spam emails and the files being distributed so that you can see how this campaign works. As previously stated, this latest malspam campaign is pretending to be updated emergency exit maps for the recipient's building. These emails state that they are coming from Rosie L. Ashton and have a subject of "Up to datе еmеrgеnсy еxit map". Attached to these spam emails is a Word document titled Emergencyexitmap.doc as shown below. If the attachment is opened, the user will simply see a document with the text "Emergency exit map" and a prompt to enable content. If the user clicks on the Enable Content button, the Word macros will execute a PowerShell script that downloads and installs the GandCrab v5.1 Ransomware onto the computer. When defobfuscated, you can see that the macros download a file called putty.exe from http://cameraista.com/olalala/putty.exe and save it to C:\Windows\temp\putty.exe. The putty.exe is then executed. The putty.exe executable is GandCrab 5.1 and will begin to encrypt the files on your computer. Like earlier variants, GandCrab continues to encrypt files and then append a random extension to their file name. While

Likely   Occurs several times, a common occurrence.  Occasional    Occurs sporadically, but is not uncommon.  Seldom   Remotely possible, could occur at some time. Usually several things must go wrong for it to happen.  Unlikely   Can assume will not occur, but not impossible.  SEVERITY  Catastrophic  Complete mission failure or the loss of ability to accomplish a mission. Death or permanent total disability. Loss of major or mission-critical systems or equipment. Major property or facility damage. Severe environmental damage. Mission-critical security failure. Unacceptable collateral damage  Critical  Severely degraded mission capability or unit readiness. Permanent partial disability or temporary total disability exceeding three months time. Extensive major damage to equipment or systems. Significant damage to property or the environment. Security failure. Significant collateral damage. Marginal  Degraded mission capability or unit readiness. Minor damage to equipment or systems, property, or the environment. Lost days due to injury or illness not exceeding three months. Minor damage to property or the environment. Negligible  Little or no adverse impact on mission capability. First aid or minor medical treatment. Slight equipment or system damage, but fully functional or serviceable. Little or no property or environmental damage. Separate network storages should be provided on every network and on every document classification. Top Secret computer lacks printer. Shortfall of the Current Setup External USB Hard Drives are needed to backup all Network Attached Storages (NAS) in the event that these storages are corrupted (by ransomware, power fluctuation, bad sectors, loss of files, etc). title: 06 PFSense Setup Procedure.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/06 PFSense Setup Procedure.docx
author: System
content: DISCLAIMER This handbook is simplified for MAC Builders utilization. Some reference materials and sources may be derived from open and public sites on the Internet, as well as copyrighted books and publications. All logos, graphics, designs, trade names, trademarks and service marks belong to their respective owners and entities. Introduction Almost by definition, a "firewall" provides a filter that incoming or outgoing packets must pass through. If the firewall does something beyond filtering, like checking against a restrictions list, that's great, but it's not necessarily the "definition" of a firewall's function. Firewalls essentially trap inbound or outbound packets, analyze them, and then either send them on their way or toss them out. Any one of these products may or may not suit your needs. Once you've got a handle on the issues, however, you should be able to do your own product elimination, simply by comparing functional specifications. PfSense is an open source operating system used to turn a computer into a firewall, router, or a variety of other application-specific network appliances. PfSense is a customized FreeBSD distribution based on the m0n0wall project, a powerful but light-weight firewall distribution. PfSense builds upon m0n0wall's foundation and takes its functionality several steps further by adding a variety of other popular networking services. At its most basic level, a pfSense machine can be used to replace the common home router when more functionality is desired. In more advanced configurations, pfSense can be used to establish a secure tunnel to a remote office (VPN), load-balance a web farm, or shape and prioritize all network traffic (Traffic Shaping) just to name a few example scenarios. There are literally hundreds of ways to configure and customize a pfSense installation. The core functionality of any firewall involves creating port forward and firewall security rules, and pfSense is no different. These core features, plus others,

title: 07 Overview of SIEM.pptx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/07 Overview of SIEM.pptx
author: System
content: Security Information & Event Management Background on Network Components Router IPS/IDS Firewall Switch (L2 & L3) Servers (Application, Database, etc.) Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) Virtual Private Network 2 Defense in Depth 3 Seems ideal network! What's the problem? 4 Log management (LM) comprises an approach to dealing with large volumes of computer-generated log messages (also known as audit records, audit trails, event-logs, etc.). LM covers log collection, centralized aggregation, long- term retention, log analysis (in real-time and in bulk after storage) as well as log search and reporting. Log Management 5 Log Management 6 Log Management Challenges Analyzing Logs for Relevant Security Intelligence Centralizing Log Collection Meeting IT Compliance Requirements Conducting Effective Root Cause Analysis Making Log Data More Meaningful Tracking Suspicious User Behavior 7 The term Security Information Event Management (SIEM), coined by Mark Nicolett and Amrit Williams of Gartner in 2005. Describes the product capabilities of gathering, analyzing and presenting information from network and security devices; identity and access management applications; vulnerability management and policy compliance tools; operating system, database and application logs; and external threat data. Introduction to SIEM 8 Introduction to SIEM Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) is a term for software and products services combining security information management (SIM) and security event manager (SEM). The acronyms SEM, SIM and SIEM have been sometimes used interchangeably. The segment of security management that deals with real-time monitoring, correlation of events, notifications and console views is commonly known as Security Event Management (SEM). The second area provides long-term storage, analysis and reporting of log data and is known as Security Information Management (SIM). 9 Key Objectives Identify threats and possible breaches Collect audit logs for security and compl

author: System
content: UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Intrusion Detection Systems UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Agenda Overview of IDS Intrusion prevention using game theory Reducing false positives Clustering alerts from multiple sensors Conclusions UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr OVERVIEW OF IDS UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Intrusions ? An intrusion happens when somebody (hacker or cracker) attempts to break into or misuse your system Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is a software or hardware product that monitors the events occurring in a computer system or network and analyses them for signs of intrusions. Intrusion Detection is the art of detecting inappropriate, incorrect, or anomalous activity. UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Consider your home Authentication IDS Firewall UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Is it any good? Early detection may prevent (or at least minimize the extent of) damage Existence of intrusion detection system serves as deterrent to potential intruders, thus preventing them Enables collection of information to be used to – strengthen the prevention facilities – prosecute (legally) intruder UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Typical Intrusion Scenario Step 1: outside reconnaissance Step 2: inside reconnaissance Step 3: exploit Step 4: foot hold Step 5: profit UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Data Source Application Examines the behaviour of an application program, generally by analysing the application log files Host Utilizes two types of information sources, operating system audit trails, and system logs Network Examines network traffic. Often consist of single purpose sensors that run in stealth mode Hybrid Combines two or more of the sources above UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Host-based IDS UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Network-based IDS UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Detection Methods UNIVERSITY OF PIRAEUS http://www.unipi.gr Comparing Anomaly

content: Cyber Risk Assessment Audit Presented by: OFRATES C SIRINGAN CHR AFP CRA Inspector 7 March 2019 Armed Forces of the Philippines Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) Control Parameters, Gap Capabilities / Findings and Recommendations Continuous Vulnerability Management Continuous Vulnerability Management CRA Parameters Gap Capabilities / Findings Recommendations Utilize an up-to-date SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool to automatically scan all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis to identify all potential vulnerabilities on the organization's systems. No policy for SCAP-compliant vulnerability assessment and/or scanning tools to determine the critical vulnerabilities. Run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis; inform system administrators of most critical vulnerabilities. Implement and enforce SCAP Based Vulnerability Management System. Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning with agents running locally on each system or with remote scanners that are configured with elevated rights on the system being tested. No authenticated credential authentication intended for vulnerability assessment. Perform vulnerability scanning on each end system in authenticated mode with agents or remote scanners Provide authenticated vulnerability scanning on all networked end systems using software agents or remote scanners. Continuous Vulnerability Management CRA Parameters Gap Capabilities / Findings Recommendations Use a dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability scans, which should not be used for any other administrative activities and should be tied to specific machines at specific IP addresses. Lack of dedicated account for authenticate vulnerability assessment. author: System
content: The 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations 26 THE 2016 REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 9184 The 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations 27 THE 2016 REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 9184, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT REFORM ACT RULE I – GENERAL PROVISIONS Section 1. Short Title and Purpose This 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations2 , hereinafter called the IRR, is promulgated pursuant to Section 75 of Republic Act No. (R.A.) 9184, otherwise known as the "Government Procurement Reform Act," for the purpose of prescribing the necessary rules and regulations for the modernization, standardization, and regulation of the procurement activities of the Government of the Philippines (GoP).(a) Section 2. Declaration of Policy The provisions of this IRR are in line with the commitment of the GoP to promote good governance and its effort to adhere to the principles of transparency, accountability, equity, efficiency, and economy in its procurement process. It is the policy of the GoP that procurement of Goods, Infrastructure Projects and Consulting Services shall be competitive and transparent, and therefore shall undergo competitive bidding, except as provided in Rule XVI of this IRR.(a) Section 3. Governing Principles on Government Procurement The procurement of the GoP shall be governed by these principles: a) Transparency in the procurement process and in the implementation of procurement contracts through wide dissemination of bid opportunities and participation of pertinent non-government organizations. b) Competitiveness by extending equal opportunity to enable private contracting parties who are eligible and qualified to participate in competitive bidding. c) Streamlined procurement process that will uniformly apply to all government procurement. The procurement process shall be simple and made adaptable to advances in modern technology in order to ensure an effecti

"The Services" means those services ancillary to the supply of the Goods, such as transportation and insurance, and any other incidental services, such as installation, commissioning, provision of technical assistance, training, and other such obligations of the Supplier covered under the Contract. "GCC" means the General Conditions of Contract contained in this Section. "SCC" means the Special Conditions of Contract. SPECIFICATIONS COMPLY/NOT COMPLY Threat Intelligence Platform Two (2) years subscription On-premise solution Minimum of 2 Analyst Capability to automatically parse IOCs from unstructured source documents such as PDF, DOC, XLS, as well as web pages and blog posts Must automatically researches and scores each IOC imported using machine learning or other unsupervised techniques Must have sandboxing for detonation of phishing email attachments and URLs, that can run as a cloud service with no additional infrastructure requirements Must have SaaS service and an on-premise components and store IOCs and investigations on physical premise with no cloud opex cost Must allow analyst to conduct detailed investigations with workbench, on-demand enrichment and link analysis tools. content: ANNEX 6 RISK, THREAT AND VULNERABILITY MANAGEMENT Overview: Scope of Work: Supply, delivery, installation and configuration of the system. Testing and Commissioning Training Documentation Two (2) years Maintenance and Warranty NO SPECIFICATIONS COMPLY/NOT COMPLY The solution must be on premise, perpetual license with 2 years Maintenance The System must be able to import scanning data from different vulnerability scanners technologies such as Rapid7 The System must be able to assist in the analysing of incidents and assessment of risk. The System must have the ability to run risk analysis on network paths based on firewall policies and network connectivity The System must be able to perform risk exposure analysis. The System must be able to model the network map based on threat source, vulnerability analysis, network, and service info. The System must be able to identify attack vectors across a whole network, or specified subparts, from a specified start point(s) and to specified target(s) known as attack path analysis. The System must be able to model IPS as a compensating control to mitigate any exploitable attack path. The System must be able to model firewall rule changes to mitigate and exploitable attack path. The System must be able to analyse potential paths of access between security zones known as network path analysis. The System when performing vulnerability exposure analysis the solution must also consider the post attack conditions that need to be in place for the attacker to take advantage of the vulnerability to extend further towards a potential attack. The System must have the capability of prioritizing vulnerabilities for remediation based on network configurations, security controls such as Firewalls, IPS & etc, density, proximity to different levels of criticality of business, availability of exploit kits, knowledge of vulnerability exploitation in the wild, exposure, age and severity of the vulnerability. BRIEF PROJECT DESCRIPTION Cyber Laboratory and Security Operation Center with Mission Essential Equipment, with ISO 27001 certified facility and accompanying Initial Integrated Logistics Support will be acquired for an estimated cost of P200.691 M. 2. PURPOSE Execute the appropriate strategy and process for the acquisition of the Cyber Laboratory and SOC. 3. OBJECTIVE To provide the Bids and Awards Committee (BAC) the guidelines regarding the preparation of bid documents, bidding proper, evaluation of bids, formulation of contract and other procurement activities. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS & ISSUANCES 1. RA 7898 (AFP Modernization Act) 2. RA 9184 (The Government Procurement Reform Act) 3. IRR of RA Nr 9184 5. STATEMENT OF NEED Naval defense and national development require a significant cyber security capability that could support military and non-military operations. To provide the needed cyber security capability, the Philippine Navy needs to acquire Cyber Laboratory and Security Operation Center. The cyber laboratory has a capability for cyber range, vulnerability assessment and penetration testing, incidence response and cyber forensic. The Security operation center has a real-time threat intelligence, data loss prevention, endpoint detection and response, integration of sensors, back up and recovery and DDOS Monitoring or anti-DDOS. 6. title: CLASOC for DNDBAC2 - 23 August 2019 -main.pptx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/CLASOC for DNDBAC2 - 23 August 2019 -main.pptx
author: System
content: Cyber Laboratory & (Security) Operations Center 23 August 2019 SECRET Scope of Presentation Project Description Project Milestones Previous Comments Project Timelines Recommendation The establishment of a Cyber Laboratory and Security Operation Center with mission essential equipment and ISO 27001 compliant Data Center housed in a two (2) storey building. The Cyber Laboratory is a facility that establishes a contained and controlled environment to simulate, test or practice cyber related activities (defensive & offensive cyber operations) including digital forensics examination, malware detection and deactivation and penetration testing. A Security Operations Center is a facility where cyber or IT systems are monitored, assessed, and defended. It enables the effective collaboration and communication of the personnel (people), disparate security products (technology), and varying processes and procedures (processes). Project Description Project Name: Cyber laboratory and Security Operations Center Lot 1: Equipment: One Hundred Fifty Million Six-Hundred Ninety-One thousand Pesos (Php 150,691,000.00) Lot 2: Infrastructure: Fifty Million Pesos (Php 50,000,000.00) Funding: AFP Modernization Act Trust Fund (GAA 2019) Mode of Acquisition: Section 4.2 (Government to Government Procurement), per ADM Nr. 2018-038 dtd 27 October 2018. Project Description Programmed Capability Project Milestones 2nd Pass to VC PN 16 April 2018 2nd Pass to PNDCC 30 April 2018 2nd Pass to DAS Ad Hoc 11 May 2018 2nd Pass to USFM 08 June 2018 2nd Pass to AFPSEO & J4 19 June 2018 2nd Pass to FOIC PN 20 June 2018 2nd Pass to SNRLD & DND 22 June 2018 DASAT TWG Oath Taking 10 Sept 2018 CSAFP signed Decision Package 20 Sept 2018 ASLA released ADM 27 Oct 2018 1st update presentation to DNDBAC 24 July 2019 2nd update presentation to DNDBAC 07 Aug 2019 Previous Comments Why is it G to G is the mode of procurement? title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_JOEY_v2.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel
