title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: what HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: Attendance to RootCon Hackers' Conference Ref: FOIC, PN approved DF dated 02 August 2019, subject: Attendance to RootCon Event Encls: Topic Presentations AAR from LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN Pictures with caption I. General: ROOTCON is an annual cyber security conference and the largest hacking conference in the Philippines. The event aims to foster camaraderie and sharing of expertise among cybersecurity professionals, security researchers, and ethical hackers. A two-day activity showcasing lectures on the latest techniques and tactics of hacking, a hands-on experience on ways of cracking devices; and competing in the Capture the Flag (CTF) contest - a special kind of cybersecurity competition designed to challenge its participants to solve computer security problems. This activity was held on 26-27 September 2019 at Taal Vista Hotel, Tagaytay and was attended by LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, CPT JEAN PAUL T SAN GABRIEL PN(M), LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN, LTJG JOMAR M WELBA PN, SN2 Rhea T Espinosa PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. II. Schedule of Activities: Time Activities/ Topics Resource Person Day 1 0900H-0930H Keynote CDR LOPEZ, Commander, AFPCYG 0930H-1015H Navigating the Shift from Opportunistic to Targeted Ransomware Christopher Elisan 1015H-1115H Capture The Flag (CTF) game participated by ON6 and NICTC personnel. 1115H-1215H Farewell, WAF - Exploiting SQL Injection from Mutation to Polymorphism Boik Su Lunch 1300H-1345H The Man-In-The-Middle attack against a certain password manager Soya Aoyama 1345H-1430H Pilot Study on Semi-Automated Patch Diffing by Applying Machine-Learning Techniques Asuka Nakajima 1430H-1545H SAML Assailant Narayan Gowraj 1545H-1645H Identity crisis: war stories from authenti

content: what HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: Attendance to RootCon Hackers' Conference Ref: FOIC, PN approved DF dated 02 August 2019, subject: Attendance to RootCon Event Encls: Topic Presentations AAR from LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN Pictures with caption I. General: ROOTCON is an annual cyber security conference and the largest hacking conference in the Philippines. The event aims to foster camaraderie and sharing of expertise among cybersecurity professionals, security researchers, and ethical hackers. A two-day activity showcasing lectures on the latest techniques and tactics of hacking, a hands-on experience on ways of cracking devices; and competing in the Capture the Flag (CTF) contest - a special kind of cybersecurity competition designed to challenge its participants to solve computer security problems. This activity was held on 26-27 September 2019 at Taal Vista Hotel, Tagaytay and was attended by LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, CPT JEAN PAUL T SAN GABRIEL PN(M), LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN, LTJG JOMAR M WELBA PN, SN2 Rhea T Espinosa PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. II. Schedule of Activities: Time Activities/ Topics Resource Person Day 1 0900H-0930H Keynote CDR LOPEZ, Commander, AFPCYG 0930H-1015H Navigating the Shift from Opportunistic to Targeted Ransomware Christopher Elisan 1015H-1115H Capture The Flag (CTF) game participated by ON6 and NICTC personnel. 1115H-1215H Farewell, WAF - Exploiting SQL Injection from Mutation to Polymorphism Boik Su Lunch 1300H-1345H The Man-In-The-Middle attack against a certain password manager Soya Aoyama 1345H-1430H Pilot Study on Semi-Automated Patch Diffing by Applying Machine-Learning Techniques Asuka Nakajima 1430H-1545H SAML Assailant Narayan Gowraj 1545H-1645H Identity crisis: war stories from authenti

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: Chapter 1 `INTRODUCTION Background of the Study Data exchange or data communication is a key process of providing accurate and timely information to senior leaders, top management, and decision makers. It involves the use of email, instant messaging, video conference, chat, online forums, and other applications that transmit data from sender to receiver. Many organizations and modern companies prefer to use instant messaging rather than email for simpler and more user-friendly collaboration among staff and management. It also exchanges data almost at an instant, allowing two-way communication in near real-time. Instant messaging applications like Facebook messenger, SKYPE, and Yahoo Messenger provide easy, fast, and cost-effective means of text, voice, and video communication. It has become the most preferred application to communicate with peers, families, and among professionals from various industries and sectors. Businesses are now beginning to embrace IM for their office communication. Although it is less formal than a face to face meeting, it can bridge the gap of needing to collaborate and communicate with each other. Private companies, schools, organizations, and government agencies use IM to support or provide redundancy with their other existing mode of communication. The military recognizes the necessity to develop or acquire a secure, reliable, and near real-time data communication tool for effective exchange of information and to provide the high-command a means to collate information needed for decision-making. In today's network-centric operation, Instant Messaging (IM) is an essential information communication tool for rapid delivery of messages and reports, and for situational awareness. The US military has long been using IM for its military operations. In fact, Cummings (2004, p. 654) stated that "it was the primary means of communication between navy ships during Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2003". The Philippine Navy (PN), a branch of service in t

filename: D:/drive/N6B/Tags/Cyber Lab/CEIS Dir on PN Standard LAN and Network Security .docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS DIRECTIVE ) NUMBER… ) SUBJECT: Supplemental Guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities TO: See Distribution REFERENCES: SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities CEIS LD Nr. 2012-001 dtd 19 Dec 2012, Subj: PN Standard LAN and Network Security Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. PURPOSE: This CEIS Directive prescribes the supplemental guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities particularly on the conformity to the SANS twenty (20) Critical Security Controls. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cybersecurity -deliberate synergy of technologies, processes, and practices to protect information and the networks, computer systems and appliances, and programs used to collect, process, store, and transport that information from attack, damage and unauthorized access. Cybersecurity Posture – refers to the overall cybersecurity strength of an PN. It expresses the relative security of the IT estate and its vulnerability to outside threats. Risk Assessment – is a process of identifying, estimating, and prioritizing risks of PNal assets and operations. It involves evaluating hazards, and developing plans to remove or minimize the level of risk. Security Controls - refers to technical, physical, and administrative safeguards to detect cyber threats, minimize risks, and protect from cyber attacks. POLICIES Malware Protection Utilize centr

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: 25 Chapter 2 CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK This chapter presents the review of previous literatures and studies related to Instant Messaging applications. It explores the earlier developments, previous research, and existing technologies leading to the development of a prototype cryptographic IM (CIM). It includes the operational definition of terms used, and the conceptual framework to visually synthesize all materials and techniques in achieving the desired objective. Review of Related Literature and Studies Historical Development of Instant Messaging (IM) The advent of Instant Messenger like Facebook Messenger, Skype, WhatsApp, Telegram, and other popular IM revolutionizes the way people communicate with each other. But its impressive features would not be possible without the earlier breakthrough of their predecessors. Desjardin (2016), in his article "The Evolution of Instant Messaging", narrates the written accounts that brought the IM and how it grows prominence in the new era. Instant Messaging became known in the 1990's but decades ago Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) already demonstrated an information sharing program called Compatible Time-Sharing System (CTSS). In 1988, Jarkko Oikarinen developed the first chat system that allows sending messages to users through their computers (Oikarinen, 1988). His Internet Relay Chat (IRC) paved the way for other IM players like AOL IM, ICQ, and Microsoft IRC to battle for share in the IM market. Yahoo messenger dominates in 1998 with its intuitive designs and feature-rich IM environment. Engel (2014) recounts how IM grow prominence in the 2000s. This was the golden age of instant messenger. MSN Messenger introduced the concept of sharing photos and included the PC-to-PC and PC-to-phone audio capabilities. Skype Messenger peaked in popularity in 2003 as it showcased Audio and Video chat capabilities. Facebook chat was first introduced in 2008 and accelerated its popularity in 2014 when it decouples from the Facebo

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: Plan Design Build Test Review Launch 44 Plan Design Build Test Review Launch Chapter 3 RESEARCH METHODOLOGY This chapter presents the project design and project development to provide blueprint of the entire system architecture. Operational procedure and method of testing and evaluation are explained to measure its effectiveness based on predefined parameters. Project Design The Cryptographic Instant Messaging (CIM) system is Instant Messaging (IM) application software that provides encrypted chat communication and file transfer for secure and reliable exchange of information. IM Relay ServerIM Relay Server IM Relay Server IM Relay Server INTERNETINTERNET INTERNET INTERNET EncryptEncryptDecryptDecrypt Encrypt Encrypt Decrypt Decrypt ReceiveReceiveSendSend Receive Receive Send Send Client XClient XClient YClient Y Client X Client X Client Y Client Y Figure 2. Interface Diagram of CIM Operational Concept and Dataflow Figure 2 from the previous page illustrates the fundamental structure of the system and flow of data from an end-user's perspective. Client X initiates a chat conversation with Client Y using the CIM client software. During the chat conversation, the system automatically encrypts the text message prior sending it to the IM Relay Server. The server now searches for the intended recipient from its list of client sockets. When the recipient's socket is available, the server transmits the encrypted text message to Client Y (recipient) through its socket. The server manages all clients' sockets. It handles authentication of all incoming clients prior acceptance of the socket. IM Relay Server maintains a minimal database using MS SQL Server, SQL Express, or MS Access for accounts and activity logs. As soon as the text message arrived at Client Y (recipient), the software then decrypts the text using the system-generated key as the default. Unreadable message or randomized characters indicates unmatched passkey. Both Client X (sender) and Client Y (recipient) m

content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila The Manager/Director Google Philippines Inc. Net Park Building, 5th Avenue, Bonifacio Global City,  Taguig, 1634 Metro Manila Sir/Madam: What? xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx Greetings!  This pertains to your latest offering of making Google Meet available to everyone for FREE during this pandemic crisis. The Google Meet is said to be built on a secure foundation and provides the protections needed to keep users safe, data secure, and information private. The Philippine Navy, wishes to be part of this endeavor and keen on testing the product earlier than the scheduled roll-out.   Should the management of Google finds merit on this request, please do contact LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN with mobile number 0917-8095116 or our office number 02-522-2376. Thank you and we hope to hear from you! Very truly yours, ERIC    E   NICANOR     Colonel, PN(M) (GSC)            AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6

Thank you and we hope to hear from you! Very truly yours, ERIC    E   NICANOR     Colonel, PN(M) (GSC)            AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada  2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila Secretary EDUARDO M. AÑO Department of Interior and Local Government DILG NAPOLCOM Center EDSA corner Quezon Avenue Quezon City, Metro Manila Dear Secretary Año: The Philippine Navy (PN) will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019 (CyDex 2019) from 15 to 26 July 2019 at Philippine Navy Officers Club, Marine Barracks Rudiardo Brown (MBRB), Fort Bonifacio, Taguig City. The objective of this exercise is to evaluate the responsiveness and effectiveness of the existing PN doctrines, procedures, and protocols in cyber warfare. In this regard, the PN respectfully requests for a courtesy call on the Secretary or any of his concerned staff most convenient schedule to further discuss and articulate the intent of the command on this upcoming event, and the needed participation of your department. Should the good Secretary find merit on this request, LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, Chief, Cyber, Warfare Department, N6 with mobile phone number 0917-8095116 will coordinate the other details on this matter. Thank you and more power!   Very truly yours, FOR THE FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND, PN: ERIC    E    NICANOR  Colonel   PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: Good!  Not Good! xxhh HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY      OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6  Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From:  Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via:     Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: Attendance to RootCon Hackers Conference  Ref:   FOIC, PN approved DF dated 02 August 2019, subject: Attendance to RootCon Event Encls:    Topic Presentations AAR from LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN Pictures with caption  I. General:  ROOTCON is an annual cyber security conference and the largest hacking conference in the Philippines. The event aims to foster camaraderie and sharing of expertise among cybersecurity professionals, security researchers, and ethical hackers. A two-day activity showcasing lectures on the latest techniques and tactics of hacking, a hands-on experience on ways of cracking devices; and competing in the Capture the Flag (CTF) contest - a special kind of cybersecurity competition designed to challenge its participants to solve computer security problems. This activity was held on 26-27 September 2019 at Taal Vista Hotel, Tagaytay and was attended by LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, CPT JEAN PAUL T SAN GABRIEL PN(M), LTJG MARIO N TRIBUNAL PN, LTJG JOMAR M WELBA PN, SN2 Rhea T Espinosa PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. II. Schedule of Activities: Time Activities/ Topics Resource Person Day 1 0900H-0930H Keynote CDR LOPEZ,  Commander, AFPCYG 0930H-1015H Navigating the Shift from Opportunistic to Targeted Ransomware Christopher Elisan 1015H-1115H Capture The Flag (CTF) game participated by ON6 and NICTC personnel. 1115H-1215H Farewell, WAF - Exploiting SQL Injection from Mutation to Polymorphism Boik Su Lunch 1300H-1345H The Man-In-The-Middle attack against a certain password manager Soya Aoyama 1345H-1430H Pilot Study on Semi-Automated Patch Diffing by Applying Machine-Learning Techniques Asuka Nakajima 1430H-1545H SAML Assailant Narayan Gowraj 1545H-1645H Ident

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: Cyber Risk Assessment For HPA Risk Assessment Secure Configuration for Hardware and Software Probability Severity Risk Level Likely (61%-80%) Catastrophic Extremely High 78% Secure Configuration for Hardware and Software Sub controls Capability Gap/ Findings Recommendation Maintain documented, standard security configuration standards for all authorized operating systems and software While the Cybersecurity Flight is implementing secure configuration such as closing ports prior deployment, this practice is not being written Crafting of procedure or manual for baseline secure configuration for all servers and workstations Maintain secure images or templates for all systems in the enterprise based on the organization's approved configuration standards Secure Configuration for Hardware and Software Sub controls Capability Gap/ Findings Recommendation Deploy system configuration management tools HPAF offices are implementing unsecured file and folder sharing or workgroup sharing Implement central management of all computers in the HPAF. Secure system configuration for workstations can be automated through the implementation of Active Directory. Utilize a Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP) compliant configuration monitoring system Risk Assessment Application Software Security Probability Severity Risk Level Occasional (41%-60%) Critical High 43% Application Software Security Sub controls Capability Gap/ Findings Recommendation Establish secure coding practices appropriate to the programming language and development environment being used. While the Software Development Flight is inculcating cybersecurity among the programmers, there is no written policy for secure coding Develop a policy that will categorically include the security aspects especially secure coding throughout the software development lifecycle (SDLC) Application Software Security Sub controls Capability Gap/ Findings Recommendation Verify that the version of all software is still supported by th

title: Update.pptx
author: System
content: PN CYBER WARFARE INFORMATION BRIEF 25 June 2018 1 2 CONFIDENTIAL SCOPE OF PRESENTATION Introduction Common Cyber Threats in PN Network PN Cyber Warfare Efforts Way-Ahead 3 4 4 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 26 June 2013 Malicious emails originating from O/CNS e-mail account. 08 August 2013 The database of the PN Web Server was hacked. The attacker was able to extract several user accounts. 10 May 2013 Philippine websites including the PN was under Distributed Denial of Service (DDOS) attack following the Taiwanese fisherman shooting incident 30 August 2013 Adoption of Cyberspace as domain of AFP operations 04 April 2014 FOIC, PN received an email with malware embedded attachment May 2014 Phishing Attack on CIB, ON2 02 December 2014 NICTC became PN support unit 11 Feb 2015 VAPT report of USPACOM found several exploitable computers, routers and network switches 27 May 2015 Malicious mails were sent to different PNCS accounts 05 March 2016 Report on Backdoor Trojan Malware (Lotus Blossom) by DOST 26 April 2016 Malicious emails were sent with an HTML embedded code exploiting the Zimbra's default setting of Opening email using HTML. 04 August 2016 PMC Website was hacked by a group called BloodSecurity; Later found out to be NISF elite hackers conducting Penetration Testing against PN website. 20 September 2016 Symantec report of a PRC-linked Billbug Cyber Espionage activity targeting the PN 22 October 2016 NICTS Cebu reported Ransomware Attack on FMSGC . 08 December 2016 Taiwan Intelligence Agency reported cybersecurity breach on PN Network. Several classified documents were exfiltrated purportedly by PLA such as 3 docs frm O/F2 Introduction Milestone of PN Cyber Warfare 5 5 Cyberspace as 4th domain of AFP Operations Introduction The Two Enabling Doctrines of Cyber Warfare Introduction PN Information Network Operations (INO) Defensive Cyberspace Operation (DCO) Offensive Cyberspace Operation (OCO) The Cyber Warfare Manual Introduction 8 Introduction 9 O-55 EP-299 CE – 76 TOTA

title: Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System 28 April 2019.pptx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System 28 April 2019.pptx
author: System
content: Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System(EPMIS) Armed Forces of the Philippines Procurement Service (AFFPS) Scope of Presentation Reference Background Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) System Features & Benefits Automated Processes Sample Prototype and generated report' Issues and Concerns Recommendations Reference FOIC, PN Command Guidance CY 2019 Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) of AFPPS Background In line with FOIC, PN Command Guidance CY 2019 to ensure check and balance as well as transparency in procurement processes of all projects is the adoption of a Procurement Monitoring System. Last 28 March 2019, Mr Bong Sapasap of Business Solutions and IT Services presented Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) that was previously used by AFP Procurement Service (AFPPS). Electronic Procurement Monitoring Information System (EPMIS) a web-based application developed to serve as the focal point for AFPPS, its Procurement Centers and Contracting Offices to process, manage, and monitor procurement services Features User Friendly Process Oriented/Driven Transaction transparency/traceability Compliant to standards/statutory and regulatory requirements Real time availability of data/reports to Catered Units, Suppliers and stakeholders Secured SECURED has the highest 'class' of available SSL, Extended Validation (EV) SSL, that secures websites SECURED Has a high-level 2048-bit encryption provided by COMODO SSL Certificate SECURED Has a grade of A and above in compliance with SSL/TLS Security Test BENEFITS Improved Quality, Governance and Reliability Barcodes in every forms. Security codes are imbedded in each form to ensure printed forms came out of the system. Ensuring authenticity of the documents. All forms are precise. It ensures that all salient points in a form is created with the same specifications and process every time. Consistency of the process/workflow. It ensures that process

author: System
content: Comparison of Mobile Phones with regards to Privacy and Security Parameters Huawei Oppo Samsung Iphone Encryption File-based (AES 256 bit) File-based (AES 256 bit) File-based (AES 256 bit) Authentication Pin, Password, Pattern Pin, Password, Pattern Pin, Password, Pattern, Fingerprint and Iris Scanner Pin, Password, Pattern, Facial Recognition Privacy Protection (e.g. disable location) Yes Yes Yes Yes Security Patch Time-frame Monthly Scheduled Monthly, Quarterly, and Only when necessary Scheduled Password Protected Files SecureFolder Reputable Apps Store Less stringent review in Playstore More stringent review Operating System Open Source (Can be freely modified) Proprietary Hardware Advance RISC Machine Main Office Location China South Korea USA Embedded Spying Chips no substantial proof of espionage has ever been established Assessment: All mobile phones provide the necessary security features for data protection. However, Iphone is more advantage in having less reported malware due to its proprietary OS and a more stringent review of all applications in the App Store.

title: Brief Description of the General Function of.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Brief Description of the General Function of.docx
author: System
content: Brief Description of the General Function of Information Technology Officer (ITO) II: Formulate plans, policies, and manage IT infrastructure and cyber security controls; supervise the activities of subordinate analyst, researcher, programmer, and technologist in the conduct of systems development and maintenance of computers and IT networks. Specific Duties and Responsibilities: Develop, review, and update the PN cyber security and information system policies and procedures. Develop, review, and update the PN Information Systems Strategic Plan (ISSP). Oversees the activities of subordinate analyst, and programmers in the development of information systems. Oversees the activities of subordinate technologist in the conduct of preventive and corrective maintenance of computers and networks. Evaluate and facilitate the fund request of PN units pertaining to Information and Communication Technology hardware and software. Oversees the implementation of all funded ICT projects of the PN including cyber security controls, network infrastructure, and information systems. Provides technical advice to superior officers on matters pertaining to information technology and cyber security.

content: ICT Project Updates – 01 October 2019 Minutes of Conference Procurement Monitoring System CNICTC intends to launch the system prior the 2nd semester command conference. title: 0217 - AAR on OPLAW Cyberwarfare Seminar.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/AAR/0217 - AAR on OPLAW Cyberwarfare Seminar.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR WCEIS, N6 Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Branch Chief, Research and Doctrine To: AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Subj: Operational Law Alumni Forum (Cyberwarfare Seminar) Ref: NDCP Invitation Encl: 1) Programme of Activities 2) Certificate of Appearance 3) Pictures 4) Presentations on Hybrid Threats and its Implications 5) Cyberwarfare and International Law 6) Operational Law and the Threats of Cyberwarfare and Terrorism in the Philippines I. General: The National Defense College of the Philippines (NDCP), in cooperation with the Friedrich Ebert Stiftung (FES), conducted the Operational Law Alumni Forum featuring a seminar on "Cyberwarfare, the Law of Armed Conflict and Challenges of Future Warfare". The two-day activity was held from 17 to 18 February 2017 at Club Balai Isabel, Talisay, Batangas and was attended by OPLAW alumni from the defense department, AFP, government agencies and non-government agencies. The activity aimed to achieve the following: Collaborate with all the OPLAW alumni from the five classes Discuss cyberwarfare Discuss the operational law in cyberwarfare The alumni were transported from Discovery Hotel, Ortigas, Pasig City to the venue in Talisay, Batangas on 171330H February 2017. The alumni joined the graduation ceremony of Operational Law Course Class 5 on 171600H February 2017 followed by a dinner fellowship. The main activity started thru a formal opening ceremony on 180900H February 2017. BGEN ROLAND G JUNGCO AFP (Ret), the Executive Vice President of NDCP rendered a welcome remarks. The foreign counterpart, Dr. Johannes Kadura, resident representative of FES, also gave his welcome remarks. The highlight of the seminar are the topics delivered by prolific speakers namely CDR THOMAS BOEHLKE (Ret), a faculty from the German Armed Forces Command and Staff College who discussed Hybrid

title: 1515574050-FINAL_PN Staff Writing Hand Guide.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/1515574050-FINAL_PN Staff Writing Hand Guide.pdf
author: System
content: Staff Writing Hand Guide PHILIPPINE NAVY PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 2 Philippine Navy Staff Writing Hand Guide Copyright 2017 Office of the Chief of Naval Staff PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 3 Message The crafting of the PN Staff Writing Hand Guide supports the aim of the Philippine Navy to be a world-class navy that our maritime nation can be proud of. More than our thrusts for operational and strategic excellence, we also endeavor for a holistic advancement, which includes the quality of our naval documents. Through this hand guide, we take another step forward in terms of professionalizing our navy and its systems. We cultivate and further improve our written documents as a reflection of our excellence and professionalism. Just like our processes and strategies, our written documents must also be improved in a way that will make our jobs easier and our service better. With the few but important points presented in this hand guide, we must aim to take the standards of the navy writing to a higher level. Therefore, everyone is encouraged to follow the writing guidelines contained in this hand guide. FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila RONALD JOSEPH S MERCADO Vice Admiral, AFP PHILIPPINE NAVY STAFF WRITING HAND GUIDE 4 Message The Philippine Navy (PN) uses written communication in its official and daily correspondence, both within and outside our institution. We put everything in writing to have permanency of records and effective communication that leads to efficient operations. To achieve clear and concise naval documents, this PN Staff Writing Hand Guide prescribes the use of plain writing that will allow readers to easily comprehend what is written. It does not only supplement the PN Staff Writing Manual, but it also introduces resolutions to the common issues observed in the different written communication. With this hand guide, all officers, enlisted personnel and civilian emp

title: Conference-29Aug2019.docx
author: System
content: Information Systems Updates Conference: 29 August 2019 Agenda: Updates on Procurement Monitoring System Invite PS3 and PS6 of AFP PS to be involved in the Procurement System next week. Sub-phases for the PHASE 1 (275 working days) are: Sub Phase 1 – Competitive Bidding (95 working days) Sub Phase 2 – Alternative mode of procurement Sub Phase 3 – File Uploading Submit documentary requirements to COA prior NTP. Phase 2 – implement PKI and Bar coding Phase 3 Cloud based, data analytics, and notification service For modification: Delete option is deleted Monitoring number of dates, warning to user for the number of dates. Progress or milestone payment (this maybe irrelevant because of the "remark" option) Growth repair Procurement service only encodes contract number and not controls number. Project Control number will be the UPR number. End user will encode the UPS number. Add contract number for PS. drop down "mode of procurement – Competitive bidding and alternative mode", Display "NOA and supplier" if alternative mode of procurement. Separate interface for internal end users (FOIC monitoring) and public users (supplier). Remove "remarks" in public viewing status only. Develop Flowchart for the end users appreciation. Next week. Workshop next week for PRISM. Conference Meeting on 03 September 2019 at 1500H. Agenda: Updates on NRC MIS Start encoding of data (build up database) while developing the other requirements of NRC. Define project objectives and rationale. Develop the entire NRCMIS project in phases. Target date of completion - 10 September 2019. Deployment- 11 September. Users training 12 September.

filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/AAR/0317 - AAR on Microsoft Active Directory Course.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR WCEIS, N6 Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 06 March 2017 From: Branch Chief, Information Management To: AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for WCEIS, N6 Subj: After Training Report on Microsoft Active Directory Course Ref: Microsoft Training Voucher Encl: 1) Training Confirmation from NTT Data Philippines 2) NTT Data Philippines Location Map 3) Certificate of Achievement 4) Pictures 5) Printed Digital Microsoft Courseware I. General: The Microsoft Philippines, in cooperation with NTT Data (formerly Wizards Group), conducted Microsoft Official Course 20410D: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012. The course is a five (5) days activity whichwas held from 27February to 03March 2017 at NTT Data Phils. Training Center, Unit 2801, 88 Corporate Center, Sedeño corner Valero St, Salcedo VillageMakati City. The course was participated by the undersigned together with LT BERT Z. DOLOT PN and S2DP Rhea Mae E. Espinosa PN from Naval Information, Communications and Technology Center (NICTC). The course is composed of a classroom lectures and laboratory exercises from 9am to 5pm everyday led by a Microsoft Certified Trainer (MCT). Exercise guide materials and desktop computers with internet access were provided and configuredfor every students to access the Digital Microsoft Official Courseware.During the duration of the course, breakfast, light snacks and lunch were also provided. The Microsoft Official Course 20410D: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 is outlined to 13 modules as follows: Module 1: Deploying and Mapping Windows Server 2012 Module 2: Introduction to Active Directory Domain Services Module 3: Managing Active Directory Domain Services Objects Module 4: Automating Active Directory Domain Services Administration Module 5: Implementing IPv4 Module 6: Implementing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Module 7:

title: AAR on CyberCon.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR WCEIS, N6 Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Branch Chief, Cyber Warfare Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR, N6 Subj: AAR on Cyber Security Conference and Exhibition (Cybercon Asia 2017) Ref: Invitation from WorldTech Philippines Inc. Encl: 1) Agenda Details 2) Certificate of Attendance 3) Pictures I. General: CyberCon Asia is an annual cyber security conference and exhibitions that brings together asia's leading cyber experts to discuss various issues, trends, and threat landscape of the cyberspace. The PN was invited by Worldtech Philippines in this two (2) day seminar held at Grand Convention Center, Cebu City, Philippines; attended by LT RODEL G BARRACA PN and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro CE. The event, aims to produce a consortium of cyber security professionals, IT practitioners, ethical hackers and IT product specialists from various industries, academe, corporate sectors, government, and non-government organizations to raise awareness about the state of cyber security in both domestic and international level. Specifically, the conference aims to achieve the following: Develop solidarity in protecting nations privacy; Raise awareness in cyber related threats. Discuss best practices and frameworks for cyber security. Share new techniques in exploiting software vulnerabilities in order to counter possible attack against our own information systems. The activity started with a speech from the PNP Chief of Public Information Office, PCSupt. Dionardo Bernardo Carlos followed by lecture on Data Privacy Act by the Deputy Privacy Commissioner of NPC, Mr. Damian O. Mapa; and the presentation of National Cybersecurity Plan 2022 by the DICT Region 7 Director, Mr. Antonio E. Padre. While some subsequent speakers grab the opportunity to discuss their product portfolio, others provide lectures on cyber security framework a

title: AAR_Rootcon.docx
author: System
content: HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: International Publication of Mr. Maligro's Research Entitled Hybrid Encryption Algorithm Towards Secured Instant Messaging Ref: Letter invitation from Encls: Journal entitled Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging I. General: The International Research Conference in Computing, Engineering, Education and Education Technology (IRCCEEE) is an International convention of technological researches being conducted by various academic institutions. This year the event was held at Legazpi City, Philippines. Mr. Maligro's research is fortunate to be chosen as one of the three (3) thesis and dissertations of Technological University of the Philippines (TUP) to be presented during this conference. Due to conflicting schedule, Mr Maligro was represented by his adviser Dr. Gemma Belga and successfully defended the research before the panel of experts and professors. The research entitled "Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging" is actually the enhancement of PNC2 Messenger integrating AES 256 bit and Hidden in Plain Sight (HIPS) Encryption Algorithm (see enclosure). The research paper is initially accessible at http://www.warse.org/IJATCSE/static/pdf/file/ijatcse35912sl2020.pdf pending the indexing of SCOPUS Journal. . II. Timeline of Activities Leading to the Publication of Research: Date Activities November 2018 Final Oral Defense of Thesis at TUP with CPT JOHANNA V PORTILLO PN(M) as member of the Panel March 2019 Approval of Thesis and Subsequent Printing August 2019 Presentation of Thesis during the research forum at TUP January 2020 Presentation of research during the IRCCEEE 2020 Conference March 2020 Approval of the revised research paper by the IRCCEEE May 2020 Pu

title: AAR Publication of Research .docx
author: System
content: HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Staff Officer, Cyber Warfare Management Branch To: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Via: Deputy AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: International Publication of Mr. Maligro's Research Paper Entitled Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging Ref: Letter invitation from the organizer of IRCCEEE Encl: Volume 9, No.1.2, 2020 of International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering I. General: The International Research Conference in Computing, Engineering, Education and Education Technology (IRCCEEE) is an International forum of academicians, professionals, researchers, and scientists with research involving engineering, education, and computing technology. This year the event was held at Legazpi City, Philippines. Mr. Maligro's research is fortunate to be chosen as one of the three (3) thesis and dissertations of Technological University of the Philippines (TUP) to be presented and showcased during this event. Due to conflict schedule, Mr Maligro was represented by his adviser Dr. Gemma Belga during this conference and successfully defended the research before the panel of experts and professors. The research entitled "Hybrid Encryption Algorithm towards Secured Instant Messaging" is actually the enhancement of PNC2 Messenger - the messaging application widely used by the Philippine Navy - integrating AES 256 bit and Hidden in Plain Sight (HIPS) Encryption Algorithm (see enclosure). The research paper is initially accessible at http://www.warse.org/IJATCSE/static/pdf/file/ijatcse35912sl2020.pdf pending the indexing of Scopus Journal - the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature. . II. Timeline of Activities Leading to the Publication of Research: Date Activities November 2018 Final Oral Defense of Thesis at TUP with CPT JOHANNA V PORTILLO PN(M) as member of the Panel

title: MFR AFP Implan.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/AFP Closed Net/MFR AFP Implan.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPNAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 29 January 2018 MEMORANDUM for- AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: After conference report on Enhancement of AFP Network Connectivity, Security and Administration The Chief of Cyber Warfare Branch, ON6 together with Mr. Nelson G. Maligro, attended the coordinating conference of OJ6 ICOW the submission of IMPLAN and timelines for the establishment of closed network and designation of Net Control Officer in relation to the enhancement of AFP network. The representative of CEISSAFP and representatives of Major Services 6 presented their IMPLAN and Timelines to J6, RADM FRANCISCO. The following are significant action items of individual IMPLAN: Philippine Navy CEISSAFP Separate CAGNET and establish AFPNet Closed Network; Detach commercial internet from the AFPNet; Determine and Isolate AFP information systems needing online updates; Retain IP Radio for redundancy; Release memo for the removal of Internet by 15 Feb 2018; and Designate Net Admin for Active Directory. Philippine Air Force Already included in the budget programming the IP-VPN, Fiber Optics, and IP-VSAT projects that will connect all PAF Commels; Connect TDL terminals to the VPN; Deployment of AD and other automated tools; and Develop cyber defense and creation of PAF CERT. Philippine Army Inclusion in the budget the PA WAN enhancement and HPA Wifi connectivity; The HPA Wifi Project will separate the internet from the PANET; and Establish closed PANET; . Following these presentations, J6 gave his notable remarks. They are as follows: Interpret all of these projects from the perspective and needs of Unified Commands and the GHQ; There is a need to reorient CEIS units for setting up a closed network; Update the presentation to reflect the End State, the Primary Objectives that will meet the end state, and the broken-down SMART objectives in support

author: System
content: Navigating the Shift from Opportunistic to Targeted Ransomware Attacks Christopher Elisan, Director of Intelligence at Flashpoint @TOPHS Introduction Opportunistic TTPs Targeted TTPs Why The Shift? Notable Differences Likely Targets Mitigation Questions? From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 2 Agenda About the speaker Christopher Elisan, Director of Intelligence at Flashpoint, is a seasoned Reverse Engineer, Malware Researcher and published Author. He speaks at conferences around the world and frequently provides expert opinion about malware, botnets and advanced persistent threats for leading industry and mainstream publications. Elisan's published works include Hacking Exposed: Malware and Rootkits, 2 ed. Elisan is also involved in Flashpoint's Threat Readiness & Response (TR2) subscription, which helps companies prepare for, as well as quickly assess and respond to a ransomware or cyber extortion attack. 3 Introduction From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks OPPORTUNISTIC TTPs From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 4 From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 5 GandCrab Ransom Note 6 GandCrab Desktop Wallpaper From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 7 GandCrab Payment Site 8 GandCrab Panel TARGETED TTPs From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 9 From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 10 Ryuk Builder From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 11 Ryuk Ransom Note From WannaCry to LockerGoga: Navigating the Shift from Targeted to Opportunistic Ransomware Attacks 12 Ryuk Process Killer From WannaCry

author: System
content: Z3r0 to H3r0 – Targeting Crown Jewels over the Internet Viral Maniar # whoami Over 7 years of experience in the field of Information Security Passionate about offensive and defensive security Working as a Principal Security Consultant at Threat Intelligence In my free time I develop security tools Presented at BlackHat USA in August 2019 (PowerShell-RAT) Outside of Infosec land – I like photography https://github.com/Viralmaniar https://twitter.com/maniarviral https://www.linkedin.com/in/viralmaniar/ https://viralmaniar.github.io/ Disclaimer Performing any hack attempts or tests without written permission from the owner of the computer system is illegal. If you recently suffered a breach and found techniques or tools illustrated in this presentation, this neither incriminates my involvement in any way, nor implies any connection between myself and the attackers. The tools and techniques remain universal and penetration testers and security consultants often uses them during engagements. Presentation Outline What is External Pentest? Infrastructure setup for attack Reconnaissance methods and OSINT techniques Common issues and misconfiguration in the external perimeter Gain internal access to the network Stay calm and quiet in the network and plant a backdoor Identify crown jewels Exfiltrate sensitive data Key takeaways MITRE ATT&CK Knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques Foundation for the development of specific threat models and methodologies Consists of 3 major matrices: PRE-ATT&CK ATT&CK MOBILE External Pentest Methodologies PRE-ATT&CK - Set of 15 different categories used by an attacker to plan an attack https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/pre/ OSINT Framework - OSINT framework focused on gathering information from free tools or resources. The intention is to help people find free OSINT resources https://osintframework.com/ ISTAR - Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance F2T2EA Model - Find, Fix, Track, Target, Engage and Assess

title: Standard Data Center Construction.pdf
author: System
content: WHITE PAPER The Three Principles of Data Center Infrastructure Design The Three Principles of Data Center Infrastructure Design Understand These Three Principles and You'll: Lower your total cost of ownership Support your future growth plans Reduce your risk of downtime Maximize performance Improve your ability to reconfigure Your data center is the most critical resource within your organization. As you know, it provides the means for all storage, management and dissemination of data, applications and communications for your business. When employees and customers are unable to access the servers, storage systems and networking devices that reside in the data center, your entire organization can shut down. Millions of dollars can be lost in a matter of minutes for businesses like banks, airlines, shipping facilities and online brokerages. Faced with these consequences, IT executives today must optimize their data centers, particularly the network infrastructure. When you consider that 70 percent of network downtime can be attributed to physical layer problems, specifically cabling faults, it's paramount that more consideration be given to infrastructure design. Within this white paper we introduce three principles, that when executed properly, will help you gain significant benefits and savings throughout the life of your data center. Page The Three Principles of Data Center Design When you understand the three principles of data center design, you are able to: Lower your total cost of ownership Support your future growth plans Reduce your risk of downtime Maximize performance Improve your ability to reconfigure Principle 1: Space Savings Environmentally controlled real estate is expensive. The cost of building a data center is more than $1,000 per square foot in some cases (see Table 1). Data center racks and equipment can take up an enormous amount of real estate, and the future demand for more network connections, bandwidth and storage may require even more space

title: DarkNet AAR_Revision2_Nelson.docx
author: System
content: HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 To: Flag Officer in Command, Philippine Navy Subj: After Activity Report of DarkNet Workshop Ref: A) MISS DND Letter of Invitation to FOIC, PN dated 26 January 2018. J6 STL (undated), received 20 February 2018, Subj: DarkNet Workshop Tasking. Encl: A) Group Output Presentation B) Pictures I. General: The Management Information System Service (MISS), Department of National Defense (DND) spearheaded the workshop "Dealing with the DarkNet: Measures to Prevent Violent Extremism" last 27 February 2018 at Tejeros Hall, AFPCOC, Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City. The objectives of the activity are to discuss with the key national stakeholders the risks of the DarkNet, determine policy responses for the Philippines, and identify capacity-building needs of government agencies and partners. This activity is in cooperation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Information for All Programme (IFAP) and Education Sector. The PN provided Officer in Attendance (OIA) to Ms. Chafica Abou Khaled Haddad the Chairperson, UNESCO Information for All Programme Intergovernmental Council, the guest speaker and at the same time the moderator the workgroup Education and Youth. II. Schedule of Activities: Time Activities Remarks 0900H-0915H Opening Ceremony Proper Welcome Remarks SEC DELFIN A LORENZANA Secretary, DND 0915H-0930H Opening Remarks MS CHAFICA ABOU KHALED HADDAD Chairperson, UNESCO Information for All ProgrammeIntergovernmental Council 0930H-0940H Photo Opportunity 0940H-0955H Coffee Break AFPCOC Premises 0955H-1025H The Philippine Situation BGEN JESUS V. LOMEDA, JR., AFP (RET) Chief of the MISS and Cyber Division, DND 1025H-1055H DarkNet Overview, Challenges for Governments, Recruitment, Technical aspects MrWilliam Lippert Crimina

title: Welcome Remarks.docx
author: System
content: Welcome Remarks It is my honour and my pleasure to welcome you to________________. Back sometime in May of 2013, the government websites of the Philippines are being taken down by "Taiwanese" keyboard warriors following the taiwanese fishermen incident, serving as payback. The Philippines is now taking a step towards safeguarding its digital network or the cyberspace. The digital world is becoming more and more vulnerable. As much as great inventions and technologies empower us, these pose real threats and can lead to unprecedented damage. Inadequate response to these incidents may result to national crisis. Statistics are truly alarming. Each minute somewhere around the world a cyberattack is being performed. Literally this very second, someone's computer is being hacked, someone's personal records, financial information, or intellectual property is being stolen and sold on the black market. The Philippine Military is no exception to this. Everyday your Philippine Navy experiences numerous cyber-attacks in an attempt to penetrate our network and some get through by means of inadvertent downloads and USB insertion. Criminals are stepping up their game and data breaches are increasingly common and devastating. That is why we need to act together – Government agencies, Private Sectors, NGO, Academe, and even households with internet connections. With that, Thank You at Mabuhay po tayong lahat!

content: "The NAVY: Protecting the Seas, Securing our Future" DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (If any) File Number: N6B-0518- Subject: Availability of Funds to Support the CCTV Requirements of PN Bases TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS DATE: COMMENT NR:___ VIA: VCOM, PN LT BARRACA PN-6390 __________ N6 _________ ________DNRMO_______ ________DNMFO_______ SUMMARY: Reference: FOIC, PN verbal instruction on equipping all Naval Bases, stations, and, detachments with Closed Circuit Television (CCTV). In compliance with above-cited reference, this office directed NIC, MBGL, and Unit 6s and 2s to submit proposal on installing and enhancing the CCTV within their AOR. Thirteen (13) units submitted their POE, network diagram, and other relevant documents for this proposal (Encl B). In view of the foregoing, N6 recommends that the fund support for these requirements with the total amount of PhP21,883,276.24 be charged to 1st Semester CY2018 Residual Funds (Encl A). RECOMMENDATION: FOIC, PN approval on the fund request for CCTV requirements with an aggregated amount of TWENTY-ONE MILLION, EIGHT HUNDRED EIGHTY-THREE THOUSAND, TWO HUNDRED SEVENTY-SIX PESOS AND TWENTY-FOUR CENTAVOS (PhP21,883,276.24). The same shall be charged to 1st Semester CY2018 Residual Funds subject to SPBAC deliberation. KAGAON Encls: Program of Expenditure for the Requirements of CCTV for the Bases, Stations, and Detachments Consolidation of all CCTV requirements NAVY 2020: STRONG AND CREDIBLE Program of Expenditure for the Requirements for the Installation and Enhancement of CCTV L/I DESCRIPTION TOTAL COST (PhP) 1 NFW (NSAP, NSCC, Parola, Oyster Bay) 5,463,471.00 2 NFC (NBRR) 2,045,221.40 3 NFSL (Infanta, Capul, HNFSL) 1,656,980.00 4 NFNL (HNFNL, HNBCO, BOLINAO, CASIGURAN, BONUAN, SUAL, MSE) 4,170,035.00 5 NFEM 2,816,060.00 6 NFWM 2,241,580.00 7 NIC (NBHA, NSPL) 2,541,763.84 8 HQBN 116,800.00 9 IBBN 128,500.00 10 CSSB 47,700.00 11 MTMB 12,800.00 12 MBGL 262,315.00 13 MBDE (2MBDE, 3MBDE) 380,050.00 Total 21,883,276.2

title: Cyber IPB.docx
author: System
content: Scenario: The AFP opens a bid for its Internet and IP VPN connectivity as required by higher authorities; subsequently, MISIS-TEL Telephone Company, being the lowest bidder, won and was awarded the contract to provide the internet and IP VPN services for all AFP units including the PN. Some secured networks of the AFP, especially the VPN, are now passing through the MISIS-TEL routing nodes. Because of these, threat on cyber security is perceived to be eminent. Operational security is compromised and personal/ family safeties of AFP members are put to risk. Condition: The AFP secured network or the VPN is running through MISIS-TEL Telco. National ID System is contracted to a Chinese Firm Metro Manila CCTV project is contracted to a Chinese Firm Requirement (Action of the Attacker): Recon and scan the AFP network through the MISIS-TEL VPN control terminal. Chong Go is a penetration agent of CH government disguising an employee of MISIS-Tel Company. Chong is in charge of maintaining routers and network switches of IP VPN including the subnet of the AFP. He reckoned and gathered information about the AFP; and later learned the allocated IP address or network address of the AFP. Chong, being inside the IP VPN of all MISIS-TEL subscribers, scanned the network or subnet owned by the AFP using the NMAP. The NMAP is an effective tool for scanning and identifying all devices connected in the network. It generates a graphical layout of the entire network including basic information of the devices (e.g. OS version, ports opened) upon completion of the scan. The attacker now is able to map out the entire network of the AFP including all connected computers and servers. Intrude into J3 and N3 domains and terminals. Chong narrows down to J3 and N3 computer terminals using various info gathering tools such as nslookup, traceroute, and Sparta (banner grabber). The attacker selects a specific computer terminal from the shortlisted targets and conducts a Man-in the Middle (MITM) attac

content: General Function AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 The AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6, assists and advices the Flag Officer In Command, PN on matters pertaining to C4ISR Systems support for PN Command and Control (C2), maritime situational awareness, information assurance, cyberspace operations, and electronic warfare. Proposed Modifications and Justification for N6 Civilian Plantilla Staffing Proposed Staffing Modification Action Scrap and Build – creation of new units and/or positions corresponding to the equivalent cost of structures or staffing reduced or abolished (DBM National Budget Circular no. 485 dated March 13 2003) Reclassification of positions – may be applied only when there has ben a substantial change in the regular duties and responsibilities of the incumbent of the position and which may result in a change in any or all of the following: position title, level, and salary grade. (DBM National Circular no. 2005-5 stated August 16 2005) Retitling Proposed Positions for Scrap and Build ACTUAL PLANTILLA POSITIONS (TO SCRAP) PROPOSED NEW POSITIONS (TO BUILD) Job Title SG Annual Salary Job Title SG Annual Salary Computer Maintenance Technologist II (1) SG – 11 242,148.00 Information technology Officer II (1) SG-20 564,444.00 Administrative Officer IV (1) SG 15 348,120.00 Computer Programmer I SG-15 348,120.00 TOTAL 3 590,268.00 TOTAL 2 912,564.00 JUSTIFICATION: The proposed positions recommended to be scrapped are vacant. The re-organization of ON6 which created new branches entailed the need to create additional civilian positions that are needed to perform tasks in lieu of the functions of the respective branch which these positions will be assigned. Further, the scrap and build proposal will incur an excess variance of 322, 296 on personnel services cost. title: scenario for cyber ipb.docx
author: System
content: SCENARIO 1: MISLATEL AS 3rd TELCO PLAYER RP has approved the MISLATEL as the provisional 3rd Telco to provide internet and IP VPN services in order to break the duopoly of PLDT and GLOBE Telecoms. Part of MISLATEL is China Telecoms, a state-sponsored corporation. MISLATEL offers the lowest bid in providing internet and IP VPN services to some government agencies, to include the Philippine Navy. At present, the current internet and IP VPN services provided by PLDT is less viable in terms of technological and financial concerns that led to the termination of contract of PLDT. By 2020, the PN open the bidding to the 3 Telco and subsequently, MISLATEL was awarded the contract to provide the internet and IP VPN services. Some secured networks of the PN, especially the VPN, are passing through the MISLATEL routing nodes that uses China software. Because of these, threat on cyber security is perceived to be eminent. Assumption: MISLATEL VPN AFP Cyber breach using Huawei Tech National ID System CCTV Scenario: Due to the implementation of the National ID system, all crucial information to include the biometrics and iris scan of all PN personnel were registered already. Also, the CCTV project of DILG pushed-through and the full implementation covers the integration of the entire system of CCTV within Metro Manila where the seat of the government lies. Subsequently, MISLATEL were indicted that there were solid evidences proving the allegations that billions of data were being sent from every China ICT equipment routing nodes back to Beijing, China. Intelligence report, also, states that a group of CH Hackers claimed to be working with Chinese government facilitating the volumes of data traffic to Beijing. A certain LT DUGUMON PN, while driving his car along EDSA while enroute to Camp Aguinaldo, was monitored and scanned though the CCTV at the intersection of Ayala-EDSA. Subject Officer was on official business, wearing his uniform and showing his nameplate, to attend conferen

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0b.xlsx
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. title: CONFIG MGMT-16 Aug 2019.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Config Mgmt/Config Management Policy/CONFIG MGMT-16 Aug 2019.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D (Page 1 of 1) R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R Philippine Navy Configuration Management Policy PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to Cybersecurity, Network, Management Information System and Command and Control, Computer, Communications Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) systems. It shall provide standards for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration; and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. Furthermore, this policy shall ensure secured configuration of C4ISR system that warrant support to managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN C4ISR Systems that include but not limited to software/applications, operating system, Cybersecurity systems, and software-enabled C3 system and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components

title: Annex A CRA Process.doc
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/CRA_OJ6/AFP CRA/Annex A CRA Process.doc
author: System
content: ANNEX A to SOP Nr. _______ AFP dated ________ CRA PROCESS PHASES/STEPS Ucs/AFPWSSUs/JPS CEISSAFP MAJOR SERVICES AFPCyG I. Iinitial Assessment         A. Planning         Determine and define the system and procedures for evaluation. Identify and classify critical cyber assets. Determine Teams to conduct the Evaluation      B. Conduct         Perform cyber risk assessment. Assess risks to system information and assets. Select evident security controls. Monitor and assess the effectiveness of controls.     C. Report Generation         Generate comprehensive report on risk assessment and recommendation       D. Submission         Submit report for consolidation       II. Consolidation         Consolidate the submitted report from CEISSAFP and Major Services respective Cyber 6s      III. Overall Assessment         Define the Major Services, Program IV and entire AFP cybersecurity posture respectively      Provide support for active executive sponsorship and adequate resources / funding for the cyber security program.  IV. Programming         Define the program/procurement priorities in cyber related projects        V. Implementation         Realization of cyber related programs and projects to improved the cybersecurity posture of the AFP     

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0_MS.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

Refs: a. FOIC, PN Approved DF dated 26 May 2018, Subj: Repair and Enhancement of PN IPMS Database System b. HPN LOI Nr 042-18 dated 12 June 2018 (Implementation of Civilian Employee Biometric Information System) 2. Ref _a_ pertains to the approval of FOIC, PN on the adoption of the PN Civilian Employees Biometric System (CEBIS) and allocation of funds essential for the implementation of the program. The CEBIS program is in accordance with the requirements of Higher Headquarters for the inclusion of a module in IPMS that can provide a database of PN civilian employees for the purpose of personnel management. 3. Ref 9 pertains to the PN Letter of Instructions issued primarily to ensure the successful implementation of PN Civilian Employee Biometric Information System (CEBIS). 4. title: AuditScripts.xlsx
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function. These functions were defined by NIST in the EOF and act as control characteristics.",,,,,,,,,,,, Sensor or Baseline,,,This is the type of technical system or basel

title: CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY-Edited-16Jan2019.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R Philippine Navy Command and Control, Computers, Communication, and Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) Systems Configuration Management Policy PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN C4ISR Systems. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure C4ISR Systems for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN C4ISR Systems. C4ISR Systems include but not limited to software/applications, operating system, Cybersecurity systems, and software-enabled C3 system and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. C4ISR Systems – pertain

title: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/CRA_OJ6/P3BD_10.1.6.153/CRA-PRESENTATION CONSOLIDATION/ISG-CEIS/AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
author: System
content: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) 04 – 08 March 2019 CRA Parameters Capability Gap Recommendation Continuous Vulnerability Management Utilize an up-to-date SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool to automatically scan all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis to identify all potential vulnerabilities on the organization's systems. Lack of SCAP-compliant vulnerability assessment or scanning tool to scan all systems and network. Run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis; inform system administrators of most critical vulnerabilities Implement and enforce SCAP Based Vulnerability Management System Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning with agents running locally on each system or with remote scanners that are configured with elevated rights on the system being tested. No authenticated credential authentication for vulnerability assessment. Perform vulnerability scanning on each end system in authenticated mode with agents or remote scanners Tenable can provide authenticated vulnerability scanning on all networked end systems using software agents or remote scanners. Use a dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability scans, which should not be used for any other administrative activities and should be tied to specific machines at specific IP addresses. No dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability assessment. Monitor logs associated with any scanning activity and associated administrator accounts to ensure legitimate scans Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that the operating systems are running the most recent security updates provided by the software vendor. No centralized update deployment service and/or patch management system tools. Deploy automated patch management tools and software update tools for OS and software; apply patches to all systems Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that third-party software on al

title: AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Manual-Assessment-Tool-v7.0.xls
author: System
content: Critical Security Controls Initial Assessment Tool (v7.0b),,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Instructions - Read me first.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, "The purpose for this tool is to provide organizations with a simple tool for performing an initial assessment of their information assurance maturity level based on the controls defined by the Critical Security Controls and the Council on Cybersecurity. Any questions about how this tool works or suggestions can be directed to info@auditscripts.com. In order to use this tool, the assessor must only complete the answers to the drop down menu questions lists on the pages labeled CSC #1 - CSC #20. By choosing a drop down choice for each critical control, the assessment tool will automatically generate scores and maturity level based on the answers to each question. Based on the answers to each question, the dashboard worksheet will automatically populate with the overall maturity level scores for the organization as a whole. These scores can therefore be used to measure the organization's progress and what percentage of the Critical Security Controls they are currently following. Ideally in the long term organizations would deploy tools that would automate the collection of this information, but in the meanwhile, this tool can be used to help start the process of manually assessing the organization's maturity level.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Field Definitions,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, ID,,,This is the ID number of the specific critical security control sub-control reference as included in the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, Critical Security Control Detail,,,This is the detail behind each specific sub-control as defined by the Critical Security Controls documentation.,,,,,,,,,,,, EOF Function,,,"This standards for ""Executive Order Framework (EOF)"" function.
