title: 05-2011.pdf
author: System
content: RESOLUTION NO. 05-2011 _______________________________________________________________________________________________________ APPROVING THE PRE-SELECTION PROCEDURE IN THE CONDUCT OF LIMITED SOURCE BIDDING UNDER SECTION 49 OF REPUBLIC ACT 9184 AND ITS REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS Section 48 of Republic Act 9184 (RA 9184) provides that Limited Source Bidding, otherwise known as Selective Source Bidding, is a method of procurement that involves direct invitation to bid by the procuring entity from a set of pre-selected suppliers or consultants with known experience and proven capability relative to the requirements of a particular contract. Under Section 49 of RA 9184 and its revised Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR), it may be employed under any of the following conditions: (1) procurement of highly specialized types of goods (e.g., sophisticated defense equipment, complex air navigation systems, coal) and consulting services where only a few suppliers or consultants are known to be available, such that resorting to the public bidding method will not likely result in any additional suppliers or consultants participating in the bidding; or (2) procurement of major plant components where it is deemed advantageous to limit the bidding to known qualified bidders in order to maintain uniform quality and performance of the plant as a whole. Section 49.2 of the IRR of RA 9184 provides that the pre-selected suppliers or consultants shall be those appearing in a list maintained by the relevant government authority that has expertise in the type of procurement concerned. The list of pre-selected suppliers or consultants shall be updated periodically. A copy of the list shall be submitted to, and maintained updated with, the Government Procurement Policy Board (GPPB). In addition, the IRR under Section 49.3 thereof, prescribes that pre-selection shall be based upon the capability and resources of the bidders to perform the contract taking into account their

title: Eclipse IDE.pdf
author: System
content: Explore the English language on a new scale using AI-powered English language navigator. Setting up Eclipse: Java's popular IDE Summary This tutorial will help you to install JDK (Java Development Kit), setup Eclipse IDE (Integrated development environment) and get started with Java. Keywords: IDE, Eclipse, JDK Downloads First of all you have to download some stuff from the Internet: 1. Download the latest JDK from: http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp 2. Download Eclipse IDE for Java Developers from: http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ Installation Run JDK installer and follow instructions. After you installed the JDK, unpack eclipse archive somewhere on a disk and run eclipse.exe. Get started with Eclipse Select a workspace If you did previous steps right, you should see the following: You are asked to select a workspace directory, where all of your further projects would be stored. You may leave the default folder or choose another one. It's important to remember this path for future. After you choose the workspace location, press ok and wait a little, while Eclipse is loading. Creating a project Choose File New Java Project from menu. In the "New Java Project" window type "HelloWorld" in the project name edit box. Then press Finish button. Click with the right button on the HelloWorld project in package explorer. Choose New Class: Name it "HelloWorld" and set checker box to create main method stub. Then press Finish button. Type: System.out.println("Hello World! I am new to Java."); in the main method's body and run HelloWorld with run button: You will see the result in a console window: Your first Java application is ready! We will discuss it in detail in the next article. title: Annex B CRA Parameters.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/AFP CRA/Annex B CRA Parameters.docx
author: System
content: ANNEX "B" to SOP Nr ____AFP Dated__________ Cybersecurity Risk Assessment (CRA) Template CRA Parameters Description Available Capability Gap Recommendation Inventory of Authorized and Unauthorized Devices Reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems: Use active monitoring and configuration management to maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. No inventory of authorized and unauthorized devices Program for Asset Management System such as MS Active Directory Inventory of Authorized and Unauthorized Software Identify vulnerable or malicious software to mitigate or root out attacks: Devise a list of authorized software for each type of system, and deploy tools to track software installed (including type, version, and patches) and monitor for unauthorized or unnecessary software. Secure Configurations for Hardware and Software on Mobile Devices, Laptop, Workstations, and Servers Prevent attackers from exploiting services and settings that allow easy access through networks and browsers: Build a secure image that is used for all new systems deployed to the enterprises, host these standard images on secure storage servers, regularly validate and update these configurations, and track system images in a configuration management system. Continuous Vulnerability Assessment and Remediation Proactively identify and repair software vulnerabilities reported by security researchers or vendors: Regularly run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems and quickly remediate any vulnerabilities, which critical problems fixed within 48 hours. Malware Defenses Block malicious code from tampering with system settings or contents, capturing sensitive data, or spreading: Use automated anti-virus and anti-spyware to continuously monitor and protect workstations, servers, and mobile devices. Automatically update such anti-malware

title: Config Mgmt_ver 1.docx
author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER………………………………… PN INFOSTRUCTURE CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES 1. PURPOSE: The purpose of this SOP is to provide guidance to Philippine Navy units/offices to ensure compliances with minimally acceptable system configuration requirements as determined by the organization within the information security standards and best practices. Furthermore, this SOP shall provide guidance to PN units/offices to develop fixed reference in the development cycle or an agreed-upon specification of information systems. PN shall develop baseline configuration that shall serve as a documented basis for defining incremental change and encompasses many different aspects of the information systems. The baseline configuration shall be the center of the effective configuration management program whose purpose is to give definite basis for change control in a project by controlling various configuration items like work, features, system performance and other measurable configuration, which is basically defined specification that is considered the baseline for all changes that follow. In addition, this SOP is important process for establishing and maintaining secure information system configurations and provides important support for managing security risks in information systems. This SOP supports the policy and guidelines of the PN Cybersecurity Policy and adopted the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems–Requirements. 2. SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY: This SOP applies to all personnel and third party stakeholders, who provide, administer, maintain, and operate PN information system services

title: CONFIG MGMT-13 Aug 2019.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Config Mgmt/Config Management Policy/CONFIG MGMT-13 Aug 2019.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D (Page 1 of 1) R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R Philippine Navy Configuration Management Policy PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to Cybersecurity, Network, Management Information System and Command and Control, Computer, Communications Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) systems. It shall provide standards for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration; and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. Furthermore, this policy shall ensure secured configuration of C4ISR system that warrant support to managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN C4ISR Systems that include but not limited to software/applications, operating system, Cybersecurity systems, and software-enabled C3 system and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components

title: MFR-Conceptus.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPNAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 01 December 2017 MEMORANDUM for- AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: After conference report on the IELTA Conceptus System The Chief of Cyber Warfare Branch, ON6 together with CDR SALVADOR SAMBALILO PN, LCDR JAMES MINGUILLAN PN, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro attended the product presentation of IELTA on 211300H November 2017 at the Manila Peninsula Hotel, Makati City. The proponent presented the Conceptus System, a social media and web intelligence platform. The following are salient features of the system: Passive intelligence collection from social media and the web through creation of a seemingly legit social media personality (Avatar) that will blend in with the group or person of interest (POI); Crawls social media, deep web, darknet and bitcoin websites to collect valuable intelligence information about the POI; Generates actionable recommendation to grow and improve the avatar's reputation; and Correlates information from bitcoin transactions to provide further insights into the identity of the POI. While similar products, like the Knowlesys, have already been introduced to the PN, this branch is unable to determine the value and cost-benefit analysis of the system since this is a tool for Intelligence gathering. As such, we shall forward its brochure and other pertinent information to the TIG, NISF for their evaluation. For information of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems. RODEL G BARRACA LT PN Chief, Cyber Warfare Branch 3-Encls: Conference Notice Attendance Brochure

In addition, it provides specific guidance for the organization on creating and maintaining baseline configuration of information system and industrial control system and shall employ configuration change control processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. Moreover, this policy is an important process for establishing and maintaining secure information system configurations and provides important support for managing security risks in information systems. This policy adopted the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to: All personnel who administer, maintain, and operate PN information system's services and components; All units that provide, operate, and maintain information systems; Third Party Stakeholders that provide, operate, and maintain PN information systems; and, PN C4ISTAR Systems' sub-systems that are composed of information systems and information system components/services. title: 05 Overview of PFSense.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/05 Overview of PFSense.pdf
author: System
content: pfSense Tutorial BSDCan 2008 From zero to hero with pfSense May 13, 2008 Chris Buechler <cmb@bsdperimeter.com> Scott Ullrich <sullrich@bsdperimeter.com> History of pfSense Started as a work project 13 years ago when we needed a internal firewall Originally Linux, switched to FreeBSD 2.2 Evolution of this path shrunk the firewall down to a Soekris size Moatware was started Met Chris Buechler during this time Sell a number of products Sales guy moves to Florida Moatware fails Chris and myself debate starting over fresh pfSense is forked from m0n0wall roughly 4 years ago Still going strong today pfSense Overview Customized FreeBSD distribution tailored for use as a firewall and router. pfSense has many base features and can be extended with the package system including one touch installations of popular 3rd party packages such as SpamD (spam filter) and Squid (web caching). Includes many features found in commercial products such as Cisco PIX, Sonicwall, Watchguard, etc. Many support avenues available, mailing lists, forum and commercial support. Has the best price on the planet.... Free! pfSense Platforms Live CD Full Install Embedded Developers pfSense Stable Versions 1.0 - October 4, 2006 * 1.0.1 - October 20, 2006 * 1.2 - RELENG_1_2 - February 25, 2008 Downloaded more than 500,000 times to date * Not branched in CVS pfSense Development Versions Current Development Versions 1.3-ALPHA - RELENG_1 2.0-ALPHA-ALPHA-ALPHA - HEAD Snapshots are built every two hours available at http://snapshots.pfsense.org Bonus for attendees - 1.3 snapshots available Minimum Hardware Requirements CPU - 100 MHz (500+ MHz for best experience) RAM - 128 MB (256 MB or more is encouraged) Platform Specific Live CD CD-ROM drive (currently USB CD-ROM devices are not supported) USB flash drive or floppy drive to store configuration Full Installation CD-ROM for initial installation 1 GB hard drive Embedded 128 MB CF serial port for console null modem cable Popular hardware NICs - Intel Pro/100 and

author: System
content: GENERAL HEADQUARTERS ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff for Communications, Electronics and Information Systems, J6 Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City OTAG/OJ6 STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER ________ AFP CYBER RISK ASSESSMENT REFERENCES: AFP Cyber Strategy; 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Secuirty (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the AFP cyber defense capability, there is a need to first determine the current AFP cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among AFP units. However, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should, therefore, be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats.The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOPprescribes general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to ensure cybersecurity AFP-wide. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all AFP Staff Officer for CEIS and AFP CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: a. Cyber – is a prefix for a term or the modifier of a compound word, rather than a stand-alone word which usually relates to electronic data processing, information technology, electronic communications or information and computer systems. b. Cyber defense – is cyberspace operations intended to defend In

author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ PHILIPPINE NAVY CYBER RISK ASSESSMENT REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment; AFP Cyber Strategy; 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the PN cyber defense capability, there is a need to first determine the current PN cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among PN units. Thus, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats. The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to provide adequate cybersecurity controls for the PN. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential info

AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the PN cyber defense capability, there is a need to first determine the current PN cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among PN units. Thus, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats. The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to provide adequate cybersecurity controls for the PN. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software

title: Configuraton Mgmt 09Oct2018.docx
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D R E S T R I C T E D (Page 6 of 19) PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION SYSTEM CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN information systems (IS) and its components. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure IS for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN information systems and its components. PN IS includes but not limited to application software, operating system, and software-enabled C2 systems and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. Configuration Change Control - The systematic proposal, justificatio

title: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CRA/CRA_OJ6/CRA-PRESENTATION CONSOLIDATION/ISG-CEIS/AFP Cyber Risk Assessment Template.docx
author: System
content: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) 04 – 08 March 2019 CRA Parameters Capability Gap Recommendation Continuous Vulnerability Management Utilize an up-to-date SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool to automatically scan all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis to identify all potential vulnerabilities on the organization's systems. Lack of SCAP-compliant vulnerability assessment or scanning tool to scan all systems and network. Run automated vulnerability scanning tools against all systems on the network on a weekly or more frequent basis; inform system administrators of most critical vulnerabilities Implement and enforce SCAP Based Vulnerability Management System Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning with agents running locally on each system or with remote scanners that are configured with elevated rights on the system being tested. No authenticated credential authentication for vulnerability assessment. Perform vulnerability scanning on each end system in authenticated mode with agents or remote scanners Tenable can provide authenticated vulnerability scanning on all networked end systems using software agents or remote scanners. Use a dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability scans, which should not be used for any other administrative activities and should be tied to specific machines at specific IP addresses. No dedicated account for authenticated vulnerability assessment. Monitor logs associated with any scanning activity and associated administrator accounts to ensure legitimate scans Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that the operating systems are running the most recent security updates provided by the software vendor. No centralized update deployment service and/or patch management system tools. Deploy automated patch management tools and software update tools for OS and software; apply patches to all systems Deploy automated software update tools in order to ensure that third-party software on al

content: "The NAVY: Protecting the Seas, Securing our Future" DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (If any) File Number: N6B-0219- Subject: Availability of Funds to Support the Maintenance of Software Licenses TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS Date: Comment No:___ VIA: VCOM, PN LCDR BARRACA PN-6390 _________ N6 _________ ________DONFM_______ SUMMARY: Reference: CNICTC Letter to FOIC, PN (Attn: N6), Subject: Availability of Funds for the Procurement of Hardware and Software Requirements of the PN Units, Request for Updates on the Implementation of Software Licenses Conference Notice dated 27 Feb 2018 , Agenda: Procurement of Hardware and Software Above reference 1a pertains to the request of CNICTC for the procurement of computer hardware and software licenses in order to address the issue of unlicensed software as a result and findings of the Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing (VAPT) of the twenty two (22) PN units conducted during the AGI. Based on the assessment of the actual inventory and specifications of these computers, several desktops and laptops are obsolete and can no longer support the installation of the latest software specifically the Microsoft Windows 10 Pro operating system. Hence, the NICTC recommends the procurement of software licenses only to computers that meets the minimum requirements for Windows 10 and further recommends the replacement of the obsolete computers with desktops and laptops bundled with Windows 10 pro. Relatedly, the NICTC facilitated the procurement and installation of software licenses for some PN units through the previous fund releases (ref 1b). After assessment on the actual inventory of the remaining unlicensed computers (windows 10 compatible), the NICTC identifies the total number of required software licenses for the twenty two (22) PN units. Moreover, It was discussed during the conference (ref 1b) that only the software requirements shall be requested from the 2018 residual fund while the hardware shall be programmed f

title: LCDR JONATAS PN Assignment for Forensics.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/LCDR JONATAS PN Assignment for Forensics.pdf
author: System
content: CASE STUDY IN FORENSIC INVESTIGATION SUBMITTED BY: LCDR JOSEPH L JONATAS PN BCWOC 02-2018 Executive Summary CE Jack Daniels, who works in National Research and Technology Development Center is suspected of accessing and possessing digital content pertaining to frogs. Accessing, possessing, and distribution of digital content pertaining to frogs breaches both civil and criminal laws. Jack has also been accused by NRTDC of obtaining two highly confidential documents. One document encompasses the names, position, usernames and password of notable personnel within the company. The second company is a top secret technology invention report wherein Jack should not have had access to either of these documents. As a consultant who specialized in Digital Forensics investigation, I am tasked to examine an image of Jack's laptop which was seized with the appropriate warrants. An image of the hard disk was created using forensically sound practices. Only a logical acquisition was undertaken by the individual responsible for creating the forensic copy. The logical acquisition was undertaken in a forensically sound manner and the md5 value at the same time of acquisition was "a72a04e309dc8aa20345db1e2ba4cd61". To start the investigation, the examiner Samsung Ativ 7 Core i5 laptop to investigate the downloaded image of Jack Daniels hard disk through the use of the following applications; OSMount, OSForensics, Autopsy, Passware Password Recovery Kit Forensic and Truecrypt. With the use of OSForensics and Autopsy Tools, the examiner investigate, exploit and explore the recent activity made by Jack Daniel to the computer. Manually browsing and/or auto search was also conducted using both software to search any suspicious file specifically frogs that has been accessed by Jack Daniel to his laptop. After thorough search and analyzation, fifteen (15) frogs were located to different folder locations. Said files extensions were change intentionally by Jack Daniel to avoid easy detection a

title: CYBER WARFARE COURSE - Seatworks.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CW Course/CYBER WARFARE COURSE - Seatworks.docx
author: System
content: CYBER WARFARE COURSE – FIREWALL/IDS/SIEM Those who are absent for more than 6 meetings are required to submit all seat works from day 1 to day 12 Non-submission of seat works will mean INCOMPLETE for the course. Email your completed seat works to : csg.nictc@navy.mil.ph Cc: maligro.nelson7129ce@navy.mil.ph SEAT WORKS: Design a network diagram that exhibits preventative and detective security controls (use Microsoft Visio). Explain the following excerpt from best cybersecurity practices: "You cannot protect what you cannot see" Setup an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) – Security Onion Deliverables: Screenshot of Security Onion with your full name on it. Simulate the IDS ability to detect network probes or attacks using the NMAP/Zenmap. Deliverables: Screenshot of SGUIL that displays continues alerts triggered from the NMAP/Zenmap scan. Setup a firewall – PFSense Deliverables: Screenshot of PFSense FW with your name on it. Configure your FW to adopt the best FW practice - Block All and Permit Only Needed Services/protocols. Deliverables: Screenshot of PFSense showing the following egress filtering rules: Block all services/protocols. Allow only HTTP, HTTPS, DNS, and ICMP protocol.

PN IS includes but not limited to application software, operating system, and software-enabled C2 systems and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- North Korea Malware.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- North Korea Malware.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) New North Korean Malware and Phishing Attacks Sourced from: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/us-govt-exposes-new-north-korean-malware-phishing-attacks/ The US government today released information on three new malware variants used in malicious cyber activity campaigns by a North Korean government-backed hacker group tracked as HIDDEN COBRA. The new malware is being used "for phishing and remote access by #DPRK cyber actors to conduct illegal activity, steal funds & evade sanctions" according to the information published by Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), and the Department of Defense (DoD). U.S. Cyber Command has also uploaded five samples of the newly discovered malware variants onto the VirusTotal malware aggregation repository. Besides the malware samples shared by the U.S. Cyber Command, CISA has also published detailed malware analysis reports (MARs) on its website containing indicators of compromise (IOCs) and YARA rules for each of the detected samples. The cybersecurity agency also provides mitigation measures in the form of Snort rules, as well as recommendations for system owners and administrators to strengthen the security posture of their organization's systems. The MARs are issued to help network defenders detect and reduce exposure to HIDDEN COBRA malicious cyber activity as the United States government cybersecurity agencies refer to North Korean government malicious activity. Three new North Korean malicious tools The first of the new malware variants, COPPERHEDGE, is described as a Remote Access Tool (RAT) "used by advanced persistent threat (APT) cyber actors in the targeting of cryptocurrency exchanges and related entities." This RAT is known for its capabil

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 4 -GrandCrab Ransomware.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 4 -GrandCrab Ransomware.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 03 Beware of Spam Email with GandCrab Ransomware Security Source: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ A new malware spam (malspam) campaign pretending to be the current emergency exit map for the recipient's building is being used to install the GandCrab Ransomware. These spam emails contain malicious Word documents that download and install the infection from a remote computer. According to Myonlinesecurity.co.uk, who discovered this campaign, a server that was previously distributing the Ursnif banking Trojan has now started pushing GandCrab Ransomware v5.1. BleepingComputer decided to take a look at the spam emails and the files being distributed so that you can see how this campaign works. As previously stated, this latest malspam campaign is pretending to be updated emergency exit maps for the recipient's building. These emails state that they are coming from Rosie L. Ashton and have a subject of "Up to datе еmеrgеnсy еxit map". Attached to these spam emails is a Word document titled Emergencyexitmap.doc as shown below. If the attachment is opened, the user will simply see a document with the text "Emergency exit map" and a prompt to enable content. If the user clicks on the Enable Content button, the Word macros will execute a PowerShell script that downloads and installs the GandCrab v5.1 Ransomware onto the computer. When defobfuscated, you can see that the macros download a file called putty.exe from http://cameraista.com/olalala/putty.exe and save it to C:\Windows\temp\putty.exe. The putty.exe is then executed. The putty.exe executable is GandCrab 5.1 and will begin to encrypt the files on your computer. Like earlier variants, GandCrab continues to encrypt files and then append a random extension to their file name. While

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 -FormJacking.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 06 Ransomware Out, Formjacking In as Primary Attack Vectors Source: https://www.symantec.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/ Symantec has seen a major uptick in formjacking attacks recently, with publicly reported attacks on the websites of companies including Ticketmaster, British Airways, Feedify, and Newegg by a group called Magecart being the most notable examples. Formjacking is a term we use to describe the use of malicious JavaScript code to steal credit card details and other information from payment forms on the checkout web pages of e-commerce sites. Formjacking is not a new technique, but recent campaigns are interesting as they are large, sophisticated, and have increased dramatically since mid-August 2018. . How does formjacking work? When a customer of an e-commerce site clicks "submit" or its equivalent after entering their details into a website's payment form, malicious JavaScript code that has been injected there by the cyber criminals collects all entered information, such as payment card details and the user's name and address. This information is then sent to the attacker's servers. Attackers can then use this information to perform payment card fraud or sell these details to other criminals on the dark web. How big is this campaign? This is a significant and sustained campaign, with activity increasing substantially in the week of September 13 to 20. According to Symantec telemetry, since August 13 we have blocked 248,000 attempts at formjacking—almost a quarter of a million instances. However, more than one third of those blocks (36 percent) occurred from September 13 to 20, indicating that this activity is increasing. What types of businesses are these attacks targeting? As we can see from the publicly reported attacks, Mag

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 -MITM.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 0 Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attack and How to Prevent Them Source: https://www.csoonline.com/article/3340117/cyberwarfare A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack is when an attacker intercepts communications between two parties either to secretly eavesdrop or modify traffic traveling between the two. Attackers might use MitM attacks to steal login credentials or personal information, spy on the victim, or sabotage communications or corrupt data. "MITM attacks are a tactical means to an end," says Zeki Turedi, technology strategist, EMEA at CrowdStrike. "The aim could be spying on individuals or groups to redirecting efforts, funds, resources, or attention." Though MitM can be protected against with encryption, successful attackers will either reroute traffic to phishing sites designed to look legitimate or simply pass on traffic to its intended destination once harvested or recorded, meaning detection of such attacks is incredibly difficult. How man-in-the-middle attacks work? MitM attacks consist of sitting between the connection of two parties and either observing or manipulating traffic. This could be through interfering with legitimate networks or creating fake networks that the attacker controls. Compromised traffic is then stripped of any encryption in order to steal, change or reroute that traffic to the attacker's destination of choice (such as a phishing log-in site). Because attackers may be silently observing or re-encrypting intercepted traffic to its intended source once recorded or edited, it can be a difficult attack to spot. "These types of attacks can be for espionage or financial gain, or to just be disruptive," says Turedi. "The damage caused can range from small to huge, depending on the attacker's goals and ability to cause misc

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 8 - Summer Cyber Safety Tips.docx

author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) US Government Agencies Have Banned Tik Tok Application By: https://www.businessinsider.com/us-government-agencies-have-banned-tiktok-app-2020-2 The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) became the latest federal agency to ban short-form video app TikTok, which is owned by Chinese company ByteDance. The video platform has been criticized for censoring content that might offend governments in markets where it operates. In September 2019, The Guardian saw internal documents that instructed moderators to censor content that could anger the Chinese government, including mentions of Tiananmen Square or Tibetan Independence. In a statement, TikTok said that these policies were no longer in use as of May. In November, the US Senate held a hearing on technology and data security and invited representatives from major technology companies, including TikTok. TikTok declined to send a representative. Zhu said he planned to meet with lawmakers about their concerns over TikTok but then canceled the meetings. The lawmakers argued that because TikTok's parent company ByteDance is based in China, TikTok could be forced "to support and cooperate with intelligence work controlled by the Chinese Communist Party." The senators added in their October letter to the acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire that "there is no legal mechanism for Chinese companies to appeal if they disagree with a request." TikTok responded with a statement, saying that it stores all US user data in the United States and backs it up in Singapore. The TikTok refusal "only underscores Senator Cotton's concerns that the company is beholden to the Chinese Communist Party and will not secure the rights and privacy of its American users," the Arkansas Republican's office said in a state

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- SIM Jacking.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- SIM Jacking.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) Protect Yourself from SIM Take-over By: https://www.facebook.com/SmartCommunities/posts/2519963494998967 A SIM take-over is when somebody tries to transfer your SIM's mobile number to another SIM through social engineering techniques. It is like a virtual version of budol-budol and is also known as "SIM-jacking", or "SIM-hijacking". How is it done? Through voice calls or SMS, cyber criminals pretend to be a Telecom representative (i.e Smart Communication or Globe Telecom) and will ask you to send a text message and receive a code from the telecom provide. On a Smart SIM, you will be asked to send GET PIN to 7927; and for Globe SIM you will be asked to send UPGRADE to 8080. You will then receive an upgrade code or One Time Password (OTP) number. These codes are intended to transfer the phone number of your current SIM to the new SIM upon purchase of "Upgrade SIM". The Globe and Smart is providing this feature in order for subscribers to upgrade to LTE – a new wireless broadband standard for faster Internet connection - while retaining your current phone number. The cyber criminals will then ask for these codes or OTP numbers which they will use to activate a new SIM card in their possession. Once the key have activated the new SIM card, your current SIM will be deactivated. If you are compromised, all text messages (SMS) and calls that are supposed to be received by your number will be received by the cyber criminal. They can then use this data to hack your banking, email, and other online accounts. What to do? If you received similar messages report it by calling *888 to Smart subscribers or any Globe or Smart hotline numbers. Remember; never give any sensitive information to strangers. Smart and Globe representatives will never ask for your OTP number or upg

author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ INVENTORY AND CONTROL OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems, there is a need to use active monitoring, manage configuration and maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution. Maintaining inventories for hardware and software will identify vulnerable systems, detect malicious software, mitigate unpatched software, and root out attacks. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units for the inventory of Information Technology (IT) hardware and software SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cyber – is a prefix for a term or the modifier of a compound word, rather than a stand-alone word which usually relates to electronic data processing, information technology, electronic communications or information and compu

PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to establish a standard for the administration of user accounts that facilitate access PN information systems. An account, at minimum, consists of a user ID and a password; supplying account information will usually grant access to some set of services and resources. This policy establishes standards for issuing accounts, creating password values, and managing accounts. SCOPE: This SOP is applicable to units 6's and CEIS units for the management of user accounts or access to shared information or network devices. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cybersecurity -deliberate synergy of technologies, processes, and practices to protect information and the networks, computer systems and appliances, and programs used to collect, process, store, and transport that information from attack, damage and unauthorized access. Cybersecurity Posture – refers to the overall cybersecurity strength of an PN. It expresses the relative security of the IT estate and its vulnerability to outside threats. Risk Assessment – is a process of identifying, estimating, and prioritizing risks of PNal assets and operations. It involves evaluating hazards, and developing plans to remove or minimize the level of ris

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- Eventbot .docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- Eventbot .docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) A New Android Malware That Steals Banking Passwords and Two-Factor Codes By: https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/29/eventbot-android-malware-banking/ Security researchers are sounding the alarm over a newly discovered Android malware that targets banking apps and cryptocurrency wallets. The malware, which researchers at security firm Cybereason recently discovered and called EventBot, masquerades as a legitimate Android app — like Adobe Flash or Microsoft Word for Android — which exploits Android's in-built accessibility features to obtain deep access to the device's operating system. Once installed — either by an unsuspecting user or by a malicious person with access to a victim's phone — the EventBot-infected fake app quietly siphons off passwords for more than 200 banking and cryptocurrency apps — including PayPal, Coinbase, CapitalOne and HSBC — and intercepts and two-factor authentication text message codes. With a victim's password and two-factor code, the hackers can break into bank accounts, apps and wallets, and steal a victim's funds. "The developer behind Eventbot has invested a lot of time and resources into creating the code, and the level of sophistication and capabilities is really high," Assaf Dahan, head of threat research at Cybereason, told TechCrunch. The malware quietly records every tap and key press, and can read notifications from other installed apps, giving the hackers a window into what's happening on a victim's device. At one point the malware's creators improved the encryption scheme it uses to communicate with the hackers' server, and included a new feature that can grab a user's device lock code, likely to allow the malware to grant itself higher privileges to the victim's device like payments and system settings. Best Security Pract

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- image malware MS Team .docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Bulletin/Cyber Bulletin Nr 2020- image malware MS Team .docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2020–(NR) The Evil GIF Cyber Attack By: https://thehackernews.com/2020/04/microsoft-teams-vulnerability.html Video Tele-Conference System (VTS) is a communication and collaboration platform that includes chat, video conferencing, file storage, and application integration capabilities. The solution can be highly useful to organizations, particularly during this COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak, when many employees are forced to work from home. Researchers at CyberArk, a company that specializes in privileged access security solutions, discovered vulnerability related to how popular VTS passes authentication access tokens to an image file. An attacker can exploit this weakness to create a link or GIF image file that, when processed, it sends an authentication token to a server they control. In the case of links, the victim needs to click on the link, but in attacks involving GIF images, the victim simply needs to view the GIF image in the chat and their token is sent to the hacker. Once they have obtained the token, the attacker can use it to hijack the victim's account through the VTS Application Programming Interfaces (API). The attacker can use this method to read the user's messages, send messages on their behalf, create groups, add or remove users from a group, and change group permissions. However, there are certain prerequisites for the attack to work. First of all, when the victim sees the malicious GIF, their access token can only be sent to a subdomain (e.g. teams.microsoft.com), so the attacker somehow needs to hijack such a subdomain. Microsoft released a patch for this vulnerability earlier of April and ensured the public that the domains identified by CyberArk cannot be abused and says it has taken other measures to prevent exploitation. As of this writing, th

title: Cyber Bulletin Nr 6 - Website Management.docx

author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Office of the AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila hpn.n6@navy.mil.ph N6B CYBERSECURITYBULLETIN: 2019 – 07 Best Security and Maintenance Practices for the Website The website is one of the important assets in an organization. As such, it is crucial that we manage and take proper security measures to protect it from various online threats. After all, a protected and well-maintained site will provide a secure environment for your visitors and increase the trust in your organization. In this bulletin, we will outline best practices for securing and maintaining the organization website. . Monitor and Update the Content of the Website A good reason to update your website with valuable content is to keep current audience updated. Your continually fresh content can provide visitors with valuable information about your organization. This will led visitors to your site through a search engine link. Regularly Scan the Website for Vulnerability Scan your web site for malware and vulnerability on a regular basis. Keeping it secure is the best way to prevent hackers from gaining access and ensuring your visitors has the best possible user experience. Patch or Update the Content Management System (CMS) A CMS is a digital system, and like all digital systems it can be hacked. As it gets older – a version of your CMS becomes more exposed to security risks. One of the biggest reasons that makers of a CMS release updates is to address these risks. Install a Web Application Firewall Install a Web Application Firewall to add another layer of protection to your site. You can use a plugin such as Sucuri to add their premium firewall functionality to your site. This will help instantly block hackers, add DDoS mitigation and prevention, and prevent Zero-Day exploits on your site. Backup the Website Having a backup of the website is crucial in case the worst happens. A

content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS DIRECTIVE ) NUMBER… ) SUBJECT: Supplemental Guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities TO: See Distribution REFERENCES: SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities CEIS LD Nr. 2012-001 dtd 19 Dec 2012, Subj: PN Standard LAN and Network Security Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. PURPOSE: This CEIS Directive prescribes the supplemental guidelines to SOP Nr. 13 dated 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities particularly on the conformity to the SANS twenty (20) Critical Security Controls. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cybersecurity -deliberate synergy of technologies, processes, and practices to protect information and the networks, computer systems and appliances, and programs used to collect, process, store, and transport that information from attack, damage and unauthorized access. Cybersecurity Posture – refers to the overall cybersecurity strength of an PN. It expresses the relative security of the IT estate and its vulnerability to outside threats. Risk Assessment – is a process of identifying, estimating, and prioritizing risks of PNal assets and operations. It involves evaluating hazards, and developing plans to remove or minimize the level of risk. Security Controls - refers to technical, physical, and administrative safeguards to detect cyber threats, minimize risks, and protect from cyber attacks. POLICIES Malware Protection Utilize centr

First aid or minor medical treatment. Slight equipment or system damage, but fully functional or serviceable. Little or no property or environmental damage. content: The 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations 26 THE 2016 REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 9184 The 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations 27 THE 2016 REVISED IMPLEMENTING RULES AND REGULATIONS OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 9184, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT REFORM ACT RULE I – GENERAL PROVISIONS Section 1. Short Title and Purpose This 2016 Revised Implementing Rules and Regulations2 , hereinafter called the IRR, is promulgated pursuant to Section 75 of Republic Act No. (R.A.) 9184, otherwise known as the "Government Procurement Reform Act," for the purpose of prescribing the necessary rules and regulations for the modernization, standardization, and regulation of the procurement activities of the Government of the Philippines (GoP).(a) Section 2. Declaration of Policy The provisions of this IRR are in line with the commitment of the GoP to promote good governance and its effort to adhere to the principles of transparency, accountability, equity, efficiency, and economy in its procurement process. It is the policy of the GoP that procurement of Goods, Infrastructure Projects and Consulting Services shall be competitive and transparent, and therefore shall undergo competitive bidding, except as provided in Rule XVI of this IRR.(a) Section 3. Governing Principles on Government Procurement The procurement of the GoP shall be governed by these principles: a) Transparency in the procurement process and in the implementation of procurement contracts through wide dissemination of bid opportunities and participation of pertinent non-government organizations. b) Competitiveness by extending equal opportunity to enable private contracting parties who are eligible and qualified to participate in competitive bidding. c) Streamlined procurement process that will uniformly apply to all government procurement. The procurement process shall be simple and made adaptable to advances in modern technology in order to ensure an effecti

Likely   Occurs several times, a common occurrence.  Occasional    Occurs sporadically, but is not uncommon.  Seldom         Remotely possible, could occur at some time. Usually several things must go wrong for it to happen.  Unlikely       Can assume will not occur, but not impossible.  SEVERITY  Catastrophic  Absence of controls may result to the following: Total devastation of PN mission-critical systems and vital ICT Infrastructure that may lead to imminent threat on national security. (e.g. SCADA and ICS devices that controls the navigation and fire control systems are damaged or remotely controlled). Cripples electronic medical equipment of PN hospitals that could lead to serious harm on individuals. Damage or jeopardize tactical or communication systems that may lead to complete mission failure or the loss of ability to accomplish a mission (e.g. sniffed or spoofed radio communication, remotely controlled Intel database).   Critical - Absence of controls may result to the following: Damage or jeopardize PN mission-essential systems and vital ICT Infrastructure that may lead to severely degraded mission capability or unit readiness (e.g. disrupts COP, Operational Reporting, email, and messaging Systems). Infect or compromise File storage containing Top secret, secret, and confidential documents which could lead to data exfiltration. author: System
content: ANNEX 6 RISK, THREAT AND VULNERABILITY MANAGEMENT Overview: Scope of Work: Supply, delivery, installation and configuration of the system. Testing and Commissioning Training Documentation Two (2) years Maintenance and Warranty NO SPECIFICATIONS COMPLY/NOT COMPLY The solution must be on premise, perpetual license with 2 years Maintenance The System must be able to import scanning data from different vulnerability scanners technologies such as Rapid7 The System must be able to assist in the analysing of incidents and assessment of risk. The System must have the ability to run risk analysis on network paths based on firewall policies and network connectivity The System must be able to perform risk exposure analysis. The System must be able to model the network map based on threat source, vulnerability analysis, network, and service info. The System must be able to identify attack vectors across a whole network, or specified subparts, from a specified start point(s) and to specified target(s) known as attack path analysis. The System must be able to model IPS as a compensating control to mitigate any exploitable attack path. The System must be able to model firewall rule changes to mitigate and exploitable attack path. The System must be able to analyse potential paths of access between security zones known as network path analysis. The System when performing vulnerability exposure analysis the solution must also consider the post attack conditions that need to be in place for the attacker to take advantage of the vulnerability to extend further towards a potential attack. The System must have the capability of prioritizing vulnerabilities for remediation based on network configurations, security controls such as Firewalls, IPS & etc, density, proximity to different levels of criticality of business, availability of exploit kits, knowledge of vulnerability exploitation in the wild, exposure, age and severity of the vulnerability. title: COR CL&SOC V1.doc
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/CyberLab Project/COR CL&SOC V1.doc
author: System
content: CIRCULAR OF REQUIREMENTS FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT AND OPERATIONALIZATION CYBER LABORATORY AND SECURITY OPERATION CENTER PROJECT SECTION I INTRODUCTION BACKGROUND: In cyberspace, the Philippine Navy Area of Operation (AO) falls within the two main types of information infrastructure. The PN Controlled Open Public Network or Gray network, where the regular internet services run and the PN Closed Network or Red Network wherein critical information systems services are connected. The current thrust of the General Headquarters is to enhance the AFP Wide Area Network by integrating the heterogeneous networks of the GHQ, Unified Commands, and Major services such as the PN Red Network into a robust, secured and resilient AFP Closed Network as mandated in Letter Directive Nr 65 (Enhancement of the AFP Network Connectivity, Security and Administration). Said letter directive requires to take the role in cybersecurity by protecting and securing the PN infostructure. In line with this, monitoring of traffic and endpoint devices at the PN Closed Network is important to ensure security and resiliency of the PN Infostructure.  Furthermore, the PN Gray Network provides connectivity with other government agencies, commercial partners, and platforms or units not connected to the closed network for coordination, collaboration and information exchange. It is through this connectivity that the PN network is at high risks in information and operation security, because of its link to other external networks. In addition, with data leakage incidents that had happened in this network, this infrastructure is considered vulnerable. The adversaries exploited the aforesaid vulnerable network and exfiltrated classified information, hence this network needs to be protected, monitored, and assessed regularly.  In 2009, the Cyber Security Group was created to be the first Cyber security Group of the AFP. The said group was responsible on the detection, identification and determining the various forms

BRIEF PROJECT DESCRIPTION Cyber Laboratory and Security Operation Center with Mission Essential Equipment, with ISO 27001 certified facility and accompanying Initial Integrated Logistics Support will be acquired for an estimated cost of P200.691 M. 2. PURPOSE Execute the appropriate strategy and process for the acquisition of the Cyber Laboratory and SOC. 3. OBJECTIVE To provide the Bids and Awards Committee (BAC) the guidelines regarding the preparation of bid documents, bidding proper, evaluation of bids, formulation of contract and other procurement activities. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS & ISSUANCES 1. RA 7898 (AFP Modernization Act) 2. RA 9184 (The Government Procurement Reform Act) 3. IRR of RA Nr 9184 5. STATEMENT OF NEED Naval defense and national development require a significant cyber security capability that could support military and non-military operations. To provide the needed cyber security capability, the Philippine Navy needs to acquire Cyber Laboratory and Security Operation Center. The cyber laboratory has a capability for cyber range, vulnerability assessment and penetration testing, incidence response and cyber forensic. The Security operation center has a real-time threat intelligence, data loss prevention, endpoint detection and response, integration of sensors, back up and recovery and DDOS Monitoring or anti-DDOS. 6. General Conditions of Contract Definitions In this Contract, the following terms shall be interpreted as indicated: "The Contract" means the agreement entered into between the Procuring Entity and the Supplier, as recorded in the Contract Form signed by the parties, including all attachments and appendices thereto and all documents incorporated by reference therein. "The Contract Price" means the price payable to the Supplier under the Contract for the full and proper performance of its contractual obligations. "The Goods" means all of the supplies, equipment, machinery, spare parts, other materials and/or general support services which the Supplier is required to provide to the Procuring Entity under the Contract. "The Services" means those services ancillary to the supply of the Goods, such as transportation and insurance, and any other incidental services, such as installation, commissioning, provision of technical assistance, training, and other such obligations of the Supplier covered under the Contract. "GCC" means the General Conditions of Contract contained in this Section. "SCC" means the Special Conditions of Contract. "The Procuring Entity" means the organization purchasing the Goods, as named in the SCC. "The Procuring Entity's country" is the Philippines. "The Supplier" means the individual contractor, manufacturer distributor, or firm supplying/manufacturing the Goods and Services under this Contract and named in the SCC. (02) 889-1301, 815-3420 & 843-4416 local 6341 PNBACPNBAC PNBAC PNBAC C4ISR-PNBAC-2019-__ Cyber Laboratory & Security Operations Center Project for the Philippine Navy (PN) Section VII. Technical Specifications STATEMENT OF COMPLIANCE TO TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS Bidders must state in the last column opposite each parameter and required specifications either "Comply" or "Not Comply". All pages must be properly signed. Bidders must state here either "Comply" or "Not Comply" against each of the individual parameters of each Specification stating the corresponding performance parameter of the equipment offered. Statements of "Comply" or "Not Comply" must be supported by evidence in a Bidders Bid and cross-referenced to that evidence. Evidence shall be in the form of manufacturer's un-amended sales literature, unconditional statements of specification and compliance issued by the manufacturer, samples, independent test data etc., as appropriate. A statement that is not supported by evidence or is subsequently found to be contradicted by the evidence presented will render the Bid under evaluation liable for rejection. A statement either in the Bidders statement of compliance or the supporting evidence that is found to be false either during Bid evaluation, post-qualification or the execution of the Contract may be regarded as fraudulent and render the Bidder or supplier liable for prosecution subject to the provisions of ITB Clause above goods manufactured by us. CLARIFICATION AND SETTLEMENT OF CONFLICTING INTERPRETATION OF THE TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS All clarifications regarding the technical specifications stipulated in this section will be clarified by the PN Technical Working Group. In cases of conflicting interpretations, the nature and purpose of the equipment will be the basis of interpretation. The main basis for technical specifications and requireme

Corrupt, Fraudulent, Collusive, and Coercive Practices Unless otherwise specified in the BDS, the Procuring Entity as well as the bidders and suppliers shall observe the highest standard of ethics during the procurement and execution of the contract. In pursuance of this policy, the Procuring Entity: defines, for purposes of this provision, the terms set forth below as follows: "corrupt practice" means behavior on the part of officials in the public or private sectors by which they improperly and unlawfully enrich themselves, others, or induce others to do so, by misusing the position in which they are placed, and includes the offering, giving, receiving, or soliciting of anything of value to influence the action of any such official in the procurement process or in contract execution; entering, on behalf of the government, into any contract or transaction manifestly and grossly disadvantageous to the same, whether or not the public officer profited or will profit thereby, and similar acts as provided in RA 3019. content: PN CYBER LABORATORY AND SECURITY OPERATIONS CENTER TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION Nr Item Qty U/I Specification Comply/ Not Comply 1. SECURITY ORCHESTRATION AUTOMATION AND RESPONSE (SOAR) 1 lot The system shall, at the minimum, include the following: At least one (1) SOAR server hardware or appliance with following minimum specification: Intel Xeon Scalable processor with minimum of 16 cores per processor or similar processor equivalent for the appliance Memory: 128GB Hard drive Bays: 8 minimum Power Supply: 2 x 800W minimum HDD (SATA): 32 TB minimum SSD: 1 TB minimum With management port With minimum of Four (4) 1G port With minimum of Two (2) USB 3.0 ports Must be compatible with any enterprise SOAR software At least one (1) Enterprise SOAR Software with following minimum features or requirements: Perpetual License On-premise deployment Thirty (30) active user accounts Ten (10) concurrent logged-in Analyze and protect at least 2600 endpoint devices and 100 network devices Interact with at least 2600 EDR for in-depth endpoint forensic investigation and activate response action. Orchestrates alerts, logs and information from at least two (2) SIEM for network analysis, and endpoint monitoring. Consolidate and integrate from at least ten (10) security and network sensors such as firewall and IDS into a single and easily manageable screen. Near real-time mitigation with at most two (2) minutes detection and response activation. Provides at least one (1) Case Management System such as creation of incident reports Provides at least one (1) business intelligence dashboard and reports for the Management or PN leadership Records network and endpoint information with thirty (30) days retention for threat hunting and incident investigation Allow integration of at least one (1) threat intel feeds from both subscribed or open source. However, this added convenience doesn't come without a price – namely, the increased exposure to tech-savvy cyber attackers. author: System
content: Windows Desktop Edition Windows Vista / Windows 7 / Windows 8 / Windows 8.1 / Windows 10 Windows Server Edition Windows Server 2008 / 2012 / 2016 Note: Both 32 bit and 64 bit versions of Windows are supported. Operating System: Globodox can be installed in Server mode on any Supported Windows Operating system. We recommend you use Windows Server 2012 Memory (RAM): 4GB server memory minimum. We would recommend 8GB or above for better performance. Free hard disk space for software installation: 200MB Hard Disk space to store documents: Depends on the total size of your documents. Microsoft.Net Framework 2.0, 4.0: (If not present, it will be automatically downloaded and installed.) Web Server: IIS must be enabled on the server machine if browser based access via Globodox Web Client is required (this is available as part of Glob Globodox Standard). Processor: 1GHz processor (2 GHz or more recommended) Memory (RAM): 2GB recommended Free hard disk space for software installation: 200MB Microsoft.Net Framework 2.0, 4.0: (If not present, it will be automatically downloaded and installed.) Note: In case you are using a MySQL DB, MySQL ODBC Client Driver 5.3.4 (32 bit) must be installed on the Client machines. To know m 1 of 2 Browser Latest versions of Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Safari, Opera & Internet Explorer MS SQL Server 2005 and higher One machine on the network running MS SQL Server is required if you want to create and use MS SQL Server based Globodox DBs. MS SQL Express One machine on the network running MS SQL Server is required if you want to create and use MS SQL Server based Globodox DBs. MySQL 5.0 and higher One machine on the network running MySQL Server is required if you want to create and use MySQL based Globodox DBs. MySQL ODB installed on the Client machines. MS Access You do not need MS Access to be installed on your machine to create or use MS Access based Globodox DBs. Globodox installs all the f based Globodox DBs. Copyright © 1998 - 2017 ITAZ ®

title: Philippine Navy NICTS.pdf
author: System
content: 09 January 2019 Nelson Maligro, ON6 Philippine Navy Via email: nelsonmaligro@gmail.com Dear Sir: Thank you for meeting with us last November 2018 to discuss your document management requirements. May we take this opportunity to summarize the Globodox DMS objectives discussed during the meeting: 1. To respond quickly to the search/retrieval of records. Globodox DMS provides several search methods including the retrieval of records by indices or by a document's content, very similar to how a search and retrieve is made in Yahoo or Google. 2. To demonstrate office efficiency. Retrieval of records can be by school name, by teacher's name such as last name, first name, middle name, locality, and other fields. FMWC would like to define. Globodox DMS provides simple and advance search functions. 3. To have a backup of records electronically. Electronic records (scanned civil registry images, Microsoft Office files, email, and other forms of electronic files) placed into Globodox DMS can be copied into external medias to serve as a backup of original paper and office records. 4. To maintain disaster recovery measures in times of fire, rain, and earthquakes. In case of disaster, Globodox DMS can utilize these external disks/CDs and recreate the server database for business continuity. Floro International Corporation Unit 717B, ACG Buding Shaw Boulevard, Wack Wack, Mandaluyong Phone 533-2584 Fax: 654-7215 email: floro@floro-intl.com www.floro-intl.com, www.digitizingdocuments.com 2000-001 5. To relieve employees from clerical activities such as searching, retrieving and printing. 6. To provide security of original documents. Paper documents do not need to be accessed, thereby minimizing loss or misfiled documents though the use of Globodox DMS. Moreover, minimizing the handling of paper documents minimizes the wear and tear caused by handling. 7. To provide transfer of technology to the employees of FMWC through training and implementation of the Globodox DMS system. We have

title: SOP 10 PN IPMS UPDATING AND USAGE POLICY.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/NORS/SOP 10 PN IPMS UPDATING AND USAGE POLICY.pdf
author: System
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) GBM:OPL:VAC;anm:jpg-3200 2335 Pres. M. Roxas Boulevard, Manila ONMDC/ONA 11 May 2006 STANDING OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER 10 PN IPMS UPDATING AND USAGE POLICY 1. PURPOSE: To prescribe and standardize procedure in updating PN personnel information using PN Integrated Personnel Management System (PN IPMS) in order to provide standardized personnel SOI output format with authenticated entries. This SOP also prescribes enhancement of personnel information in aid of accounting and monitoring. 2. SCOPE: The provisions of this SOP shall apply to all naval personnel in the active service and civilian employees presently employed. 3. DEFINITION OF TERMS: a. PHILIPPINE NAVY INTEGRATED PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (PN IPMS) – is an information system facility which is capable of storing personnel information, data processing and reports generation. It is a technological tool specifically designed for personnel management and administration. b. Summary of Information (SOI) – the official document for information of military personnel. c. ISMB – Information Systems Management Branch, the specific branch of NMDC that manages data of PN personnel. d. Chief, ISMB – the head of the ISMB e. Individual – pertains to any military or civilian personnel requesting for update, amendment and/or retrieval of his or her SOI. f. Digital Camera – an electronic device used to capture image of an individual. g. PN IPMS workstation – a computer set used for purpose of capturing, processing, and/or retrieving of personnel data from the IPMS database. h. Validators – specially-trained personnel who verify the authenticity of personnel information submitted prior encoding. i. Database Administrator - any qualified and trained personnel who maintains and manages the database to ensure its security, integrity and credibility. He/She is authorized to edit/update the database upon the approval of the IPMS Board. R

title: NRC wesite defacement-report J6_VER2.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Forensic Investigation/NRC wesite defacement-report J6_VER2.docx
author: System
content: FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila SUBJECT: Incident Report on the Alleged Website Defacement of Naval Reserve Command TO: Chief of Staff, AFP General Headquarters, AFP Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo Quezon City (Attn: DCS for CEIS, J6) References: PN SOP nr 07 dated 01 August 2012, Subject: PN Computer Emergency Response Team. PN SOP nr 30 dated 09 Dec 2011, Subject: PN Website Management This pertains to the alleged website defacement of Naval Reserve Command which was reported in social media (Facebook) account of a certain Mr Art Samaniego Jr. on 102126H April 2019. Based on initial result of investigation, the hacker with pen name "SIBAT" was able to upload some files that could run commands in the server. The NRC website contains feature that allows uploading of photos however the programmer fails to secure this functionalities through validation of input that denies uploading of any files other than images. This vulnerability provided a means for the hacker to upload malicious files including the infamous "sibat.html". The following are the established facts of investigation: The NRC website is not actually defaced and the original homepage remains intact and unchanged. The attacker successfully uploaded the bragging "Sibat.html" page but failed to overwrite the "index.php" which is the homepage because of non-write privilege. Based on the review of logs, there is no evidence of database/records extraction. On 30 Oct 2018 the programmer/administrator of NRC website modified/updated the system which included the "File Upload" feature but failed to submit it for VAPT first. For information. ROBERT A EMPEDRAD VADM AFP Encl: Screenshots on How the Hacker Did It?
