author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE OF THE AC OF NS FOR C4ISR SYSTEMS, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Pres. M. Roxas Boulevard, Manila N6B 10 November 2017 MEMORANDUM for – AC of NS for C4SR Systems, N6 Subj: IPMS Board Conference 1. References: O/N1 Conference Notice dated 07 November 2017 2. The IPMS Board headed by the AC of NS for Personnel, N1 called the meeting to update the members on the current status of the IPMS V12 system and discussed the following agenda: a. Personnel Administration Module b. IPMS Generated Recurring Reports c. Orders Module d. IPMS Center e. IPMS Payroll Module Concerns 3. O/A 0805H the meeting was called to order wherein the secretary has certified a quorum. At the onset of the meeting, CAPT KARL A DECAPIA PN(GSC) presented the agenda to be tackled in the meeting as well as the observations he solicited regarding the current operation of the IPMS at the tactical level. Following were the observations of the chairman: a. Issues in the SOI updating at the tactical level; b. Low turn-out of the SOI updating; c. Improvement of the SOI; d. Implementation salary cut-off in the finance module as per policy on ETE for enlisted personnel and ETAD/SOT for reserve officers; and, e. Advocate the proactive updating of the SOI. 4. LCDR SAMBALILO PN(GSC), the Deputy Commander of NICTC presented the status of IPMS to the body. LCDR SAMBALILO PN(GSC) discussed the important milestones of the system starting from where the system was re-developed last 25 June 2010 up to the partial implementation of its third phase this 2017, which is the connectivity of the marine brigades under MITHI project. LCDR SAMBALILO PN(GSC) also presented the current status and way ahead of the system (Encl 1). Mandate Legal Basis The Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT) was created through Republic Act No. 10844 "An Act Creating the Department of Information and Communications Technology, Defining its Powers and Functions, Appropriating Funds Therefore and for Other Purposes" which was issued on 23 May 2016. Functions A.2. Vision Statement "An innovative, safe and happy nation that thrives through and is enabled by Information and Communications Technology" A.3. Mission Statement "DICT of the People, DICT for the People". The DICT commits to: Provide every Filipino access to vital ICT infostructure and services; Ensure sustainable growth of Philippine ICT-enabled industries resulting to creation of more jobs; Establish a one digitized government, one nation; Support the National Government in fully achieving its goals; and Make the DICT as the enabler, innovator, achiever, and leader in pushing the country's development and transition towards a world-class digital economy. content: RESTRICTED Page 1 of 26 PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R PHILIPPINE NAVY CYBERSECURITY POLICY 1. PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide an overarching governance and top-level guidance to ensure the resiliency and protection of Philippine Navy (PN) Information Infrastructures (Infostructure), National Security Systems (NSS), and information resources. This publication shall serve as a basis for the issuance of specific policies, procedures, and guidelines to effectively implement cybersecurity. In this context, the PN adopts the principles of Confidentiality by ensuring that information is accessible only to those who are authorized, Integrity by safeguarding the accuracy and completeness of information and processing methods, and Availability by ensuring that authorized users have access to information and associated systems when required. It discusses the procedures to address the requirements of the cybersecurity framework enablers such as Policy, Technology, Awareness, and Mitigation that are mutually supporting each other to achieve credible defense cybersecurity posture as mentioned in the PN Cyberwarfare Doctrine. Per said doctrine, cybersecurity is a prelude to Defensive Cyber Operations (DCO). Any organization cannot engage in DCO without fortifying its cybersecurity capability first. 2. SCOPE: This policy provides guidance to administrators, maintainers, operators, and third party stakeholders of the NSS, PN C4ISTAR infrastructure, and PN Infostructure for effective administration, operations, maintenance, and security of C4ISR systems. 3. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: a. Administrator - refers to the person responsible for managing the PN network. The responsibilities of the administrator typically include installing and configuring system hardware and software; establishing and managing user accounts; upgrading softwa

title: Active Archipelagic Defense Strategy.pdf
author: System
content: S E C R E T S E C R E T 1 ACTIVE ARCHIPELAGIC DEFENSE STRATEGY BUILDING THE PHILIPPINE NAVY OFFSHORE TERRITORIAL DEFENSE FORCE 2020 Version 2013.1 "Tomorrow we shall be citizens of the Philippines, whose destiny will be brilliant because it will be in the care of loving hands… our navy's warships will guard our shores… then commerce, industry, agriculture, and science will be free to develop under the protection of wise and equitable laws as in prosperous England."– Dr. Jose Rizal in El Filibusterismo S E C R E T 2 S E C R E T PART I - INTRODUCTION LAYING THE FOUNDATION FOR THE NAVAL STRATEGY 1.1.WHY DO WE NEED A NAVAL STRATEGY? 1.1.1. Naval defense is a complex undertaking that entails detailed and deliberate planning. Today the Philippine Navy is facing two (2) major challenges concerning the defense of the Philippine archipelago. The first is the need to address the various maritime security concerns, which compels the Navy to focus not only on its military role but also on its constabulary duties. This places a significant strain on its currently available capabilities in taking on the latter role, at the cost of veering away from its core competency as a naval force. The second challenge is the maintenance of an appropriate force-mix of people, organization, equipment, and logistics that allows the naval force to accomplish national ends within a certain time frame and cost. This challenge involves key decisions on the size and shape of the current and future naval force required and the difficult strategic risk management efforts that goes with it. 1.1.2. The Philippines in the past three years has experienced giant strides in putting its maritime agenda in order. This was initially brought about by the passage of the amendments to the Philippine Baselines Law or Republic Act 9522. The law effectively set the national policy of aligning our national boundaries consistent with the UN Convention on the Law of Sea, eliminating strategic ambiguities with respect t

content: DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (IF ANY) FILE NR: N6B-1017- SUBJECT: Proposed Philippine Navy Cybersecurity Circular TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS Date: Comment Nr_____ VIA: VCOM, PN LT BARRACA PN:6395 ________ N6 _________ ________ N3 _________ ________ N2 _________ SUMMARY: References: National Cybersecurity Plan 2022 GHQ Letter Directive Nr 28 dated 30 August 2013, Subj: Adopting Cyberspace as One of the Domains of AFP Operations PN Cyber Warfare Doctrine As a background,cyber incidents are notably increasing and cyber-attacks are happening worldwide, not just in the business sector, but also in the military and the PN information infrastructure (infostructure). For the past five years, the PN had experience various cyber incidents such as website defacement, denial of service, and data breach. The aforementioned incidents can be associated to the improper practices that users are committing. These may include, but not limited to, lack of policy and procedures on the use of USB or portable drivers, placements of the security devices and network monitoring systems, and licensing and updating of operating systems and application software. Related thereto, the Department of Information and Communication Technology (DICT) published the National Cyber Security Plan 2022 (ref a) that serves as the reference in developing methods and strategy in order to ensure resiliency of the government and private infostructure, which adopted the NIST Cybesecurity Framework. In addition, the AFP has issued guidance on the adoption of cyberspace as development of related policies, plans, program and strategies in the conduct of operations in the cyberspace domain. Further, the PN has approved the Cyber Warfare Doctrine (ref c) that provides general guidance and basic reference for PN commanders and staff on the principles and procedures on cyber defense, deterrence, and offense, which also adopted the framework of National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Cybersecurity

title: ForewordOPIF.pdf
author: System
content: Foreword "Ang paggugol na matuwid ay diretso sa tao." In crafting the National Budget for 2012, the Aquino Administration aimed to advance reforms that would institute transparency, accountability, and citizen engagement in the use of public funds. At the same time, we remained faithful to the practical spirit of policy change, recognizing that public expenditure management reforms are futile if they do not result in direct, immediate, and substantial benefits to the Philippines' poorest and most marginalized. The Organizational Performance Indicator Framework (OPIF) is a key reform of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) that seeks to implement effective agency spending to produce concrete and measurable outcomes in line with the Administration's priority development agenda. Under the OPIF, the deliverables of each department and agency go well beyond the number of roads builtor nurses hired, and are instead strategically designed to reduce poverty and induce all- inclusive growth. Together with other public expenditure management reforms—the Zero-Based Budgeting (ZBB) Approach, the Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF), the Procurement Reforms, and the strengthening of Internal Control Systems—the OPIF aims to ensure that each and every peso spent by the government is dedicated to the public good. To better inform the Congress and the public on the outputs required of every department and agency in exchange for their budget allocation, the DBM published this OPIF Book of Outputs for 2012. It serves as a practical reference tool for legislators, academics, students, civil society organizations and researchers, as well as oversight agencies. This Book of Outputs also allows the public to learn more about, understand, and monitor not only the peso values in the national budget,but more importantly, the performance of government agencies relative totheir mandates and budgetary allocations. The OPIF Bookof Outputsfor 2012presents the respective budgets of n

title: AADS Promulgation.pdf
author: System
content: S E C R E T S E C R E T i FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Pres. M Roxas Boulevard, Manila 11 Dec 2013 From: Flag Officer in Command, PN To: All PN Units Subj: Letter of Promulgation (Active Archipelagic Defense Strategy) 1. Introduction Our naval forces are currently facing the twin challenges of addressing the various maritime security concerns of our country while maintaining an appropriate force-mix of people, organization, equipment, and logistics that allow the naval force to accomplish national ends within a certain time frame and cost. Buoyed by the recent advancements in the development of legal and institutional policy frameworks on advancing our country's maritime interests such as the Philippine Baselines Law, Philippine Coast Guard Law, Amended AFP Modernization Law and Executive Order 57, the Philippine Navy as an institution has to collectively come up with the right direction of naval development. We need to take stock and reassess our role in the overall national defense and security architecture of our country in order to clearly identify the tasks that naval forces in the future must be able to accomplish, and what, and how much, of our core capabilities are required to accomplish these roles. These strategic level developments prompted the review of all existing PN strategies issued in the past with the hope of coming up with a new naval strategy using the communal thought and wisdom of our past and present officers and leaders. The promulgation of this Active Archipelagic Defense Strategy (AADS) encapsulates the tedious process of research, stakeholder consultations, and collective analysis. 2. On Naval Roles and Strategic Maritime Interests Culling altogether the materials from the Philippine Constitution of 1987 and policy issuances within the security sector and the Philippines, the principal tasks required of the Philippine Navy are as follows: a. To protect and defend the integrity of the national te

title: PN OPIF.pdf
author: System
content: 371 Legal Basis Commonwealth Act No. 1 (December 21, 1935), the National Defense Act, created and organized the Off-Shore Patrol (OSP) under the Regular Force of the Army of the Philippines. Executive Order No 94 (October 4, 1947) created the Philippine Naval Patrol, forerunner of the Philippine Navy, as one of the Major Commands of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP). Executive Order No. 389 (December 23, 1950), Reorganizing the Armed Forces of the Philippines, created and organized the Philippine Navy as one of the Major Services of the AFP with primary concerns in operations at sea. Executive Order No. 292 (July 25, 1987), Administrative Code of 1987, provided for the powers, functions and organizational structure of the Philippine Navy as one of the Major Services of the AFP under the supervision and control of the Department of National Defense(DND). Mandate The Philippine Navy (PN) organizes, trains, deploys, and maintains forces for the prompt and sustained naval and maritime operations in support of the United Commands in the accomplishment of the AFP mission. title: Performance Measurement Framework ISSP.pdf
author: System
content: PROVINCE OF AGUSAN DEL SUR Prepared by: PROVINCIAL MONITORING AND EVALUATION GROUP (PMEG), PROVINCIAL PROJECT MONITORING COMMITTEE (PPMC), & OTHER CONCERNED STAKEHOLDERS EXECUTIVE-LEGISLATIVE AGENDA (ELA) INFORMATION SYSTEM STRATEGIC PLAN (ISSP) STRATEGIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PLAN (SFMP) AGUSAN DEL SUR ROAD NETWORK DEVELOPMENT PLAN (ARNDP) HUMAN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND DEVELOPMENT PLAN (HRMDP) Page 1 of 46 PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT FRAMEWORK FOR ELA, ISSP, SFMP, ARNDP & HRMDP I. INTRODUCTION The Performance Measurement Framework (PMF) is a tool used to measure performance in the implementation of a particular plan/program/project. As an enhanced Logical Framework, it highlights the hierarchy of objectives with the corresponding sets of indicators and means of verifications at the impact, outcomes, outputs and inputs level as identified/established in the logical framework during the planning stage. Further, it contains the data collection strategy (which includes the how the data is to be collected, who will provide/collect it, and when it will be available and collected) and how these data are to be analyzed. II. Rationale and Objectives The Five Development Plans, namely: Executive-Legislative Agenda (ELA), Information Systems Strategic Plan (ISSP), Strategic Financial Management Plan (SFMP), Agusan del Sur Road Network Development Plan (ARNDP) and Human Resource Management Development Plan (HRMDP), were already in the implementation stage. These plans need to be monitored and evaluated in order to know the extent or degree of accomplishments in relation to their contribution to the achievement of the province vision to become "an agri- industrialized, eco-tourism province of God-centered, caring, healthy, productive and self-sustaining communities". In January 25, 2011, the Provincial Governor Adolph Edward G. Plaza issued an Executive Order No. 3-11, Series of 2011 creating the Provincial Monitoring and Evaluation Group (PMEG). The mandate of this group is to moni

content: Page 2 of 8 PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS LETTER DIRECTIVE NUMBER SUBJECT: Policy and Guidelines for Disclosure of Document/Information of PN Modernization Projects during DAS Process TO: All Concerned REFERENCE: AFP RG 200-014 – Security of Classified Matters Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017 - PN Cybersecurity Policy CEIS Directive Nr 01 dated 06 January 2015; Subj: Unofficial Internet Posts and Use of Social Media PURPOSE: This directive prescribes policy and guidelines on the proper disclosure of the documents/information of the DAS Modernization Projects. Likewise, this document provides guidance to the members of the Defense Acquisition System Assessment Team (DASAT), DAS Technical Working Group (TWG)/Project Management Team (PMT), Technical Inspection and Acceptance Committee (TIAC), and all PN units and personnel who are directly or indirectly involved in handling, supervising, monitoring, and consulting PN modernization projects. BACKGROUND: The fast-paced technological advancement along with the associated threat is inevitable. The prevalence of smart phones, tablets, laptops, and IOT devices threatens the security of an organization and privacy of a person. ---Ano ubiquitous? People, through these mobile devices, are connected everywhere. Information is shared instantly with just a click of a fingertip. Classified information, such as mission, strategies, concepts of operations, technological specifications, and capability acquisition, is potentially at risk of getting exposed in the public; hence, security and protection of this information is very important. The social media, video sharing, and blogs are widely used technological tool for information dissemination; however, some information were posted without the consent of the PN. Unauthorized disclosure of classified documents containing details and plans of PN modernization projects poses t

author: System
content: RESTRICTE D I-1Page PHILIPPINE NAVY MANUAL Philippine Navy Electronic Warfare HEADQUARTERS PHILIPPINENAVY 2016 RESTRICTE D iPage FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Pres. M Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Flag Officer In Command, PN To: All Concerned Subj: Promulgation 1. The Electronic Warfare (EW) Manual serves as reference for the Philippine Navy to secure and maintain freedom of action in the electromagnetic spectrum in support to naval operations. 2. This manual intends to equip all PN personnel, especially our naval commanders and those supporting them with the basic information on Electronic Warfare. This publication also contains the broad concepts, principles, perspectives, roles, and planning guidance that are essential in managing EW operations. 3. This doctrine is hereby promulgated for the information and guidance of all concerned effective this date. CEASAR C TACCAD Vice Admiral, AFP RESTRICTE D Pageii Intentionally Blank iPage RESTRICTE D CHIEF OF NAVALSTAFF PHILIPPINE NAVY Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Pres. M Roxas Boulevard, Manila FOREWORD Naval forces rely on the Electromagnetic Spectrum (EMS) to sense, communicate, strike, and dominate offensively and defensively across all warfighting domains, whether on sea, air, land or cyber. Electronic Warfare (EW) is essential for protecting friendly operations and denying adversary operations within the EMS. The purpose of EW is to deny the opponent an advantage in the EM spectrum and ensure friendly unimpeded access to the EM spectrum portion of the information environment. EW is employed to support operations involving various levels of detection, denial, deception, disruption, protection, and destruction The EW Manual was envisioned by the Philippine Navy as a guide of unit commanders and their personnel in taking advantage of the EMS for the success of information operations (IO). This manual intends to keep the PN at pace with current trends inC4ISTAR System an

author: System
content: Enterprise Architecture using TOGAF Francis Uy, PMP, TOGAF©9 Paul Prout, TOGAF ©9 PAUL PROUT He is a TOGAF Certified Enterprise Architect and Open Group Instructor across the TOGAF, ArchiMate and Solution Architecture domains His career started in Australia as an ATM Developer for a bank in the mid-1980s He had experience working across Development, Operations, Infrastructure and Technology as a Systems Analyst by mid-1990s For over a decade he worked across Australia, Singapore and Japan as an Architect in the Business, Data, Application and Technology domains before then leading the Enterprise Architecture practice at Woodside Energy, Australia's largest oil and gas company Since 2016 Paul has been the Director for Enterprise Architecture in Sinag Solutions helping Philippine and Asian businesses to be global best in class through EA In his spare time, he enjoys aerial photography and drone racing. FRANCIS UY He became the first TOGAF©9 certified Enterprise Architect (EA) in the Philippines in 2012. He's been teaching EA since 2008 and has developed several EA masterplans and roadmaps for government and private sectors. He's also a Program and Project Manager. He's a Project Management Professional (PMP) since 2004. He was in charge of an MNC's USD 6B Global eCommerce program. He has implemented various systems across Philippines, Vietnam, Australia, the UK, France, Japan, ASEAN, and the US. He also has Operations/ BAU experience implementing ITSM, Six Sigma, and BPM frameworks to turn good Operations to great Operations. His experience includes Government (Health, Real-Estate, Judiciary, Environment, Labor, Finance) and with the Industry (Energy & Utilities, Pharmaceutical, Distribution, Manufacturing, Retail, Digital Marketing). M Roxas Boulevard, Manila From: Flag Officer In Command, PN To: All Concerned Subj: Promulgation 1. The Missile Defense System Manual (PNM6-11) provides basic operating concept, principles and philosophy that the Philippine Navy adopts in the deployment and employment of missile system to ensure deterrence and strengthen territorial defense. This manual is intended to equip all PN personnel especially our naval commanders and those supporting them basic reference and ample information on the PN-AFP MDS. As the first missile- themed operational manual in the PN, this publication also contains the broad guidance and concepts where subsequent tactical doctrines on missile defense shall be based upon. 2. This manual is hereby promulgated for the information and guidance of all concerned effective this date. M Roxas Boulevard, Manila FOREWORD Our Armed Forces operate in a strategic environment characterized by international interdependency, conflicting claims, common safety concerns, calamity, and finite maritime resources. Over the last several years, the Philippines has experienced a number of security issues which involved intrusions into our territorial waters and contended use of Philippine sovereign territories particularly in the West Philippine Sea (WPS). These underscored not only the ability and willingness of aggressor states to project power into those waters, but similarly the seemingly growing confidence to put Philippine Sovereignty to the test. content: Page 1 of 1 PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS LETTER DIRECTIVE NUMBER SUBJECT: Policy and Guidelines for Disclosure of Document/Information of PN Modernization Projects during DAS Process TO: All Concerned REFERENCE: AFP RG 200-014 - Document Security Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017 - PN Cybersecurity Policy CEIS Directive Nr 01 dated 06 January 2015; Subj: Unofficial Internet Posts and Use of Social Media PURPOSE: This directive prescribes policy and guidelines on the proper disclosure of the documents/information of the DAS Modernization Projects. Likewise, this document provides guidance to the members of the Defense Acquisition System Assessment Team (DASAT), DAS Technical Working Group (TWG)/Project Management Team (PMT), Technical Inspection and Acceptance Committee (TIAC), and all PN units and personnel who are directly and/or indirectly involve in supporting, supervising, monitoring, and consulting of the Philippine Navy Modernization Projects. BACKGROUND: The fast-paced technological advancement is inevitable. Telecommunications equipment such as smart phones and tablets are ubiquitous that may threaten the person or an organization's security. People are connected everywhere. Information is shared instantly-even in just a click of your fingertips. Information is the most important asset of the organization. It may contain mission, concepts of operations, technologies, and capabilities, hence security and protection of information is very important. The print, broadcast, and social media are the tools that can be utilized for information dissemination. However, there are threats underneath this technological advancement being observed lately to the organization. Unauthorized disclosure of documents containing classified information of PN modernization project details and plans were posted in the internet, specifically in the social media. These circu

content: Forcepoint Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Data protection in a zero-perimeter world 2 forcepoint.com Data security is a never-ending challenge. On one hand, IT organizations are required to keep up with regulations and protect intellectual property from targeted attacks and accidental exposure. On the other, they must adapt to macro IT movements, such as the adoption of cloud applications, hybrid cloud environments and BYOD trends, all of which increase the ways data can leave your organization. This expanding attack surface poses the most significant challenge to protecting critical data. Data security teams take the seemingly logical approach to chase data: find it, catalogue it and control it. Yet this traditional approach to data loss prevention is no longer effective because it ignores the biggest variable in data security — your people. Instead of focusing solely on data, security should begin and end with people. The key is to gain visibility into user interactions with data and applications. Once this is achieved, you can apply a level of control based on the specific user's risk and the sensitivity or value of the data. An organization's data protection program must consider the human point — the intersection of users, data and networks. In addition, the enterprise must remain vigilant of data as it moves across the enterprise and highlight the people who create, touch and move data. Secure regulated data with a single point of control for all the applications your people use to create, store and move data. Protect intellectual property with advanced DLP that analyzes how people use data, coaches your people to make good decisions with data and prioritizes incidents by risk. title: Swimlane Product Datasheet.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/Proponent's Response to RFQ-20191118T225022Z-001/Proponent_s Response to RFQ/Infocentric/Swimlane Product Datasheet.pdf
author: System
content: TECHNICAL DATASHEET Security Automation & Orchestration Review all security alerts, prioritize critical tasks, and remediate threats faster by automating security orchestration & incident response with Swimlane Automated Security Operations Despite investing heavily in a wide array of security solutions and the staff required to triage, investigate and resolve threats, information security organizations continue to struggle. Manual incident response processes, inefficient workflows and difficulty hiring and retaining qualified personnel leaves security teams struggling to keep up with an ever-increasing volume of alarms. Swimlane automates and orchestrates the incident response, collecting alert and event data from virtually any security platform with minimal effort. It automatically centralizes and responds to alerts using automated workflows to reduce mean time to detect and respond. Customizable, KPI-driven dashboards and reports deliver the intelligence necessary to drive continuous operational improvements and adaption to new threats. The Problem Organizations are losing the battle against cyber attackers. Overburdened security administrators are manually performing repetitive and time-consuming tasks to track, mitigate and resolve security events across multiple security platforms. But despite the time and effort, they can't analyze or adequately prioritize the security alerts and events necessary to protect their networks. And a lack visibility into their team's current activities, metrics, and performance leaves security managers struggling to justify additional resources. The Solution Swimlane's automated orchestration and workflow expedites the entire incident response management process, from initial event notification to remediation and closure. It automatically gathers key information, builds decision cases, and executes critical actions to prevent and/or remediate cyber threats based on logical incident response processes. Extensive out-of-the-box inte

title: Swimlane Case Study - US Government Agency (1) (3).pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/Proponent's Response to RFQ-20191118T225022Z-001/Proponent_s Response to RFQ/Infocentric/Swimlane Case Study - US Government Agency (1) (3).pdf
author: System
content: ORGANIZATION United States Federal Government Agency INDUSTRY Federal Government SCOPE 19,000 employees & contractors 200+ offices worldwide KEY IMPACTS Efficiency improvements equivalent to a 50% staffing increase Significantly lowered Mean Time to Remediation (MTTR) Increased the opportunity to be proactive Greatly improved staff satisfaction and quality of life U.S. Government Agency Improves Efficiency to Keep Pace with Increasing Threats Federal agencies are massive and highly distributed organizations that represent the U.S. government in the eyes of many people worldwide. As such, each agency has an outsized threat profile and an ever- growing number of daily attacks. To counter these threats, this federal agency has a 24/7 Security Operations Center (SOC) with a large staff. They rely on dozens of point security systems as well as sophisticated SIEM and network security platforms. They are tasked with typical SOC functions like: Monitoring Looking for anomalous activity Malware alerts Basic intelligence gathering Forensic, end-point, and network investigations SIEM management Phishing PII & classified data spills Reporting THE CHALLENGE All of these point solutions and responsibilities generate tens of thousands of alerts every day. Prior to bringing on Swimlane, each alert had to be manually triaged and investigated. Much of the SOC's time was spent on rote manual tasks like cutting and pasting information to and from ticketing systems or manually searching for information stored on various separate databases. Staff was becoming simultaneously frazzled and bored with their jobs. In the meantime, the number of both false alarms and genuine threats kept increasing. As a government agency, it has a fixed headcount and could not just throw additional bodies at the problem. Eventually, the SOC simply would not be able to keep up with the ever-increasing number of both true threats and false alarms. "We were paying a lot of money for high-level data entry people.

title: Swimlane_Architecture_Datasheet__1_.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/Proponent's Response to RFQ-20191118T225022Z-001/Proponent_s Response to RFQ/Infocentric/Swimlane_Architecture_Datasheet__1_.pdf
author: System
content: Swimlane can be deployed as one or more instances on physical hardware, virtual machines and/or cloud-based IaaS platforms. It scales vertically and horizontally, with full HA and DR capabilities. Swimlane's web tier can be load balanced or distributed across a content delivery network (CDN) to maximize front end performance and availability. Swimlane's backend database infrastructure is built on a combination of NoSQL and Graph components. NoSQL leverages sharding for scalability and replica sets to allow for HA and DR deployments. Graph DB components use clustering for scalability, HA and DR. Task Engines manage integrations, data ingestion, and data enrichment. Additional Task Engines can be easily and rapidly deployed to support added scalability. Swimlane integrates with internal infrastructure to gather relevant user, hosts, and network information, as well as security solutions to update rules, gather alarms, generate tickets and notify analysts. Swimlane can leverage cloud- based services such as threat intelligence, whois, malware detonation and other cloud- based or SaaS services. 1 2 3 4 5 6 Swimlane © 2019 Swimlane delivers enterprise scalability to meet the performance requirements of any environment. Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) Platform Swimlane is architected for maximum deployment flexibility with extensive horizontal and vertical scalability to fit the capacity requirements of any enterprise. It supports granular multitenancy, as well as full high availability (HA) and disaster recovery (DR). Gutierrez, Secretary National Institute of Standards and Technology James Turner, Acting Director Guidelines on Securing Public Web Servers Recommendations of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Miles Tracy, Wayne Jansen, Karen Scarfone, and Theodore Winograd GUIDELINES ON SECURING PUBLIC WEB SERVERS Reports on Computer Systems Technology The Information Technology Laboratory (ITL) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) promotes the U.S. economy and public welfare by providing technical leadership for the Nation's measurement and standards infrastructure. ITL develops tests, test methods, reference data, proof of concept implementations, and technical analysis to advance the development and productive use of information technology. ITL's responsibilities include the development of technical, physical, administrative, and management standards and guidelines for the cost-effective security and privacy of sensitive unclassified information in Federal computer systems. This Special Publication 800-series reports on ITL's research, guidance, and outreach efforts in computer security, and its collaborative activities with industry, government, and academic organizations. Technical Specifications STATEMENT OF COMPLIANCE TO TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS Bidders must state in the last column opposite each parameter and required specifications either "Comply" or "Not Comply". All pages must be properly signed. Bidders must state here either "Comply" or "Not Comply" against each of the individual parameters of each Specification stating the corresponding performance parameter of the equipment offered. Statements of "Comply" or "Not Comply" must be supported by evidence in a Bidders Bid and cross-referenced to that evidence. Evidence shall be in the form of manufacturer's un-amended sales literature, unconditional statements of specification and compliance issued by the manufacturer, samples, independent test data etc., as appropriate. A statement that is not supported by evidence or is subsequently found to be contradicted by the evidence presented will render the Bid under evaluation liable for rejection. A statement either in the Bidders statement of compliance or the supporting evidence that is found to be false either during Bid evaluation, post-qualification or the execution of the Contract may be regarded as fraudulent and render the Bidder or supplier liable for prosecution subject to the provisions of ITB Clause above goods manufactured by us. CLARIFICATION AND SETTLEMENT OF CONFLICTING INTERPRETATION OF THE TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS All clarifications regarding the technical specifications stipulated in this section will be clarified by the PN Technical Working Group. SECURITY ORCHESTRATION, AUTOMATION AND RESPONSE (SOAR) 1 lot Orchestrates alerts and logs, including file analysis, network and endpoint monitoring. Records and retains network and endpoint raw data for threat hunting and incident investigation either through the SOAR or other sources like SIEM or IDS. Generates and prioritize actionable intelligence to accelerate or automate incident response and investigations over the PN network 1.1 The system is proven effective and currently in use by the military of origin country or by at least two (2) foreign militaries. title: Anomali_Enterprise_Data_Sheet.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/Cyber Lab and SOC/Proponent's Response to RFQ-20191118T225022Z-001/Proponent_s Response to RFQ/SAFE-AXS/SAFE-AXS - PNAVY/Anomali_Enterprise_Data_Sheet.pdf
author: System
content: Real-Time Forensics Every day new threats are discovered, adding to the list of millions of known Indicators of Compromise (IOCs). This presents organizations with two challenges: Evaluating newly identified threats to identify an existing breach Checking millions of IOCs daily to identify newly launched attacks The first challenge is especially critical. As new threats become known, organizations need to know if attackers have already targeted and breached their networks. This means being able to look over historical data going back 6 months or longer to identify potential breaches. The second challenge, checking millions of IOCs daily for new matches, addresses the need for organizations to maintain visibility into emerging threats to the network. Detecting New Threats To determine if their organization was breached, security teams must take new threat intelligence and find any matches against recorded network activity over months or even years. Anomali developed the Real-Time Forensics (RTF) technology to complete searches over vast quantities of historical data in seconds instead of hours/days. RTF is the foundation of Anomali Enterprise, providing security teams instant visibility across all historical data. Detecting Existing Threats Security teams are simultaneously charged with live monitoring their organization's health by comparing new traffic against known threats. Threat intelligence indicators can easily run into millions of indicators, each needing to be evaluated against internal log events. Anomali Enterprise is purpose-built to perform this massive scale intelligence matching, capable of processing millions of IOCs and billions of internal log entries. Positively identified "indicators of interest" are automatically fed to the SIEM for ongoing monitoring or blocking. Indicators can also be enriched or added to investigations in ThreatStream, Anomali's Threat Intelligence Platform (TIP). Security teams can easily collaborate leveraging Anomali Enterp

title: install.txt
author: System
content: The FPDF library is made up of the following elements: - the main file, fpdf.php, which contains the class - the font definition files located in the font directory The font definition files are necessary as soon as you want to output some text in a document. If they are not accessible, the SetFont() method will produce the following error: FPDF error: Could not include font definition file Remarks: - Only the files corresponding to the fonts actually used are necessary - The tutorials provided in this package are ready to be executed

Pursuant to Republic Act (RA) No. 10349, An Act Amending Republic Act No. 7898, Establishing the Revised AFP Modernization Program and for Other Purposes, it is the policy of the State to modernize the AFP to a level where it can effectively and fully perform its constitutional mandate to uphold the sovereignty and preserve the patrimony of the Republic of the Philippines. 1.1.2. The Revised AFP Modernization Program shall have the following objectives: (a) To develop the capability of the AFP to uphold the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Republic and to secure the national territory from all forms of intrusion and encroachment; (b) To develop its capability to assist civilian agencies in the preservation of the national patrimony, including the country's living and nonliving marine, submarine, mineral, forest and other natural resources located within its territory and its exclusive economic zone; (c) To enhance its capability to fulﬁll its mandate to protect the Filipino people not only from armed threats but from the ill effects of life- threatening and destructive consequences of natural and man-made disasters and calamities, including typhoons, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, major accidents in far-ﬂung or inaccessible terrain or at sea and from all forms of ecological damage; (d) To improve its capability to assist other agencies in the enforcement of domestic and foreign policies as well as international covenants against piracy, white slavery, smuggling, drug

title: 20k_c2.txt
author: System
content: During the period in which these developments were occurring, I had returned from a scientific undertaking organized to explore the Nebraska badlands in the United States. In my capacity as Assistant Professor at the Paris Museum of Natural History, I had been attached to this expedition by the French government. After spending six months in Nebraska, I arrived in New York laden with valuable collections near the end of March. My departure for France was set for early May. In the meantime, then, I was busy classifying my mineralogical, botanical, and zoological treasures when that incident took place with the Scotia. I was perfectly abreast of this question, which was the big news of the day, and how could I not have been? I had read and reread every American and European newspaper without being any farther along. This mystery puzzled me. Finding it impossible to form any views, I drifted from one extreme to the other. Something was out there, that much was certain, and any doubting Thomas was invited to place his finger on the Scotia's wound. When I arrived in New York, the question was at the boiling point. The hypothesis of a drifting islet or an elusive reef, put forward by people not quite in their right minds, was completely eliminated. And indeed, unless this reef had an engine in its belly, how could it move about with such prodigious speed? Also discredited was the idea of a floating hull or some other enormous wreckage, and again because of this speed of movement. So only two possible solutions to the question were left, creating two very distinct groups of supporters: on one side, those favoring a monster of colossal strength; on the other, those favoring an "underwater boat" of tremendous motor power. Now then, although the latter hypothesis was completely admissible, it couldn't stand up to inquiries conducted in both the New World and the Old. That a private individual had such a mechanism at his disposal was less than probable. Where and when had he b

title: 20k_c1.txt
author: System
content: The year 1866 was marked by a bizarre development, an unexplained and downright inexplicable phenomenon that surely no one has forgotten. Without getting into those rumors that upset civilians in the seaports and deranged the public mind even far inland, it must be said that professional seamen were especially alarmed. Traders, shipowners, captains of vessels, skippers, and master mariners from Europe and America, naval officers from every country, and at their heels the various national governments on these two continents, were all extremely disturbed by the business. In essence, over a period of time several ships had encountered "an enormous thing" at sea, a long spindle-shaped object, sometimes giving off a phosphorescent glow, infinitely bigger and faster than any whale. The relevant data on this apparition, as recorded in various logbooks, agreed pretty closely as to the structure of the object or creature in question, its unprecedented speed of movement, its startling locomotive power, and the unique vitality with which it seemed to be gifted. If it was a cetacean, it exceeded in bulk any whale previously classified by science. No naturalist, neither Cuvier nor Lacépède, neither Professor Dumeril nor Professor de Quatrefages, would have accepted the existence of such a monster sight unseen -- specifically, unseen by their own scientific eyes. Striking an average of observations taken at different times -- rejecting those timid estimates that gave the object a length of 200 feet, and ignoring those exaggerated views that saw it as a mile wide and three long--you could still assert that this phenomenal creature greatly exceeded the dimensions of anything then known to ichthyologists, if it existed at all. Now then, it did exist, this was an undeniable fact; and since the human mind dotes on objects of wonder, you can understand the worldwide excitement caused by this unearthly apparition. As for relegating it to the realm of fiction, that charge had to be dropp

author: System
content: Collateral Type Identifier IBM Business Unit Identifier Industry Identifier IBM QRadar SIEM Today's networks are more complex than ever before, and protecting them from increasingly malicious and sophisticated attackers is a never-ending task. Organizations seeking to protect their customers' identities, safeguard their intellectual property and avoid business disruption need to proactively monitor their environment so that they can rapidly detect threats and accurately respond before attackers are able to cause material damage. IBM QRadar® Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) is designed to provide security teams with centralized visibility into enterprise-wide security data and actionable insights into the highest priority threats. As a first step, the solution ingests a vast amount of data throughout the enterprise to provide a comprehensive view of activity throughout on-premises and cloud-based environments. As data is ingested, QRadar applies real-time, automated security intelligence to quickly and accurately detect and prioritize threats. Actionable alerts provide greater context into potential incidents, enabling security analysts to swiftly respond to limit the attackers' impact. Unlike other solutions, only QRadar is purpose-built to address security use cases and intentionally designed to easily scale with limited customization effort required. Gain comprehensive, centralized visibility Enterprise networks can span across traditional on-premises IT, cloud-based and operational technology (OT) environments, all of which require some level of oversight to effectively protect assets, accurately detect threats and maintain compliance. Before security teams can start analyzing data to detect and manage threats, they must first have centralized visibility into disparate security data. QRadar enables organizations to gain centralized, comprehensive visibility into siloed environments by collecting, parsing and normalizing both log and flow data. Hig

content: EB-2055 DATASHEET Deliver perfect presentations with a projector offering a brightness of 5,000 lumens and intuitive features, such as Gesture Presenter. Bring sharp images and bright colours to any meeting room with our super- bright new business projector, which offers an outstanding brightness level of 5,000 lumens and XGA resolution. The EB-2055 is designed to project a scalable image up to a massive 300 inches, and offers stream and share wireless connectivity using Epson's Multi-PC projection or the Epson iProjection App. Up to 300-inch display and outstanding quality Epson's 3LCD technology ensures high-quality content has more vivid colours and brighter images. HDMI connectivity guarantees sharper and clearer content, even at the maximum image size of 300 inches. Simple setup and connectivity The EB-2055 offers stream and share wireless LAN connectivity using Epson's Multi-PC projection or our Epson iProjection App and two HDMI connections. Setup is easy too, thanks to features including auto-power-on, focus help, keystone correction and screen fit - allowing the user to deliver presentations quickly and effectively. Keep costs down Project for longer with improved reliability and a longer lamp life of up to 10,000 hours in eco mode. Home screen The home screen offers quick and easy access to a variety of useful functions, such as connection sources. Wireless connections can also be made easily using the information on screen. Gesture Presenter Change slides by simply moving your hand, making even smarter presentations a reality by liberating the user from their remote control or mouse. content: There's no shortage of new indicators of compromise (IOCs), malicious IPs, and CVEs. The irony is that the more of these indicators that flood in, the more overwhelmed and ineffective your SOC and threat intelligence teams become. The increasing velocity of threat data makes it impossible to manually compare it against logs to find matches to known threat sources. Centralizing and enriching your IOC feeds is critical to maximize their value without overwhelming your team. Solution Overview The IntSights Threat Intelligence Platform (TIP) centralizes and operationalizes thousands of sources of intelligence for streamlined investigation and faster threat blocking. IOCs are enriched using your digital assets and prioritized by severity, bringing context and clarity to your threat feeds. Our visualized investigation dashboard enables you to see how new campaigns are connected to known malicious assets and coordinate your response appropriately. Gain visibility and enhance your ability to continuously monitor and mitigate the malicious external threats that pose the greatest danger to your organization. Key Benefits Streamlined security operations Integrated external and internal threat protection Deep investigation analysis Fewer duplicates and false positives Accelerated response Automated threat blocking IntSights has enabled us to automate and operationalize our threat intelligence program. We're not just finding new threats, we're also taking quick action via automated blocking and external takedowns, enabling us to mitigate threats proactively without putting a burden on our team." -Yaniv Mizrahi SOC Manager, Teva Discover and dismantle cyberattacks early in the kill chain IntSights is revolutionizing cybersecurity operations with the industry's only all-in-one external threat protection platform designed to neutralize cyberattacks outside the wire. Whether executed by hacktivists to draw attention to a cause, fraudsters trying to illegally obtain data or funds, or a result of geopolitical events, DDoS attacks are a destructive cyber weapon. Governments, utilities, financial services and commercial institutions face daily attacks. Preparing for "common" DDoS attacks is no longer enough. Thanks to the growing array of online marketplaces, it is now possible for hackers to wreak havoc with virtually no knowledge of computer programming or networks. The Tenable.scTM platform provides the most comprehensive and integrated view of enterprise security posture so you can accurately identify, investigate and prioritize vulnerabilities. VULNERABILITY MANAGEMENT MANAGED ON-PREM Tenable.sc is a vulnerability management solution that provides visibility into your attack surface so you can manage and measure your cyber risk. Tenable.sc does this through advanced analytics, customizable dashboards/reports and workflows to identify weaknesses on your network connected assets, by identifying all vulnerabilities, misconfigurations and malware on them. Built on leading Nessus technology, Tenable.sc gathers and evaluates vulnerability data across multiple Nessus® scanners distributed across your enterprise and illustrates vulnerability trends over time to assess risk and prioritize vulnerabilities. Finally, Tenable.sc includes a configurable workflow engine that helps your security team speed up response and remediation, to reduce overall risk and streamline compliance. Tenable.sc includes Predictive Prioritization, which combines data and threat intelligence across multiple sources, and analyzes them all with a data science algorithm that uses machine learning to anticipate the probability of a vulnerability being leveraged by threat actors. You get real-time insight to help you prioritizing patching and understand which vulnerabilities to remediate first. title: Team 1.docx
author: System
content: Team1 - Teams will be ranked based on points they acquired for each scenario. Their rank in each scenario determines their round scores. The following table shows the corresponding round scores that will be awarded for teams depending on their rank. Rank Scenario 1 Scenario 2 Scenario 3 Scenario 4 Scenario 5 1st 200 217 237 261 291 2nd 180 195 213 235 262 3rd 160 174 190 209 233 4th 140 152 166 183 203 5th 120 130 142 157 174 The team with the highest total score wins the competition. Scoring Per Scenario The competition is comprised of several different scenarios, each with specific objectives that competitors must achieve to gain points. For each scenario, the teams will submit a report of their accomplishments which will be evaluated and verified by the Attack Task Group (ATG) to determine the total points acquired by each team. Verification shall be performed in a combination of automated and by manual review process of the reports and evidences presented. For automated evaluation by a computer program or script, the teams will be provided with a formatted template with clear specifications that must be strictly followed. No considerations will be given for wrong specification of data that may be unreadable by evaluation scripts. In cases of tie, the time of the submission of the report shall be the basis for ranking. Each scenario have a unique set of objectives and, therefore, teams will have different ways of earning points. Capture the Flag The objective is to capture as many flags as possible. Analyze all acquired information because they may be used in future scenarios Rank Scenario 1 Scenario 2 Scenario 3 Scenario 4 Scenario 5 1st 200 217 237 261 291 2nd 180 195 213 235 262 3rd 160 174 190 209 233 4th 140 152 166 183 203 5th 120 130 142 157 174 Network Discovery For this scenario, the objective is to discover the network and come up with a network map. Each team will identify the hosts, its running services, network devices, and determine how they are con

title: Letter to NPC.pdf
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila   COMMISSIONER RAYMUND ENRIQUEZ LIBORO. PRIVACY COMMISSIONER AND CHAIRMAN National Privacy Commission PICC Building Roxas Blvd. Metro Manila Attention: Conrad Dela Cruz IT Officer I Compliance and Monitoring Division Dear Commissioner Liboro: The Philippine Navy(PN) will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019(CyDEx 2019) on 15 to 26 July at Philippine Navy Ofﬁcer Club, Fort Bonifacio, Taguig City. The objective of this exercise is to evaluate the responsiveness and effectiveness of the existing PN doctrines, procedures, and protocols in cyber warfare. In view thereof, the PN Team respectfully request for a courtesy call on the Commissioner’s or any of his concerned staff's most convenient schedule to further discuss and articulate the intent of the command on this upcoming event, and the needed participation of the NPC. Should the good Commissioner ﬁnds merit on this request, LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, Chief Cyber Warfare Department,N6 with mobile phone number 0917-8095116 will coordinate the other details on this matter. Thank you and more power! Sincerely, FOR THE FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND, PN: ER E NICANOR Colonel PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4lSR Systems, N6

author: System
content: Blue Team Students will acquire advanced practical knowledge in the eld of investigation and protection of the organization. Red Team Students will acquire practical experience in the offensive world, and specialize as offensive teams of the cyber security industry. Cyberium Arena Advanced Training Platform Offensive and defensive simulations are designed to teach students the attacker state-of-mind. This allows for a better understanding and placement of security measures needed when dealing with security threats. ThinkCyber has developed a unique training platform designed to challenge the students way of thinking when it comes to cyber defense - the Cyberium Arena. Cyberium Arena is an advanced simulation platform that provides realistic training scenarios to improve the performance of your organization's security team. The platform is suited for small and large-scale organizations, military, police units, government departments and students. While inside the Cyberium Arena, you will need to carry out complex computer tasks, analyze intricate cyber events and master effective security methodology. Among the scenarios you can practice and investigate: malware intrusion and detection, DDoS attacks, cyber forensics and much more. Prominent Advantages: Upgrading response capabilities to cyber-attack events. Acquiring the skills to solve incidents through teamwork. Understanding threat mitigation on a practical level. Acquiring familiarity with the latest threats. Grasping the "attacker state of mind". Cyberium Course Program The Cyberium program provides theoretical and practical knowledge required for senior positions in the Cybersecurity industry. The program covers advanced technical skills and techniques for dealing with complex defensive and offensive operations in the cyber world. Throughout the course, students will be taught the core subjects of Cyber Security, enabling them to prepare for a later specialization in Red-Blue team practical simulations. The cou

author: System
content: ThinkCyber is an Israeli Cyber Security consulting and training company, the company is composed of a group of professionals and industry talents, focusing on developing new knowledge, tools and techniques in the world of Cyber Security. The company offers professional consultation and training services to a wide range of government entities, military, police units, colleges and business organizations from around the world. We also provide solutions on Penetration Testing, Cyber Forensics and SCADA Security. It is our core belief that constant research and exploration of innovative technologies is vital in today's cyber-world. Because of this, our dedicated team has set the goal of always staying up-to-date and uncover new techniques when dealing with cybercrime. Keeping up-to-date with all emerging cyber technologies and trends. Creating our own customized Linux OS. Developing an advanced, live training platform. Experimenting with existing and new tools to further develop our potential and capabilities. Conducting and developing training courses. Constructing training courseware, including curriculum building and academic consulting. Providing instructors to leading colleges. Evaluation and preparation of next-generation instructors. Advising on different features of security software and hardware solutions. Conducting comprehensive penetration tests. Performing comprehensive assessments and forensics. Consulting on building necessary defense systems for various organizations.

title: Welcome Remarks N6B-Letter to Secretary Rio.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/CYDEX/Welcome Remarks N6B-Letter to Secretary Rio.docx
author: System
content: SECRETARY ELISEO M RIO JR. Department of Information and Communications Technology C.P Garcia Ave., Diliman Quezon City Dear Secretary Rio: Greetings! The Philippine Navy (PN) will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019 (CyDEx 2019-03) on 15 to 26 July at Philippine Navy Officer Club, Marine Base Rudiardo Brown (MBRB), Fort Bonifacio, Taguig City to test and evaluate the effectiveness and responsiveness of the existing cyber doctrines, organization, infrastructure, policies, and procedures. Similarly, following are the objectives of this exercise: To test and evaluate existing operations-related policies in developing capabilities in cyberspace operations; Provide basis for the development of plans, programs, strategies, and Techniques, Tactics, and Procedures (TTPs); Test and evaluate the PN Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) and Information Security Management Systems (ISMS) Incident Handling Procedures; and, Validate PN Cyber Reservist and Cyber Solutions by industry partners for seamless integration whenever required. In view hereof, the PN Team respectfully requests for the presence of the Secretary to be the Guest of Honor and Speaker during the opening ceremony on 15 0900H July 2019 at the above-mentioned venue. Moreover, we are requesting for available subject matter expert (SME) to provide the attendees insights on the "Philippine Government Third Telco Initiative" during the Training and Awareness Seminar portion of the CyDex on 15 July 2019. Further, this Command also requests THREE CYBER PERSONNEL organic to the organization to compose the Red Team during the conduct of exercise proper on 22-26 July 2019. Should the good Secretary finds merit on this request, LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN, Chief Cyber Warfare Department, N6 with mobile phone number 0917-8095116 will coordinate the other details on this matter. Thank you and more power! Sincerely, ROBERT A EMPEDRAD Vice Admiral AFP Flag Officer in Command, PN

title: Data Privacy Manual_03_June_2019.docx
author: System
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Letter of Promulgation i Foreword iii Preface v Table of Contents vii Section Title Page CHAPTER 1 – INTRODUCTION 1-1 Background 1 1-2 Data Privacy Principle 1 1-3 Rights of Data Subjects 2 1-4 Processing of Personal Data in the PN 3 CHAPTER 2 – PRIVACY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 1-1 Organizational Chart 1-1 1-2 Data Protection Officer 1-1 1-3 Notices, Requests, Inquiries, and Complaints 1-2 1-3 Program Report 1-2 1-3 Compliance Roadmap 1-2 CHAPTER 3 – POLICY AND SECURITY MEASURE 1-1 Organizational Security Measure 1-1 1-2 Technical Security Measure 1-1 1-3 Physical Security Measure 1-2 CHAPTER 4 – DATA BREACH AND SECURITY INCIDENT 1-1 Computer Emergency Response Team 1-1 1-2 Duties and Procedure 1-1 CHAPTER I INTRODUCTION Section 1-1 Background The Data Privacy Act of 2012 is an Act protecting individual personal information consistent with the Philippines' policy of protecting the fundamental human right of privacy, while ensuring free flow of information. To promote such policy, the Act, along with its IRR, shall govern the processing of personal data by any natural or juridical person in the government or private sector, who must in turn establish policies and implement measures to guarantee the security of personal data under their control and/or custody. With the Data Privacy Act, other pertinent laws, and the principles of transparency, legitimate purpose, and proportionality as its backdrop, the Philippine Navy (PN) abides by this Manual in carrying out its mission. This is to ensure that personal data under its control remain safe and secured while being processed in the course of its key operations and processes. This Manual aims to inform PN personnel, dependents, and stakeholders of the organization's data protection and security measures, and to guide them in the exercise of their rights under the Data Privacy Act and other relevant regulations and policies. Section 1-3 Data Privacy Principle In the processing of Personal Data, the PN, its pe

title: PN SOP on CRA_13 Mar 2019.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/SOP/PN SOP on CRA_13 Mar 2019.docx
author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ PHILIPPINE NAVY CYBER RISK ASSESSMENT REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reinforce efforts to address cyber-related issues and develop the PN cyber defense capability, there is a need to first determine the current PN cyber security posture. The best way to accomplish this is through the conduct of a Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA) among PN units. Thus, a standard guide by means of a policy on CRA should be at hand. The SANS Top 20 Critical Security Controls which is being used as a recommended set of actions for cyber defense that provide specific and actionable ways to stop today's most pervasive and dangerous attacks. The SANS Institute, together with the Center for Internet Security (CIS) and other organizations, developed the 20 Critical Security Controls (CSC) for effective cyber defense as a response to the growing security threats. The Controls have best-in-class threat data and transform it into actionable guidance to improve individual and collective security in cyberspace. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units in order to provide adequate cybersecurity controls for the PN. This SOP shall likewise, be the basis for unit Commanders, Heads/Chiefs of offices to determine the unit's cyber security posture. SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software

title: Red Team Assessment.docx
author: System
content: Result of the Scenarios (Objectives) Given to the Red Team The competition is comprised of several different scenarios, each with specific objectives that competitors must achieve to gain points. For each scenario, the teams will submit a report of their accomplishments which will be evaluated and verified by the Attack Task Group (ATG) to determine the total points acquired by each team. Verification is performed in combination of automated and manual review of the reports and evidences presented. For automated evaluation by a computer program or script, the teams will be provided with a formatted template with clear specifications that must be strictly followed. No considerations are given for wrong specification of data that may be unreadable. Each scenario has unique set of objectives and, therefore, teams will have different ways of earning points. Capture the Flag Objective: Red teams compete to gather as many flags as possible from the various challenges given. Result: DICT wins with 1600 point followed by PAF with 1500 and CEISSAFP with 1300 points. Network Discovery Objective: Discover the network and come up with a network map. Each team will identify the hosts, its running services, network devices, and determine how they are connected to each other in the network. A reporting template is distributed for each team to fill-in with the required information. Result: The RESERVIST identified the most number of devices and came up with accurate map of the network. Website Hack Objectives: Hack into the Mock-up ID System Web Server and extract the database of personnel records. Result: The DICT was able to find the vulnerability of the ID System and was able to gain access to all web pages without going through the login page. Several files were extracted from the server. The vulnerability reveals that the web application is not employing session variables. A session is a mechanism to persist information across the different web pages to identify users as they

title: PN SOP on Website_15 Mar 2019.docx
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/SOP/PN SOP on Website_15 Mar 2019.docx
author: System
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ REVISED PN WEBSITE MANAGEMENT REFERENCES: SOP Nr 30 dated 09 Dec 2011, Subject: PN WEBSITE MANAGEMENT. SOP Nr 14 HPN dtd 08 April 2009, Subject: Utilization of PN IT Facilities PURPOSE: This policy provides the guidelines and procedures in the development, administration, utilization, sustainment and further enhancement of Philippine Navy websites SCOPE: This publication covers the provisions for the administration, revision and updating of the information and contents of all websites managed by the PN. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Administrator - the super user or root that has a special user account used for maintaining and operating a computer system. Audit Trail or Audit Log - is a chronological sequence of audit records, each of which contains evidence directing pertaining to and resulting from the execution of a business process or system function. Content Management System (CMS) - is an application software developed for facilitating the maintenance of the content and not the design of a web· site. A "blogging tool" is an example of a Content Management System. cPANEL - a popular web-based administration tool used by the host providers, the PN in this particular case, to allow users (PN units) to configure their own websites using an easy-to-use interface. Domain name – is an address in the internet where the website can be accessed. It is used to identify entities on the Internet rather than using IP addresses or lengthy numbers. Filip Transfer Protocol (FTP) - is rather predictably, a client-server protocol for transferring files. It is one way to download files, and the most common way to upload files to a server. An FTP client is a program which can download files from, or upload files to, an FTP server. Interactive Websites or Transactional Websites - Network Admi

title: J6 STL - Conduct VA Fortifying Network.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/VAPT/J6 Directive - Fortify Network/J6 STL - Conduct VA Fortifying Network.pdf
author: System
content: .-.. r‘ vrorurr .».«u.t:o: /-I VVOHO-CISSS Armed Forces, Source of National Pride GENERAL HEADQUARTERS ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY CHIEF OF STAFF FOR COMMUNICATIONS, ELECTRONICS AND INFORMATION SYSTEMS, J6 Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City CD/6210 1; 2;? .ril~i~l-i 2'0 i 51'' SUBJECT: Conduct of Vulnerability Assessment (VA) and Fortifying Network Defense TO: See Distribution 1 . References: a. STL from CEISSAF P dated 07 March 2019, with Subject: Incident Report of AFPSAT E-Portal; b. CSAFP-noted DF dated 08 April 2019 with subject: Alleged AF P Database Hacking; c. PN SMS re NAVRESCOM Website Hacking. 2. Per above references, the AFP systems and websites had been allegedly attacked. These systems are Internet-facing services where vulnerabilities had been exploited. 3. This Headquarters is coming up with a policy to ensure cybersecurity of systems being deployed in the internet for public access. This aims to standardize and provide guidelines on vulnerability management. 4. As initial response measures, the GHQ and Major Services’ respective CEIS/cyber units are hereby directed to fortify their network defense. 5. Speciﬁcally ensure that the following guidelines related to VA are applied: a. Conduct inventory of websites/application systems that are accessed using the internet; b. Conduct vulnerability assessment (VA) based on priority of websites/systems using automated/manual or open-source/proprietary VA tools; c. Mitigate/address known vulnerabilities until it yields “low” to “no" vulnerabilities; d. Conduct a regular VA to systems/websites; e. AFP cyber units and system administrators to collaborate in order to address the vulnerabilities; f. For result of “high” risk, make the service (websites/systems) unavailable as necessary. AFP Core Values.‘ Honor, Service, Patriotism

title: MFR-NORS.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPNAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 08 January 2018 MEMORANDUM for- AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: After conference report on NORS development using GIS The Chief of Cyber Warfare Branch, ON6 together with CDR SALVADOR SAMBALILO PN, LCDR MARK S FRANCISCO PN, LCDR REYNAN N CARRIDO PN, CPT JEAN PAUL T SAN GABRIEL PN(M), LT JOEY M CALLUENG PN, LTJG JOMAR M WELBA PN and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro, facilitated the conference for the development of NORS through customization of GIS by GEODATA Inc. last 20 December 2017. The enhancement of GIS is part of the deliverables for the MITHI-COP Project. Representatives from GeoData demonstrated how the recently upgraded GIS server can be customized to allow incident reporting for the PN. The Incident Map of the GIS is similar to the NORS requirement this office sought. The following are action items resolved from the discussion: Basic GIS training shall be conducted to provide end users with the fundamental concept of the GIS and its application to the PN. It is scheduled on Jan 23-25 2018; Following the basic training is a workshop to be facilitated by this office involving representatives from ON2, NISF, NOC, NFOC, NICTC, F6, MC2, and other participants who attended the basic training. They shall provide the necessary requirements as inputs to the NORS development. It is scheduled on the 29th of January; GeoData will then customize the built-in Incident Map of the GIS based from the consolidated requirement of NORS. This shall cover tailor-fitting indent report map for the operation centers, and customizing client-side GeoForm for the PN Units; Upon completion of the customized NORS-GIS application, end users and GIS operators shall be trained for the utilization of the NORS; Separate training shall be given to the administrator who will maintain the GIS and the NORS application. This branch will ende

title: circular-ipms-03.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N1 CIRCULAR NUMBER ____ Utilization of Integrated Personnel Management System version 2012 (IPMSv12) REFERENCE: SOP Nr 11, "PHILIPPINE NAVY INTEGRATED PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM" dtd 13 April 2011 PURPOSE: This circular provides supplemental policies for SOP Nr 11, "PHILIPPINE NAVY INTEGRATED PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM" dtd 13 April 2011, in order to delineate personnel information management utilizing the Integrated Personnel Management System as the official repository system of all personnel-related information. BACKGROUND: The continuous evolution of the Philippine Navy Integrated Personnel Management System (PN-IPMS) comes with the delivery of more personnel-oriented services. This materialized with the launching of Integrated Personnel Management System version 2012, appropriately termed as IPMSv12 to refer to the year it was launched. With the official activation of the PN Payroll Module of the IPMSv12, the processing of personnel pay, allowances, collateral and other claims becomes faster, secured and with lesser effort. However, the accuracy of individual personnel records stored in the system is a critical requirement since it becomes the basis for all financial calculations for personnel services. In order to avoid erroneous and delayed payments, it is important to ensure the completeness and accuracy of individual personnel records in the system. Thus, the IPMSv12 must be recognized and utilized as the official personnel data repository system of the Philippine Navy in order to centralize the management of information. PERSONNEL RECORDS: Personnel records include but shall not be limited to all records in the individual Military Personnel File (201 File) such as the following: Personal Information Military Service History Previous assignments Additional/Special Duties Schooling Promotion/Demotion Leave Records Unit Adjutan

title: MFR-IPMS-Launching.docx
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPNAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) OFFICE of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila 10 January 2018 MEMORANDUM for- AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6 Subj: After conference report on NORS development using GIS The Chief of Cyber Warfare Branch, ON6 together with CAPT JOB J PABLICO PN(GSC), CAPT MARCOS Y IMPERIO PN(GSC), CDR EDWIN R BEGONIA PN, CDR SALVADOR SAMBALILO PN(GSC), representatives from O/N1,CNH,NPMC,OTNA, and Mr. Nelson G. Maligro, attended the coordinating conference ICOW the launching of the following PN Information Systems: PN Information Exchange (PNIX) Text Messaging System; PN Knowledge Management System – a web based e-learning system; IPMS Records Module; PN Medical Information Computerized System (MEDICS); OESPA SALN Management System (OSMS); and IPMS Payroll Module. NICTC will demonstrate these systems as proof of capability to provide records automation and message security during its launching on the 17th of January 2018. While several issues were raised during the discussion, the following items are resolved for the successful conduct of the demonstration and proper implementation of these information systems: NICTC will continue to push the major units to update the records in the IPMS as this problem intertwines other modules used by various stakeholder units resulting to underutilization and un-appreciation; Fund is now available for the procurement of computer hardware and other equipment to be utilized for the IPMS; (i-verify pa daw ito ni LCDR BERMEO sir) NICTC proposed to install the PNIX to all key officers in parallel to the POLARIS rather than depreciating the latter from the former; Statement of Service and Leave Balance will highlight the OTNA Records module during the demonstration. NICTC will look into the issue of duplication and fraudulent entry of IPMS data by malicious encoders through the audit logs of the system; and NICTC will develop another IPMS
