author: System
content: GENERAL HEADQUARTERS ARMED FORCES OF THE PHILIPPINES OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY CHEF OF STAFF FOR COMMUNICATIONS, ELECTROMCS AND ENFORMAWON SYSTEMS, J6 Camp General Emilio Aguinaldo, Quezon City CD/6210  E  29??’ SUBJECT: Conduct of Vulnerability Assessment (VA) and Fortifying Network Defense i To: See mstribution 1 . References: a. STL from CEISSAF P dated 07 March 2019, with Subject: incident Report of AFPSAT E-Pcrtai; b. CSAFP-noted DF dated 08 April 2019 with subject: Alleged AFP Database Hacking; c. PN SMS re NAVRESCOM Website Hacking. 2. Per above references, the AFP systems and websites had been allegedly attacked. These systems are internet—facing services where vulnerabilities had been exploited. 3. This Headquarters is coming up with a policy to ensure cybersecurity of systems being deployed in the lnternet for public access. This aims to standardize and provide guidelines on vulnerability management. 4. As initial response measures, the GHQ and Major Services’ respective CElSfcyber units are hereby directed to fortify their network defense. 5. Speciﬁcally ensure that the following guidelines related to VA are appﬁed: a. Conduct inventory of vvebsiteslappiication systems that are accessed using the internet; b. Conduct vulnerability assessment (VA) based on priority of vvebsitesisystems using automatedlmanual or open-sotircelproprietary VA toois; c. Mitigate/address known vulnerabilities until it yields “low” to “no” vulnerabilities; d. Conduct a reguiar VA to systems/websites; e. AFP cyber units and system administrators to collaborate in order to address the vulnerabilities; f. For result of "high” risk, make the service (websites/systems) unavailable as necessary. title: Data Privacy Manual_30_May_2019.docx
author: System
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Letter of Promulgation i Foreword iii Preface v Table of Contents vii Section Title Page CHAPTER 1 – INTRODUCTION 1-1 Background 1 1-2 Data Privacy Principle 1 1-3 Rights of Data Subjects 2 1-4 Processing of Personal Data in the PN 3 CHAPTER 2 – PRIVACY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 1-1 Organizational Chart 1-1 1-2 Data Protection Officer 1-1 1-3 Notices, Requests, Inquiries, and Complaints 1-2 1-3 Program Report 1-2 1-3 Compliance Roadmap 1-2 CHAPTER 3 – POLICY AND SECURITY MEASURE 1-1 Organizational Security Measure 1-1 1-2 Technical Security Measure 1-1 1-3 Physical Security Measure 1-2 CHAPTER 4 – DATA BREACH AND SECURITY INCIDENT 1-1 Computer Emergency Response Team 1-1 1-2 Duties and Procedure 1-1 CHAPTER I INTRODUCTION Section 1-1 Background The Data Privacy Act of 2012 is an Act protecting individual personal information consistent with the Philippines' policy of protecting the fundamental human right of privacy, while ensuring free flow of information. To promote such policy, the Act, along with its IRR, shall govern the processing of personal data by any natural or juridical person in the government or private sector, who must in turn establish policies and implement measures to guarantee the security of personal data under their control and/or custody. With the Data Privacy Act, other pertinent laws, and the principles of transparency, legitimate purpose, and proportionality as its backdrop, the Philippine Navy (PN) abides by this Manual in carrying out its mission. This is to ensure that personal data under its control remain safe and secured while being processed in the course of its key operations and processes. This Manual aims to inform PN personnel, dependents, and stakeholders of the organization's data protection and security measures, and to guide them in the exercise of their rights under the Data Privacy Act and other relevant regulations and policies. Section 1-2 Data Privacy Principle In the Processing of Personal Data, the PN, its pe

title: PRIVACY IMPACT ASSESSMENT.docx
author: System
content: PRIVACY IMPACT ASSESSMENT This Privacy Impact Assessment ("PIA") seeks to identify the risks associated in the collection, recording, organization, storage, modification, retrieval, use, consolidation, and destruction of personal data that flows within the PN. The conduct or risk-based privacy impact assessment allows the PN to determine the reasonable measure of data security and privacy that should accordingly be adopted. General Information Below is the inventory of personal data and information systems held by the PN: Inventory of Personal Data 1. Summary of Information (SOI) 2. Personal Data Sheets (PDS) 3. Patient Records 4. Reservists Information 5. Scholastic Records Inventory of Information Systems 1. Integrated Personnel Management System (IPMS) 2. Medical Information Computerized Systems (MedICS) 3. Naval Reserve Center Management Information System (NRCMIS) 4. Civilian Employee Biographic Information System (CEBIS) To ensure that all information flows are identified, PN personnel of varying positions and functions within the units/offices are invited to participate in the PIA. Below is the form used to identify the team composition: General Information of the PIA Member Name of PN Personnel: Designation/ Position PN Unit/ Office Description of unit/office in relation to personal data processing Threshold Analysis The Threshold Analysis seeks to identify the existing information flows within the PN units/offices. The first step is to determine if any personal or sensitive personal information is processed. Does the unit/office handle any of the following information pertaining to personnel records: Name Marital Status Education Home Addresses Photograph Health Email Addresses Biometrics History of Misdemeanors/Violations Business Addresses Color, Race, or Ethnic Origin Telephone Numbers Religious Beliefs or Affiliation TIN/ Government IDs Age Political Orientation Education Birthdays Sexual Orientation Health Does the unit/office handle any other informa

content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 President Roxas Boulevard, Manila   99 Arie 2015 O/N1 SUBJECT: Letter of Instruction Nr 01 (lPMSv12 Audit and Training) T0: See Distribution 1. SITUATION: The Phase 1 of lPMSv12 software started on 20 May 2012 with its implementation at NPMC and OTNA. in this phase, assignment orders to Major Units of personnel are being transmitted electronically by NPMC to OTNA for the publication of orders through the system. Concurrently during this period, OTNA undertook encoding of HPN orders for awards, enlistment, reenlistment, leave, long pay, ETAD, retirement, reinstatement. reappointment. civilian service. CAD. promotion/demotion covering the years 1995 to 2013. This information automatically enters into the lPMSv12 version of Statement of Service (S03) and Summary of Information (SOI) of personnel that are viewable at NPMC and OTNA and various PN Systems Portal Kiosks deployed at selected areas. On the other hand, the Phase 2 of the software’s implementation covering the 22 major units of the Navy started with the completion of the lPMSv12 Phase 2a Connectivity Project on 18 June 2013. Said connectivity provided the adjutants and admin personnel the capability to encode awards, assignment, reenlistment and leave orders issued by their respective units. This also allowed the major units to view PNCCS clearances, SOI, S08 and other reports generated by |PMSv12. The most important activity that must be done by the major unit is the rendering of change in personnel status through the Electronic Change in Personnel Status (eCH|PS) report in order to achieve secure, reliable and timely monitoring and accounting of personnel. Recently, the IPMS Center was launched to cater the editing of all personnel information on the system. Personnel from different units were catered by the Center in order to update their personal information. To further increase the involvement of th

title: implan nr 004 [development and implementation sms apps.pdf

author: System
content: PHILIPPINE NAVY NAVAL INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGY CENTER Naval Base Heracleo Aiano Sangley Point, Cavite City O/lCTC3 SUBJECT: NICTC IMPLAN Nr  to HPN LOI Nr 002-17 (Development and Implementation Short Messaging System (SMS) Application) TO: See Distribution I. SITUATION: Smart phones are convenient and efficient means for Command and Control (C2) between the senior officers and the Headquarters Philippine Navy (HPN) thru the Fleet — Marine Collaboration Mobile Phone (FMCMP). These systems operate using the commercial telecommunication providers which makes them vulnerable to communication breaches and information leaks. On this, the Philippine Navy (PN) employed smart phones which are equipped with an encrypted short messaging (SMS) application to ensure the confidentiality, integrity and availability of classified information. As a need for secured SMS, Secret Message Elite was adopted, however, appeared to have cut short of the growing demand for ease of employment and message size. Hence, the Naval Intelligence Security Force (NISF) initiated the development of a better alternative to the Secure Message Elite, the Polaris SMS. The said system was an android messaging application developed by TIG, NISF on December 2016 called “Polaris SMS”. It was developed to cater the needs of the NISFIPN Intel officesfunits for a more secured way of transmitting information through short messaging service using an open source code. In this connection, the Naval Information and Communications Technology Center (NICTC) were tasked to conduct assessment, validation and corrective measure on the said system prior deployment for PN wide use. However, due to none availability of source code from NISF as reference and basis of enhancement, the center shall developlprogram and deploy new systems application similar to Polaris SMS (enhanced and secured version of Polaris SMS) to be deployed to PN wide NLT 01 June 2017. ll. title: OTNA Circular Nr 08 dtd 18 Nov 2019 Philippine Navy Information Infrastracture Configuration Management Policy.pdf
filename: D:/Drive/N6 Works/SOP/OTNA Circular Nr 08 dtd 18 Nov 2019 Philippine Navy Information Infrastracture Configuration Management Policy.pdf
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) SLC:JJAE:LBD:jabf:ade-6416 Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA 18 November 2019 CIRCULAR NUMBER 08 PHILIPPINE NAVY INFORMATION INFRASTRUCTURE CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT POLICY 1. PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third—party stakeholders on the implementation of standard configuration to the cyber security systems, network systems, commerciallcustomized software applications, command and control (C2) systems, communications systems, and intelligence surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) systems that shall be implemented by the Naval Information and Communications Technology Center (NICTC). This policy shall provide standards for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cyber security Policy. Moreover, this policy shall ensure secured configuration of PN Enterprise Network and Information Systems that warrants support to managing security risks. It adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls are mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information techno|ogy—Security Techniques- Information Security Management Systems (|SMS)——-Requirements and SOP Nr 4 dated 30 Jan 2019: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment (CRA). 2. SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY: This policy applies to administrators, users, and other PN units that operate and maintain the PN Enterprise Network and Information Systems. These network and information systems components includes but not limited to the software/applications, operating system/firmware, and hardware. 3. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: a. Baseline Configuration - a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or config

content: No. Item Qty U/I Specification Comply/Not Comply Attachment (Reference, Brochure, Datasheet) 1 SECURITY ORCHESTRATION, AUTOMATION AND RESPONSE (SOAR) 1 lot Orchestrates alerts and logs, including file analysis, network and endpoint monitoring. Records and retains network and endpoint raw data for threat hunting and incident investigation either through the SOAR or other sources like SIEM or IDS. Generates and prioritize actionable intelligence to accelerate or automate incident response and investigations over the PN network Comply Resolve is compliant. From the Resolve Security Dashboard, SecOps Analysts will have a single view of all security incidents and tickets (SIR's). Within each Security Incident Record (or "SIR") you will find the summary, artifacts, attachments and notes. You can also assign additional team members to the investigation, review any associated incidents as well as the execution history. From this window you can also view the Playbook (knkowledge blended with automations) and Activity Timeline. 1.1 The system is proven effective and currently in use by the military of origin country or by at least two (2) foreign militaries. Comply Resolve is not a vendor exlusively servicing government entities, customer is confidential and sold through Federal certified partners. 1.2 Perpetual license to use and operate Comply Resolve is compliant. content: "The NAVY: Protecting the Seas, Securing our Future" DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (If any) File Number: N6B-0219- Subject: Availability of Funds to Support the Repair and Maintenance of C4ISR Systems Requirements for the Establishment of Computer Laboratory and Standardization of Operation Center at NLC TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS Date: Comment No:___ VIA: VCOM, PN LCDR BARRACA PN-6390 _________ N6 _________ ________DONFM_______ SUMMARY: Reference: CNLC Letter to FOIC, PN (Attn: N6), Subject: Implementation of C4ISR Projects of NLC Above reference pertains to the request of CNLC for the availability of funds to support the repair and maintenance of C4ISR Systems requirements of the two (2) C4ISR projects namely: Projects Amount Standardization of Naval Logistics Operation Center Php 840,901.00 Establishment and Activation of Computer Laboratory at NLTD, NLC Php 934,384.00 Total Php 1,775,285.00 The above-mentioned projects were previously approved by the FOIC, PN last 22 Dec 2018 however, these were not considered for funding because of the constraint on the budget process. The Standardization of Naval Logistics Operation Center Project aims to enhance situational awareness (SA), achieve Common Operating Picture (COP), and monitor command and control processes for the center. On the other hand, the Computer Laboratory Project aims to enhance the trainings in terms of curriculum research and development, training evaluation, online training and exam, and performance ratings. In this connection, N6 recommends that the fund support for the requirement of NLC with the total amount of PhP 1,775,285.00 be charged to 1st Semester CY2019 Residual Funds subject to SPBAC deliberation. RECOMMENDATION: FOIC, PN approval on the request of CNLC amounting to ONE MILLION SEVEN HUNDRED SEVENTY FIVE THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED EIGHTY FIVE PESOS only (PhP 1,775,285.00) charged to 1ST Semester CY2019 Residual Funds subject to SPBAC deliberation. content: "The NAVY: Protecting the Seas, Securing our Future" DISPOSITION FORM SECURITY CLASSIFICATION (If any) File Number: N6B-0219- Subject: Availability of Funds to Support the Maintenance of Software Licenses TO: FOIC, PN FROM: CNS Date: Comment No:___ VIA: VCOM, PN LCDR BARRACA PN-6390 _________ N6 _________ ________DONFM_______ SUMMARY: Reference: CNICTC Letter to FOIC, PN (Attn: N6), Subject: Availability of Funds for the Procurement of Hardware and Software Requirements of the PN Units, Request for Updates on the Implementation of Software Licenses ISSP 2019-2021 Above reference 1a pertains to the request of CNICTC for the procurement of computer hardware and software licenses in order to address the issue of unlicensed software as a result and findings of the Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing (VAPT) of the twenty two (22) PN units conducted during the AGI. Based on the assessment of the actual inventory and specifications of these computers, several desktops and laptops are obsolete and can no longer support the installation of the latest software specifically the Microsoft Windows 10 Pro operating system. Hence, the NICTC recommends the procurement of software licenses only to computers that meets the minimum requirements for Windows 10 and further recommends the replacement of the obsolete computers with desktops and laptops bundled with Windows 10 pro. Relatedly, this office included the acquisition of several desktop computers in the PN Information Systems Strategic Plan (ISSP) 2019-2021 which was evaluated, reviewed, and endorsed last 02 February 2018 by the DICT (ref 1c). Below is the summary of the obsolete computers less the items enumerated in the ISSP. The resulting variance shall be programmed for next ISSP 2022 to 2024. title: Definition of Terms.docx
author: System
content: 4. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Electronic Documents - information recorded in a manner that requires a computer or other electronic device to display, interpret, and process it. Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Document Security Officer (DSO) – a member of the DASAT/TWG/PMT/TIAC who is competent with the knowledge in handling classified matters; and designated by the Chairman to be responsible for the classification, tagging, de-classification, release, distribution, and safekeeping of all documents pertaining their respective modernization project. Defense Acquisition System Assessment Team (DASAT) - are ad hoc teams conducting assessment and examine proposed materiel approaches for the AFP utilizing the Defense System of Management (DSOM) approaches and develop a brief and comprehensive decision package as a decision making tool for the approval of the DND senior leaders for its big ticket acquisitions, mostly funded out of the modernization fund. The team transitions as the Technical Working Group (TWG) for the procurement phase to be undertaken by the DND Bids and Awards Committee upon issuance of ADM. Technical Working Group (TWG - are groups created to perform such related functions of the BAC from a pool of technical, financial, and/or iegal experts who are trained and satisfactorily completed training or program conducted, authorized or accredited by the GPPB through its Technical Support Office and are capable to assist in the: 1) Review of the Technical Specifications, Scope of Work and Terms of Reference; 2) Preparation of bidding documents; 3) Shorilisting of Suppliers and Consultants; 4) Eligibility Screening; 5) Evaluation of bids; 6) post Qualification; and, 7) Resolutions. author: System
content: Page 1 of 7 PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose V Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila CEIS LETTER DIRECTIVE NUMBER SUBJECT: Guidelines on the Disclosure of Document or Information Pertaining to PN Modernization Projects TO: All Concerned REFERENCE: AFP RG 200-014 – Security of Classified Matter Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017 - PN Cybersecurity Policy CEIS Directive Nr 01 dated 06 January 2015; Subj: Unofficial Internet Posts and Use of Social Media PURPOSE: This directive prescribes the policy and guidelines on the proper disclosure of the documents/information pertaining to PN modernization projects. Likewise, this document provides direction to the members of the Defense Acquisition System Assessment Team (DASAT), DAS Technical Working Group (TWG)/Project Management Team (PMT), Technical Inspection and Acceptance Committee (TIAC), and all PN units and personnel who are directly or indirectly involved in handling, supervising, monitoring, and consulting PN modernization projects. BACKGROUND: The fast-paced technological advancement along with the associated threat is inevitable. The prevalence of smart phones, tablets, laptops, and IOT devices threatens the security of an organization and privacy of a person. People, through these mobile devices, are connected everywhere. Information is shared instantly with just a click of a fingertip. Classified information, such as mission, strategies, concepts of operations, technological specifications, and capability acquisition, is potentially at risk of getting exposed in the public; hence, security and protection of this information is very important. The social media, video sharing, and blogs are widely used technological tool for information dissemination; however, some information were posted without the consent of the PN. Unauthorized disclosure of classified documents containing details and plans of PN modernization projects poses threat to the conduct o

content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA C I R C U L A R NUMBER ____ GUIDELINES ON THE MANAGEMENT AND SECURITY OF PN WEBSITES REFERENCES: SOP Nr 30 dated 09 Dec 2011, Subject: PN WEBSITE MANAGEMENT. NIST Special Publication 800-44 revision 2, Title: Guidelines on Securing Public Web Servers. PURPOSE: This circular provides guidelines and procedures on the development, administration, utilization, sustainment, and security of Philippine Navy websites and public-facing web servers. SCOPE: The provisions of this circular covers PN personnel who are directly or indirectly involved in the management and security of the PN Websites and public facing web servers. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Administrator - the super user or root that has a special user account used for maintaining and operating a computer system. Audit Trail or Audit Log - is a chronological sequence of audit records, each of which contains evidence directing pertaining to and resulting from the execution of a business process or system function. Content Management System (CMS) - is an application software developed for facilitating the maintenance of the content and not the design of a web· site. A "blogging tool" is an example of a Content Management System. cPANEL - a popular web-based administration tool used by the host providers, the PN in this particular case, to allow users (PN units) to configure their own websites using an easy-to-use interface. Domain name – is an address in the internet where the website can be accessed. It is used to identify entities on the Internet rather than using IP addresses or lengthy numbers. Filip Transfer Protocol (FTP) - is rather predictably, a client-server protocol for transferring files. It is one way to download files, and the most common way to upload files to a server. An FTP client is a program which can download files from, or upload files to, an FTP server. Interact

content: SOP Nr ___________HPN dtd _________________ Annex "C" Checklist for Securing the Web Server Completed Action Secure Network Infrastructure Web server is protected by a firewall Firewall blocks all inbound traffic except permitted TCP ports (e.g. 80 and 443) Firewall detects malformed URL requests and blocks (in conjunction with IPS) malicious IP addressess Firewall is configured to protect against DoS attacks Firewall logs critical events and forwarded to Central Log Management System (i.e. SIEM) Web Application Firewall provides content filtering and blocks SQL injection and Command injection attacks. Network IDS/IPS is used to monitor the web server Network IDS/IPS is configured to monitor network traffic and detect anomalies. Host IDS/IPS is installed in the web server Host IDS/IPS or File Integrity checker is configured to monitor changes to critical files Host IDS/IPS is configured to log events and forward to a SIEM or log analysis tools Network and host IDS/IPS is updated with new attack signatures frequently Switches are configured to defeat ARP spoofing and ARP poisoning attacks Switches are configured for port mirroring in order to send all traffic to a network IDS/IPS Network and host IDS/IPS is updated with new attack signatures frequently Load balancer is used to increase web server availability, if applicable Reverse proxy is used to increase web server availability, if applicable Reverse proxy is augmented with encryption acceleration, user authentication, and content filtering capabilities, if applicable Operating System Identify and install all necessary patches and upgrades to the OS Identify and install all necessary patches and upgrades to applications and services included with the OS Identify and mitigate unpatched vulnerabilities Remove or disable unnecessary services and applications Remove or disable unneeded default accounts and groups Create the user accounts and groups for the particular computer Apply password complexity Configure to pr

title: Chapter 4 - 09Apr2020.docx
author: System
content: 51 Chapter 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION This chapter presents the final output of the system and the result of the evaluation. Project description, project structure, and the capabilities and limitations are briefly discussed to elucidate the finished project. The result of the evaluation and its interpretation was also presented in this chapter. Project Description The Cryptographic IM (CIM) system is an instant messaging application that allows data communication among peers. It provides essential features for office collaboration such as one-to-one chat, group chat, file transfer, and others. Multi-layered encryption is integrated into the CIM to provide greater security. Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) and the Hidden in Plain Sight (HIPS) algorithm encrypts the data as it traverses across the network. The system was developed in modules or components making it agile in any type of deployment. Meaning, the CIM can be deployed even without the other modules if it is not required for a particular deployment. There are three (3) modules developed, the base, file transfer, and the encryption module. The base component provides the platform for the two (2) components and other future components to be integrated into. These future components can also be a third-party DLL, API, or SDK. Project Structure The CIM was developed using the Microsoft Visual C# 2017. It runs on both MS Windows 7 and Windows 10 platform and requires dot.Net 4.6 framework. Microsoft Access database engine was included during the installation to allow local storage of user lists and other settings. The figure below shows the final structure of the system. title: DICT Request for lecturer.doc.txt
author: System
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila SECRETARY ELISEO M RIO JR. Department of Information and Communications Technology C.P Garcia Ave., Diliman Quezon City Dear Secretary Rio: The Philippine Navy will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019 (CyDEx 2019) on 15 to 26 July, 2019. This exercise evaluates the responsiveness and effectiveness of the existing PN doctrines, procedures, and protocols in cyber warfare. The exercise will be conducted in two parts namely: 1. Training and Awareness a.k.a. CyDeX 1 — this will be conducted on July 15-19, 2019 at Multipurpose Hall, Headquarters Philippine Navy. 2. Defensive Cyberspace Operation (DCO) a.k.a CyDeX 2 — this will be on July 22-26, 2019 at Asero Hall, Marine Barracks Rudiardo Brown (MBRB) Taguig City, Manila. CyDex 2 is a Field Training Exercise (FTX) wherein participants will perform realistic cyber incident scenarios in a controlled environment. One of the proposed topics for the CyDeX 1 is the "The status of the 3"' Telco and the role of D"CT". In this regard, may we request for subject matter expert (SME) to discuss the above-mentioned topic. Should our request be granted, please contact our office at 522-2376 or LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN at 09178095116 or LCDR NOMER M BILBAO PN at 09173080900. Sincerely, FOR THE FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND, PN: ERIC E NICANOR Colonel PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4"SR Systems, N6

title: Chapter 3 - 09Apr2020.docx
author: juan
content: Plan Design Build Test Review Launch 44 Plan Design Build Test Review Launch Chapter 3 RESEARCH METHODOLOGY This chapter presents the project design and project development to provide blueprint of the entire system architecture. Operational procedure and method of testing and evaluation are explained to measure its effectiveness based on predefined parameters. Project Design The Cryptographic Instant Messaging (CIM) system is Instant Messaging (IM) application software that provides encrypted chat communication and file transfer for secure and reliable exchange of information. IM Relay ServerIM Relay Server IM Relay Server IM Relay Server INTERNETINTERNET INTERNET INTERNET EncryptEncryptDecryptDecrypt Encrypt Encrypt Decrypt Decrypt ReceiveReceiveSendSend Receive Receive Send Send Client XClient XClient YClient Y Client X Client X Client Y Client Y Figure 2. Interface Diagram of CIM Operational Concept and Dataflow Figure 2 from the previous page illustrates the fundamental structure of the system and flow of data from an end-user's perspective. Client X initiates a chat conversation with Client Y using the CIM client software. During the chat conversation, the system automatically encrypts the text message prior sending it to the IM Relay Server. The server now searches for the intended recipient from its list of client sockets. When the recipient's socket is available, the server transmits the encrypted text message to Client Y (recipient) through its socket. The server manages all clients' sockets. It handles authentication of all incoming clients prior acceptance of the socket. IM Relay Server maintains a minimal database using MS SQL Server, SQL Express, or MS Access for accounts and activity logs. As soon as the text message arrived at Client Y (recipient), the software then decrypts the text using the system-generated key as the default. Unreadable message or randomized characters indicates unmatched passkey. Both Client X (sender) and Client Y (recipient) m

title: PN SOP on Inventory of Devices and Software.docx

author: juan
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ INVENTORY AND CONTROL OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems, there is a need to use active monitoring, manage configuration and maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution. Maintaining inventories for hardware and software will identify vulnerable systems, detect malicious software, mitigate unpatched software, and root out attacks. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units for the inventory of Information Technology (IT) hardware and software SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. Cyber – is a prefix for a term or the modifier of a compound word, rather than a stand-alone word which usually relates to electronic data processing, information technology, electronic communications or information and compu

GENERAL: In order to reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems, there is a need to use active monitoring, manage configuration and maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution. Maintaining inventories for hardware and software will identify vulnerable systems, detect malicious software, mitigate unpatched software, and root out attacks. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units for the inventory of Information Technology (IT) hardware and software SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. title: PN SOP on Inventory of Devices and Software.docx

author: juan
content: PUNONG HIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila ON6/OTNA STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE NUMBER _________________________ INVENTORY AND CONTROL OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE REFERENCES: AFP SOP Nr 04 dated 30 Jan 2019, Subject: AFP Cyber Risk Assessment. AFP Cyber Strategy. Circular nr 29 dated 06 December 2017, Subject: PN Cybersecurity Policy. 20 Critical Security Controls by SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute. 2. GENERAL: In order to reduce the ability of attackers to find and exploit unauthorized and unprotected systems, there is a need to use active monitoring, manage configuration and maintain an up-to-date inventory of devices connected to the enterprise network, including servers, workstations, laptops, and remote devices. Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution. Maintaining inventories for hardware and software will identify vulnerable systems, detect malicious software, mitigate unpatched software, and root out attacks. PURPOSE: This SOP prescribes the general guidelines to units 6's and CEIS units for the inventory of Information Technology (IT) hardware and software SCOPE: This covers all PN Staff Officer for CEIS/C4ISR and PN CEIS units. DEFINITION OF TERMS: Asset - is any data, device, or other component of the environment that supports information-related activities. Assets generally include hardware (e.g. servers and switches), software (e.g. mission critical applications and support systems) and confidential information. title: Circular on Secure Baseline Configuration.docx
author: nelson
content: R E S T R I C T E D PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada 2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila O/N6 C I R C U L A R N U M B E R Philippine Navy Command and Control, Computers, Communication, and Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) Systems Secure Baseline Configuration PURPOSE: The purpose of this policy is to provide specific guidance and advisory to Philippine Navy units, offices, personnel, and third party stakeholders to ensure the employment of standard configurations to PN C4ISR Systems. It provides guidelines for the creation and maintenance of baseline configuration and employment of configuration change control (CCC) processes as mandated in Circular Nr 29 dated 06 December 2017: PN Cybersecurity Policy. This policy is important in order to maintain a secure C4ISR Systems for the PN and supports for managing security risks. This policy adopts the National Institute for Standards and Technology Special Publication (NIST-SP) 800-53 for Configuration Management (CM) wherein the controls under the said publication were mapped in ISO/IEC 27001 for Information technology–Security Techniques–Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)–Requirements. SCOPE: This policy applies to all PN personnel and third party stakeholders who administer, maintain, and operate PN C4ISR Systems. C4ISR Systems include but not limited to software/applications, operating system, Cybersecurity systems, and software-enabled C3 system and ISR systems. DEFINITION OF TERMINOLOGIES: Baseline Configuration - is a documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to systems. Baseline configurations include information about system components, network topology, and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. C4ISR Systems – pertains t

title: Chapter 2 - 09Apr2020.docx
author: nelson
content: 25 Chapter 2 CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK This chapter presents the review of previous literatures and studies related to Instant Messaging applications. It explores the earlier developments, previous research, and existing technologies leading to the development of a prototype cryptographic IM (CIM). It includes the operational definition of terms used, and the conceptual framework to visually synthesize all materials and techniques in achieving the desired objective. Review of Related Literature and Studies Historical Development of Instant Messaging (IM) The advent of Instant Messenger like Facebook Messenger, Skype, WhatsApp, Telegram, and other popular IM revolutionizes the way people communicate with each other. But its impressive features would not be possible without the earlier breakthrough of their predecessors. Desjardin (2016), in his article "The Evolution of Instant Messaging", narrates the written accounts that brought the IM and how it grows prominence in the new era. Instant Messaging became known in the 1990's but decades ago Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) already demonstrated an information sharing program called Compatible Time-Sharing System (CTSS). In 1988, Jarkko Oikarinen developed the first chat system that allows sending messages to users through their computers (Oikarinen, 1988). His Internet Relay Chat (IRC) paved the way for other IM players like AOL IM, ICQ, and Microsoft IRC to battle for share in the IM market. Yahoo messenger dominates in 1998 with its intuitive designs and feature-rich IM environment. Engel (2014) recounts how IM grow prominence in the 2000s. This was the golden age of instant messenger. MSN Messenger introduced the concept of sharing photos and included the PC-to-PC and PC-to-phone audio capabilities. Skype Messenger peaked in popularity in 2003 as it showcased Audio and Video chat capabilities. Facebook chat was first introduced in 2008 and accelerated its popularity in 2014 when it decouples from the Facebo

title: DICT Request for lecturer.doc
author: rodel
content: PUNONGHIMPILAN HUKBONG DAGAT NG PILIPINAS (Headquarters Philippine Navy) Naval Station Jose Andrada        2335 Roxas Boulevard, Manila SECRETARY ELISEO M RIO JR. Department of Information and Communications Technology C.P Garcia Ave., Diliman Quezon City Dear Secretary Rio: The Philippine Navy will be conducting the Cyber Defense Exercise 2019 (CyDEx 2019) on 15 to 26 July, 2019. This exercise evaluates the responsiveness and effectiveness of the existing PN doctrines, procedures, and protocols in cyber warfare.  The exercise will be conducted in two parts namely: Training and Awareness a.k.a. CyDeX 1  this will be conducted on July 15-19, 2019 at Multipurpose Hall, Headquarters Philippine Navy.  Defensive Cyberspace Operation (DCO) a.k.a CyDeX 2  this will be on July 22-26, 2019 at Asero Hall, Marine Barracks Rudiardo Brown (MBRB) Taguig City, Manila. CyDex 2 is a Field Training Exercise (FTX) wherein participants will perform realistic cyber incident scenarios in a controlled environment. One of the proposed topics for the CyDeX 1 is the The status of the 3rd Telco and the role of DICT. In this regard, may we request for subject matter expert (SME) to discuss the above-mentioned topic. Should our request be granted, please contact our office at 522-2376 or LCDR RODEL G BARRACA PN at 09178095116 or LCDR NOMER M BILBAO PN at 09173080900.  Sincerely, FOR THE FLAG OFFICER IN COMMAND, PN: ERIC    E    NICANOR  Colonel   PN(M)(GSC) AC of NS for C4ISR Systems, N6
